If I am ever lucky enough to live in Toronto again, while he is still alive and active in his current role, I would like to think that I would revisit his establishment several times.

Reg Hart advertises his wed. night screening as PWYC but warning!!! this is not the reality. We tried to give him what we could afford as we are low income artists, but he told us to get out and never come back again! He was so shockingly rude that I strongly discourage anyone from supporting this man's business. He doesn't deserve your money.

editorial_summary.overview: Regular screenings & discussion of unusual films & animated works in the home of the series founder.

117.name: Necessary Angel Theatre
117.formatted_address: 401 Richmond St W #393, Toronto, ON M5V 3A8, Canada

118.name: Socialive Media INC.
118.formatted_address: 388 Richmond St W, Toronto, ON M5V 3P1, Canada
reviews: Great media services.

119.name: Cinesphere Theatre
119.formatted_address: 955 Lake Shore Blvd W, Toronto, ON M6K 3B9, Canada
reviews: Cinesphere is the biggest IMAX screen in Ontario, I love watching movies here in the big screen. However if it a popular movie /sold out event. Make sure u arrive an hour early to get good seats, because it can get packed.  The seats aren’t the comfiest seats either they are a bit small and leg room are like any other movie theatre and not the greatest  Overall I’d definitely catch a movie at cinesphere. Good way to watch a movie u missed or a classic.

The Cinesphere is my favourite movie theatre ever! It is a building that looks really charming and futuristic from outside, but also is a very interesting experience when you come inside.  I watched the Wizard of Oz in 3D version and it was fantastic, the sound is so clear and crisp, the screen is huge and you feel like your inside the movie, greatly recommended for families, dates, going there with friends or even enjoying a great experience alone.  I hope they keep it open always and not only weekends!

We watched Raiders of the Lost Ark, and it was breathtaking. I had seen this film more times then I've seen the sky, yet this experience was like no other. I felt like a little kid watching it for the first time, experiencing everything for the first time. The Cinesphere provided decently comfortable seats and a wide range of food and beverage. The sound quality was stunning, and the screen resolution was crisp. I thoroughly enjoyed this trip, and hope they continue to show other installments of the Indiana Jones films.

Screen and sound are still great for an IMAX theatre.  Seating is getting old - cushioning is losing its support and dirty.  Seats are small and crowded feeling.  Anxiety inducing when theatre is full or others sitting beside you.  Would go again on an off time when it isn't so busy.

Amazing experience, will definitely go there again. Highly recommend to be there an hour before the movie time if you want to get good seats. I went there half an hour before the movie time and just the front 3 rows were empty.

120.name: Ontario Place
120.formatted_address: 955 Lake Shore Blvd W, Toronto, ON M6K 3B9, Canada
reviews: It's an escape from the city. You still hear the planes take off from Billy Bishop, but still much quieter compared to being next to Lake Shore. There is a long trail for walking and cycling to travel around the island. There are parks and little areas to rest and picnic. There is even a shoreline to access the lake to swim (too many rocks to be considered a beach). Overall, this is a good outdoor space.

I have been going to Ontario Place since I was a kid. Now almost 60! Still a great place to hang out! Sad that some of the exhibits have gone, but new ones still keep cropping up! Centre piece is the Budweiser Stage! Good venue! But being the old buy, I miss the old rotating stage. But that is me! Good place to visit and take the kids ( or not )

This is a beautiful place.  I have had great memories coming to this place as a young adult...great fireworks, live bands, drinks...  Well , it's a bit sad to see white paint is covered with rust spots...and pavilions are left in poor conditions.  The architecture is still a sight to behold after all these years.
Couldn’t get enough of sunset views! This will take a whole day to enjoy the whole both islands which Ontario Place is located on. Variety of fun activities for everyone!

The place was awesome, great views and serene ambiance. The only problem when I went to watch a show (Cirque du Soleil), was that we had to walk ~30 mins to reach the venue. There were no buses allowed in the area, I think

editorial_summary.overview: IMAX theatre inside a geodesic structure showing educational films & hits on an 80 ft. screen.

121.name: Zoomerhall
121.formatted_address: 70 Jefferson Ave, Toronto, ON M6K 3H4, Canada
reviews: Fantastic place. Everyone should visit. You are treated very well. Very positive environment. Greatest people.

122.name: DGTL CINE
122.formatted_address: 545 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1M1, Canada

123.name: CineCycle
123.formatted_address: 129 Spadina Ave., Toronto, ON M5A 1J7, Canada
reviews: Great underground vibe venue where DJ Kira Day Lee would love to play a special set one or more days)))

Went for a DJ event and they had the heat on, everyone was sweaty and disgusting. It smelled horrible in there and my glasses fogged up from how warm it was, not sure who thought the heat being on was a good idea for an event where people are dancing.

Fantastic space with exposed brick walls and a bar stocking decent beer and wine. Fantastic gathering for the cinematically inclined. Nice preserve of the old underground vibe of the neighbourhood.  Very enjoyable space for a private screening .... Highly recommended! 😀

Nice, spacious venue space, however if you are hosting an event here, beware that HDMI cables are not provided. Access to HDMI is not readily available, so digital screenings cannot be accommodated by owner. Bring DVD or VHS formats.

One of Toronto's hidden gems. If you're a film buff and want to explore Toronto's underground film culture this is your first stop. Martin is the kindest man who has ever lived. Go talk to him and enjoy his presence

editorial_summary.overview: This funky coffee bar, bicycle repair shop & cinema is located in an old coach house down an alley.

124.name: Standard Theatre
124.formatted_address: 285 Spadina Ave., Toronto, ON M5T 2E6, Canada

125.name: Ontario Place Drive-In
125.formatted_address: 955 Lake Shore Blvd W, Toronto, ON M6K 3B9, Canada
reviews: I walked in and around the RBC Lakeside Drive-in at Ontario Place today and curious if any further events planned as far as a drive in after TIFF

The experience is great if you have only two peopl but for families with 4 or more.. anyone sitting in the back cannot see the movie. The cars are socially distanced but you are not allowed to park backwards with the trunk open or even go outside. I paid for 5 people .... $79.10 including taxes and three of the five people in this car cannot enjoy the movie....and we have tried all available options. It's extremely frustrating to have spent such a large amount of money and be unable to see the screen or remain outside to watch it... We also came to the haunted movies where characters are supposed to scare you while you are in the car .... All they do is flash lights in your face and then run away... Maybe a little dance... Which is EXTREMELY distracting from the movie. I suggest to save your money... Go to the theatre.... Or stay in with a movie on the couch... I am very disappointed. I have attached a photo of our view for 1.5 hrs.
Very well organized. Great sound through car radio. Clean bathrooms and a snack bar. Good placement of cars for optimal viewing

I honestly haven't been yet, but I am sure it's great. Just for those wondering however, having a vehicle (at least during COVID times) is absolutely necessary.  We bought tickets online, but the day of the show, our driver/friend that owned the car, got food poisoning and therefore could no longer go. Tried to get a refund - turns out they don't do refunds (which is understandable). But alas with no car, you cannot get into the drive in unfortunately. Which seems obvious but I figured it didn't hurt to ask under the circumstances.  So you know, try and make sure everyone's good before you go!

This is the best drive in experience I've ever had. All the music on the radio is literally drive themed. Shut Up and Drive, Radio Ga Ga, Hitchin a Ride, etc. It's so amazing lol. Really professional. There are staff everywhere to answer any of your questions and guide you to your spot. Loved it. Will definitely be back again!

126.name: Tiff Bell Lightbox
126.formatted_address: 350 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1J2, Canada

127.name: Revue Cinema
127.formatted_address: 400 Roncesvalles Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 2M9, Canada
reviews: The Revue is such a charming place to watch a film. It’s a simple one screen theatre that show excellent new films, lots of classics, and cult films too. Every time I go I feel like I am participating in an an event and not just consuming media but viewing art. I would highly recommend anyone into film or who lives in the city to come here. There’s always something good showing!
It’s really like a scene from that movie;  Rebel without a cause! Watching movies at Revue is a very nice and local experience! I enjoyed it and will go there again for sure!

Fantastic atmosphere, movie selection and community. Slope of the floor is dated but that would be a huge undertaking to fix so I can't really complain. Lots of leg room and the seats kind of lean back which is lovely. Don't sit too close though!

Cute, quaint and well managed historical cinema. Comfy seats, great popcorn, reasonable priced refreshments, non-gendered washrooms. And .. a great selection of films. What's not to love?  Took 20 school-aged kids here last PA Day and we had a real blast! 💖

First time visit to see a Halloween themed showing of Ghostbusters. A lovely community event with kids and a few adults in costume. A very creative woman curated the event with an introduction to the movie and she'd made loot bags for everyone!!

editorial_summary.overview: Historic community-run theatre with 2nd-run Hollywood films & regular special-interest screenings.

128.name: Hot Docs Ted Rogers Cinema
128.formatted_address: 506 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1Y3, Canada
reviews: Excellent theater that programs a wide variety of new and classic documentaries. Definitely worth signing up for a membership, because they offer a bunch of free tickets to screenings to make it worthwhile. Seats are very comfortable and wide. They have main level and balcony seating. Just saw the new David Bowie Doc, "Moonage Daydream" there, which was awesome!
Missed this old places. Staff are still great but movie options were better in the past. Another building with the Rogers name on it. City sold to the highest bidder. Oh well.

Old movie theatre with updated selection of merchandise, good popcorn and the concession items are cheaper than at Cineplex. The screen is set high up, which makes the ground level seating require everyone to look up higher than normal. The seats are okay. Since you have to look up, being blocked by the person in front of you is not an issue (despite it being a very gradual rise). Pick your seats in advance, online, and add them to your Apple Wallet. Staff were very friendly. Saw a great documentary so very pleased that this theatre exists. Street parking.

LITTLE KNOWN FACT - KEANU REEVES "I remember there was a beautiful, wonderful cinema in Toronto called the Bloor Street Cinema... I remember summer nights just riding my bike, locking my bike up and going into a movie, they had salty good popcorn and I'd just chill out."   The photo of Keanu was taken in the 1970's.  Keanu also frequented the Bloor Street Cinema when he skipped drama class in high school in Toronto.  His drama teachers at the time were not pleased with him.  Little did they know, in later years Keanu Reeves would come to this very theater to present films in which he stared. Hot Docs Ted Rogers Cinema was of course formerly the Bloor Street Cinema.

Seriously the best experience and most fun ever! @Rockyhorrorpictureshowto The shadow cast blew my mind and other things!!! Didn't take pictures this time. So enthralled in the whole thing but definitely next time. Franknfurter is a star!!!

editorial_summary.overview: Restored 1913 movie theatre that screens documentaries & independent film festival fare.

129.name: Cineplex Cinemas Varsity and VIP
129.formatted_address: 55 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M4W 1A5, Canada
reviews: This location is mobility accessible, however there are a couple theatres that have steps to get into the theatre. Just ask a staff member and they can assist you to bypass the stairs.   The staff are very friendly and ready to assist. The location has a nice lounge area that serves alcohol and food as well. The lounge overlooks Bay Street. This is one of my favourite movie theatres that feels more personal and local.

The VIP experience sucked. Except for ordering the food from the seat - I had zero vantage literally. Waste of money and worse experience.  I have been to VIP to other Cineplex locations- where the seats are so cozy, folding type for the legs/necks/back etc with lots of space.  I will never go to the VIP in this cinemas again.  I am giving two stars for the regular screens and the staff/service.

My review here is mainly about the VIP experience. Buy your VIP tickets at another theatre.  The good: The servers were incredibly attentive. Our food was yummy and delivered right before our movie started.  The bad: The VIP theatres are tiny, which isn't usually a problem, except that the aisles are all very thin which makes it difficult for servers to deliver food and for movie-goers to navigate without at least stepping on a few toes. The seats are a little uncomfortable but not terrible, but the tables are absolutely tiny. Only just big enough to fit a plate of food, while praying it doesn't get knocked over by someone crab-walking to their seat. The cherry on top is the fact that the VIP theatres are located IN the lobby of this Cineplex, with barely any sound proofing. Which means whenever there's a line to get food, or a crowd just entering or exiting a movie, you can hear all the chatter just outside of the door while your movie plays. This was incredibly distracting and something I have never experienced at a Cineplex before.  If you're looking to watch a movie at this theatre, don't go to VIP. If you're looking for a VIP experience, visit another theatre.

Tip parking at Manulife is $3.00 after 6 on weekdays, you just have to validate it.  There is a small Starbucks (not all drinks) along with other snacks. The theather was clean, not too many people when we went.  There are prime seats available which we didn’t know about rows G & H I believe.  Overall recommend it

Consistent customer experience especially for a VIP experience is essential. I cannot even begin to explain how shook I was that I paid full premium price for a screen the size of an elementary school projector and seats the same as economy. This is this most pathetic VIP movie theatre I have ever experienced and cannot believe I paid for this. The regular theatre is more of a vip experience than this and I could have used my scene points and used and watched the movie for free but instead I paid the premium price to watch a movie from a minuscule screen and uncomfy barely reclining chairs. I will never go to this cineplex ever again. I would pay $7 max for this experience but instead my friend and I paid almost $100 for a lack of resolution movie experience. Customer experience is everything and I just can’t believe in such a luxurious area like young and bloor this theatre wouldn’t invest in actually creating a VIP movie watching experience. Incredibly shook and disappointed. Still not sure if this is real or if I’m in a movie.

editorial_summary.overview: Modern multiplex cinema chain screening the latest Hollywood films, plus new independent releases.

130.name: Tarragon Theatre
130.formatted_address: 30 Bridgman Ave, Toronto, ON M5R 1X3, Canada
reviews: I watched 'My sisters rage'.  I didn't know what to expect as I have very little experience with theatre.  I loved it.  Was engaging and the story was more enriching than when I went to the cineplex to see 'Black Adam'.   And I love Dwayne Johnson.

Came here for entrances and exits and was delightedly welcomed with free roasted marshmallows and hot chocolate, and enjoyed a magnificent and COVID-safe improv show featuring Canadian treasure Colin Mochrie. Will make this a holiday tradition. :)
I watched Cockroach and Post-democracy and both are spectacular and breathtaking performances! such a treat to be able to see live theatre with an engaged audience
Beautiful theatre and excellent productions, I went to “My sister’s rage” play and it was fantastic. Congratulations!

My friend did a one woman show.it was very good.the theater has been around for quite awhile and I am sure a lot of big names have performed there also they house the fringe festival  come see for your self.you won't be disappointed.

editorial_summary.overview: A pair of small spaces for original works, plus significant Canadian & international plays.

131.name: Cineplex Entertainment
131.formatted_address: 1303 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4T 2Y9, Canada
reviews: Do NOT get a job at all at this place. This is the head office of Cineplex Entertainment and their hiring process and their training is trash. I was let go there because "I was not the best fit." Well it was because their training is bad and they don't tell you that there are spots available. Their processes are trash as well as how this was organized. And the employees there suck too. All in all. DO NOT WORK AT GUEST SERVICES. The position is GARBAGE.

I was told I'd receive a call after 5pm to confirm a bday party I had booked a few weeks ago. That call has yet to come and it's now approaching 9pm here. I've been trying to reach the Vaughan location for almost 2 hours now and not a single person has bothered to pick up the phone!! Now, seats for our movie are filling up quickly, I have a girlfriend who's freaking out, and her daughter is about to have her birthday party ruined. This is unacceptable!! Worst customer service ever. We're planning on just cancelling the party altogether! -_-

Guys. No one likes 3D movies. You know it, I know it, even Stevie Wonder knows it. I understand you are in it to make money but if you could maybe get creative instead of just charging a premium on 90% of your showings it would be greatly appreciated. Signed, - Someone who really really dislikes 3D movies

I was at the cineplex on 795 Paramount Dr, Stoney Creek, ON around 12:27pm Nov.17. I went to the counter and wanted to add more money to my current gift card.  The attendant asked Laura the Assistant Manager on how to do that. Laura replied back and said that the gift card needs to be emptied in order to add more money. Which i believe to know that is incorrect. So Laura wasn't able to help me, so i thought i go to another of their workers and came across Sukhbir, and i mentioned to him that what  i was facing. Sukhbir was surprised on how that i wasn't able to add more money to a gift card. I asked Sukhbir if there is a higher manager i can speak to regarding this matter. He pointed me out to Ryan (manager higher up) i explained to Ryan my situation and he said immediately that it can be done. Ryan and i went to the front counter where Laura was working and Ryan asked on my behalf the same question, Laura repeatedly said that i cannot add more money to a current gift card unless its empty. Ryan said "lets just try" and Laura entered it on the till, and what do you know! it worked!, I said right away, "you all learned something today"..Something simple as adding more money to a gift card should not have taken so much of my time and headache. Laura (so called assistant manager) needs to be retrained and a refresher on customer service.. Thanks to Ryan for at least trying and getting it done. Also thanks to Sukhbir for his kindness.

Too many commercials. Sure, run 30 minutes of commercials before scheduled start time....that's fine, but then another 20 minutes after scheduled time? Sorry, I'm done with cineplex and silver city. I was enraged, the whole theatre was enraged. Destroyed the movie before it even started.

132.name: Lewis Kay Casting
132.formatted_address: 10 St Mary St, Toronto, ON M4Y 1P9, Canada

133.name: Innis Town Hall Theatre
133.formatted_address: Innis College, 2 Sussex Ave, Toronto, ON M5S 1J5, Canada
reviews: This cozy theatre accommodates tens of participants. Great for small-scale events! The hall belongs to the University of Toronto.
Located on the University of Toronto campus, it is a fully equipped cinema which hosts numerous film festivals, free film screenings and symposiums.
Came here for a spoken word poetry slam hosted by JAYU. Very friendly staff and comfortable seating!

Defiently enjoyed using the facilities. Used the space for Canadian International Faith and Family Film Festival CIFF, and it was great! It is easy to get to and find. Walking distance right off of St. George Station. Looking forward to using the the space again this year. It was perfect to be able to have two different films going at the same time throughout this event. And the outdoors added an extra touch for the red carpet feel.
Friendly staff. They are professional and caring. Great venue for events. Every time we had events there things go smoothly and attendees are impressed by the technology and professionalism.

134.name: Cineplex Entertainment Limited Partnership
134.formatted_address: 1300 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4T 1X3, Canada

135.name: New Circle of Cinema
135.formatted_address: 462 Dupont St, Toronto, ON M5R 1W6, Canada

136.name: Revue Cinema
136.formatted_address: 400 Roncesvalles Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 2M9, Canada
reviews: The Revue is such a charming place to watch a film. It’s a simple one screen theatre that show excellent new films, lots of classics, and cult films too. Every time I go I feel like I am participating in an an event and not just consuming media but viewing art. I would highly recommend anyone into film or who lives in the city to come here. There’s always something good showing!
It’s really like a scene from that movie;  Rebel without a cause! Watching movies at Revue is a very nice and local experience! I enjoyed it and will go there again for sure!

Fantastic atmosphere, movie selection and community. Slope of the floor is dated but that would be a huge undertaking to fix so I can't really complain. Lots of leg room and the seats kind of lean back which is lovely. Don't sit too close though!

Cute, quaint and well managed historical cinema. Comfy seats, great popcorn, reasonable priced refreshments, non-gendered washrooms. And .. a great selection of films. What's not to love?  Took 20 school-aged kids here last PA Day and we had a real blast! 💖

First time visit to see a Halloween themed showing of Ghostbusters. A lovely community event with kids and a few adults in costume. A very creative woman curated the event with an introduction to the movie and she'd made loot bags for everyone!!

editorial_summary.overview: Historic community-run theatre with 2nd-run Hollywood films & regular special-interest screenings.

137.name: Frame Discreet
137.formatted_address: 96 Vine Ave Unit 1B, Toronto, ON M6P 1V7, Canada
reviews: Had some Super8 scanned recently and the quality was phenomenal. The turn around was faster than anticipated and the staff was very kind. I will be back!

This is *the* place to get your motion picture film scanned. Very helpful company too and helped recommend me products.  Just wanted to edit my review, now that I have completed 5-6 Super 8mm cartridges. Their colour correction, communications and education have been invaluable. The team here has helped me learn and grow as an "artist". Not only are their scans top notch, but the value beyond that has been amazing. Super 8mm is an expensive medium, and it's not a medium you want to cheap out on in any way. Thanks to this team, my 5th and 6th cartridge produced 3:15 of footage on each one, which is a really high success rate for a new shooter.

Frame Discreet does terrific work!  I've worked with Lianne on two occasions , transferring 16mm to digital video and also Super-8!  She takes the time to explain to you what's happening and gives you all the possible options so you can make your transfer look as good as it can be. I was surprised at how good the transfer from 16 looked and sounded.  I felt very proud when my film was screened in Spain in its new digi version on a big screen!  Thanks FD!

Sent in a 35mm short film from out of town to be transferred to digital and it looked SO GREAT. The team kept in touch when my requested masking needing slight adjustment and sent screen captures so I could make the final call. I couldn't stop talking about how beautiful the file looked!
Beautiful work as always. World-class. Could not be happier with the service provided. Cannot wait to have more film scanned. Thank you.

138.name: Eyesore Cinema
138.formatted_address: 1176 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6H 1N1, Canada
reviews: Go support a video store! The staff are nice and want to help. The selection varies, but they have more horror/cult classic selection. They are able to order in lots of stuff they don't have already in stock, just ask.

what they lack in capitalist acumen they more than make up for in customer service and an equally passionate love and vitriol for international cinema. physical media for sale, DVD rentals and special orders/international shipping on DVDs and Blu-Ray

Great video rental store. I'm surprised they still exist but I'm glad they do just because of this place! The guy behind the counter was super helpful offering to order anything they didn't have in stock and checking for anything I asked about! The store itself has a huge selection and the prices are good! I loved the vibe and aesthetic of this place, it's great place to stop by! MAKE SURE TO PICK UP A COPY OF THEIR PHYSICAL NEWS LETTER! The hand drawn art was so cool and it presented some super cool ideas about monsters and such!
This was a fun so on my walk. If you're still into renting DVDs, then this place is for you! Fun categories and themes like the photo attached.

One of my favourite stores anywhere in the world. Great products, incredible customer service. I always loved visiting the store but now that travel isn’t a thing any more I am extremely grateful that I can order Blu Rays online from them and the service is quick, slick, efficient and they always arrive super speedy in perfect condition. Long live Eyesore Cinema!

139.name: Pix Film Gallery
139.formatted_address: 1411 Dufferin St Unit C, Toronto, ON M6H 4C7, Canada
reviews: This is an old school animation studio. This is how they used to make it. Classical animation using conventional techniques and equipment before computers. Very labour intensive. A lady runs this operation and you must admire her efforts for keeping the craft alive. Entire operation is based on donations. Please lend her your support.

A great  places where moving image is produced and shown. They have artist's residencies for production of animation, film, video, installation and performance. It is the house of celuloide, from super 8mm, 16mm and 35mm, all the equipment is available.
some old equipment demonstrated the historic films making.
Best Film gallery in Toronto!
old school

140.name: Killer B Cinema
140.formatted_address: 347 Keele St, Toronto, ON M6P 2K6, Canada

141.name: Apollo Theatre
141.formatted_address: 2901 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M6P 2M2, Canada

142.name: Hockey Hall of Fame
142.formatted_address: 30 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M5E 1X8, Canada
reviews: Oh it was an amazing experience. Walking around seeing all the great scenes and items hanging on display. The shot the puck and shootout were fun for the family. The main item was walking up the stairs into the great Hall. The presentation of the trophies and all the hall of fame walls was amazing. The staff members that took my family picture with the cup was great to talk to, as he even knew the Windsor area where we were from. He was talking like he still lives there and how he went to University and watched lots of hockey. It was a great way to experience everything.

I had a blast here, such an awesome Hall of Fame and a true honor to hockey. Has the humble beginnings of hockey from back in the 1890’s, and brings it forward to the last Stanley Cup Champions Colorado Avalanche. Tons of history, not just NHL, but Olympics, Women’s, Minor leagues and international leagues. Loved the summit section, such history there. The mask exhibit was cool with a nice shout to Plante for being the first to insist on a mask. Plenty of things for kids too, interactive shootouts and also goaltending drills. Had a wonderful time and for $20 or so a person it’s a superb value. The gift shop at the end is also nice, nothing outrageously priced.

What an amazing display.  Our game is represented in the most amazing way, as is the international game.  Featured 9 & 99 display was super cool... 2 of the very best ever.  If you like hockey... even a little bit... thisbis worth a stop.  You'll need a couple hours though,  it's a BIG display.

What a cool experience for any hockey fan! Amazing displays, plenty of history and memorabilia. Enjoyed the 9 & 99 featured display, two of the best to ever play the game. You can get your photo taken with the Stanley Cup for a small fee.  Interactive games can get quite busy. There's plenty to see for all ages, I'd budget about 2 hours here as there is a lot to see!
Really cool place! I really enjoyed it. First time in Toronto. Great experience if you are a sports fan!  You'll need at least an hour to get through the exhibits.

editorial_summary.overview: A vast collection of hockey memorabilia, including famous gear, interactive games & the Stanley Cup.

143.name: Art Gallery of Ontario
143.formatted_address: 317 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M5T 1G4, Canada
reviews: We went to this museum on a weekday and it was still a little busy but still nice. When you’re below 25, you have to register to an annual pass which is free but still takes up a few minutes. The museum in itself was not really my favorite because it had too much of contemporary art which I’m not so fond of. Otherwise, the floor with the miniature boat collection is really nice and the back stairs (accessible from the third and fourth floors) are worth going to admire the view from there. During our visit, there was a nice temporary exhibition which was really nice and intriguing and it seems like they have a nice set of these temp exhibitions !

Where do I even begin?!  I got to the gallery at 3pm, thinking 2.5hrs would be enough time to finish the exhibit. (The gallery closes at 5:30pm)  Spoiler alert: it wasn’t.  I barely made it through the first floor alone. 😭 will definitely be back though!!  If you can, make a day of it or get the annual pass for an additional $10 (day pass is $25).  In my case, I was only in town for a short visit so didn’t make sense for me to get the annual pass.

A huge 5 level of gallery with amazing arts, models, painting and sculpture by different artists. Every room has a story to tell and one can easily spend an hour just in one section. Make sure to eat well and have ample time with you to visit the gallery. Also, they have a stand where you can keep your coat and bag otherwise if you are carrying a backpack, you have to carry it either on the front or the side but not in the back.  I would recommend to get the tickets online or if you are a member of Toronto Public Library you can avail free passes every Saturday.  Overall, a lovely experience.

Great gallery.  Very pleased at the wide selection of art in the collection, including Canadian art, Indigenous art, and foreign art.  The temporary exhibits are also well done.  It’s also always free for people under 25, which is a great way to get young people involved in the arts!  Tickets should be purchased online in advance even if you are under 25, as you may need to wait for an email confirmation.

I spent approximately four hours in the museum just checking out the ground floor. There were four other levels that I didn't have the time to visit. There's A LOT to see here. It's worth it. Just make sure you have ample time to make the most out of it. There's even a restaurant and a gift shop, so you can pretty much spend most of your day here.

editorial_summary.overview: Large gallery with huge Canadian collection, European masterworks & a major Frank Gehry renovation.

144.name: Toronto's First Post Office
144.formatted_address: 260 Adelaide St E, Toronto, ON M5A 1N1, Canada
reviews: I discovered the first Toronto post office was at the heart of Toronto. The exterior itself was a beautiful architecture and well maintained. At first, it looked like a regular building, but when you go inside you submerged into the 1830's. The place was small, but the best museum to visit. You get to use featured ink pen to write your name and sand it off to dry it, as how people used to do. The staffs were very patience and nice, I got traditional seal wax on my postcards, which were unique. A must go place to explore

It was so peaceful to be visiting the first post office , loved trying to write with feather ink pens ❤️❤️❤️you can write as many and take it away with you . There’s also a small mini shop inside as you enter just opposite to Canada post and as you walk in , there’s a mini museum too ❤️

Visited the post office during OpendoorTO, it was packed. It is a small old post office. You could write messages with ink and take them with yourself. They have beautiful maps of the city of Toronto. It is worth a visit!

was it clean: yes was it efficient: yes was it kind: yes lovely lady wonderfully tackling the tasks all by herself was it straightforward: yes most importantly WAS IT ZEN: yes! Quiet and quaint spot to visit, sit and post mail from the city's first post office!
Great time to visit the First ever Post Office😀✌️

145.name: Mackenzie House
145.formatted_address: 82 Bond St, Toronto, ON M5B 1X2, Canada
reviews: Visited the Mackenzie House today for a workshop on the printing press. The two ladies who gave the presentation shared incredible insight on the history behind the printing press and our first ‘rebel mayor.’ They also guided us through the steps in making our own posters and bookmarks which we were able to take home. Overall, a fun while educational experience for the kids and myself.

Even though the main house is closed due to water damage, the hands on “tour” of the printing press and some of storytelling of the newspapers that William Mackenzie printed and distributed was fun. Vanna did a great job - there were only two of us, so it was essentially a private tour. She also talked about others who printed local newspapers, like Mary Ann Shadd, who has quite a story of her own. It was interesting thinking about the process that used to be used to print and communicate.
The staff are very knowledgeable and accommodating. We had a great time!

As a house museum aficionado, I can say this house is extremely well preserved. The tour guide was excellent and provided a ton of great tidbits. My favorite parts were the textiles and the working interior gas lights!

A small but  interesting museum devoted to publisher and first mayor of Toronto William Lyon Mackenzie. The tour guides were very knowledgeable and passionate. I really love their hands on printing experience. Pro tip for Toronto residents: you can get a free pass to historic sites in Toronto from your local Toronto Public Library. Just ask for the MAP pass.

editorial_summary.overview: 19th-century row house museum dedicated to historic politician & publisher William Lyon Mackenzie.

146.name: Osgoode Hall
146.formatted_address: 130 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5H 2N5, Canada
reviews: A unique, historical and beautiful location in the heart of Toronto. Features include an architecturally significant building dating back to 1829 and beautiful and tranquil gardens with several areas to sit and take in the surroundings. Large wrought iron fences surround the area and cobblestone drives are a wonderful feature. Large trees offer shade and one would not feel as though they are in the heart of a large metropolitan city.

I can't believe I passed by this beautiful place and never realized what it held inside! This building has a gorgeous library and it's full of paintings of past treasurers, each with their own unique touches! There's a dining hall thats been used for over a hundred years with short little seats because people were tinier back then. Come in for a treasure trove of Canadian law history :)
Beautiful hall anyone can get in. Pretty place for pictures. Has a gorgeous library on laws
Was there two years ago and was interested by the historical and architectural building. Especially the Great Library.

Very beautiful from the outside! The trees are absolutely lovely and the old design and floors were a sight to behold. One of the cooler architecture pieces of Toronto as it was designed more than 100 years ago! Definitely a treat to have explored it during doors open Toronto, as it was a great cultural experience and a fun one too! Definitely recommend!

editorial_summary.overview: Architecturally significant 19th-century building currently housing law offices & courts.

147.name: TIFF Bell Lightbox
147.formatted_address: 350 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 3X5, Canada
reviews: I was fortunate enough to attend TIFF..In conversation with Taylor swift! The best thing ever happened to me, I love TayTay & had been waiting from so long to see her & FINALLY❤️ I loved the theatre, audio-visual were on point & made a great experience for attendees.

A not for profit organization that screens more artistic movies than the big budget Hollywood extravaganzas we are used to.  This location has multiple screens for large showings (250 or so) to some smaller theatres that seat 20 viewers.  The staff and volunteers here are very friendly and always look forward to the big September festival that brings a worldwide cast of talent to showcase their goods for all to enjoy

Excellent seating arrangement and ambiance. The sound is amazing, I felt the screen size is a bit smaller compared to the regular Cineplex though . Excellent location at the heart of Toronto's Entertainment District.

The theatre is amazing and has a very nice viewing podium. Therefore even if you are in the front the movie doesn't look so close. The movie selections are really good as movies which don't get released elsewhere are present here. Members also get to watch movies for free too and the price of a ticket is also very affordable as well. Definitely make a trip to watch international acclaim movies without fail.

First time in and loved the ambience and the screening rooms. Quite spacious and friendly ushers to direct you as needed even if it's just getting to the restroom. Not privileged enough to get into the lounge so had to settle for the smaller cafeteria experience. Gift shop offered many TIFF assortment of purchase options and very informative staff. Very clean, well maintained.

editorial_summary.overview: This centre of the Toronto International Film Festival features world cinema & events year-round.

148.name: Ontario Black History Society
148.formatted_address: 10 Adelaide St E, Toronto, ON M5C 1J3, Canada
reviews: Outstanding.  I went on a tour with Pamela and learned so much about the ward and our Canadian black heritage.  Both Pamela and Michelle were exceptional in sharing their time, resources and knowledge with me. It was an entirely incredible day.  I was doing research on Vilola Desmond, these two ladies shared so much information with me. They were so helpful.
Great office, people are friendly and well informed. Before coming into the city give them a call for tour routes and upcoming events.
An incredible source of history. Treasures not found in the mainstream that need to be further amplified.
An amazing place full of history and great people
This place is awesome.

149.name: The Market Gallery
149.formatted_address: 95 Front St E, Toronto, ON M5E 1C2, Canada
reviews: This small but mighty gallery is on the second floor of the iconic St Lawrence Market, and is the former home of City Hall. The exhibit on now: "Toronto through the eyes of women artists". May is "Museum  Month" in the city of Toronto, meaning that you can get into nine city of Toronto-run museums for free with your Toronto library card. Visit here and you will get a terrific view of the St Lawrence Market below.

It's a nice little gallery. They have an exhibition until April 2020 about Street Art and the organization that is behind. And it is free for this particular exhibition. I didn't know where those murals come from. It has been a discovery to know that there is a huge work from the City of Toronto and many artist not only to decorate the city but also to mentor artists at all stages of their development.
Since moving to Toronto this gallery has become one of my favourites to stop into when I am i nthe area. Nice selection of local artists...good to support our locals!!!

I visited on a field trip and was so delighted! The man who was guiding us was funny, friendly, and sarcastic. We had a blast doing the various activities prepared and visiting the historic St. Lawrence Market.

I've seen to so many great shots that have been put on here over the years, historical Toronto photos, the CNE and just before COVID, the streetArToronto exhibit. I just can't find info on who the curator is for the space.

150.name: Haley Sharpe Design (Canada) Inc.
150.formatted_address: 75 Sherbourne St, Toronto, ON M5A 3X9, Canada

151.name: Enoch Turner Schoolhouse Museum and Special Events Venue
151.formatted_address: 106 Trinity St, Toronto, ON M5A 3C6, Canada
reviews: Very affordable wedding venue!  Ben who was on site for rehearsal and ceremony was great to work with.  Roxann, great email communication and was lovely meeting her on the day as well!  They have two easels for use, little chalkboards for small signs, and the schoolroom was perfect for a bridal suite - hair & make-up had no problems with their setup and there are four available electrical outlets in the schoolroom.  With the main room close to 150 people, it does get hot in the summer.

We went there during doors open event. It was great to learn the history of the place. They had some old books, toys and articles for display. The volunteers were kind to show us around and give us information too. Neat place for cozy events. Very tidy and well kept property.

Got married at the Enoch Turner this summer. The space is very pretty but the air conditioning cannot really keep up. The acoustics are not great as well and big chunks of the space need to be taken over by the caterers. Would not recommend it for weddings that include dancing of more than 30 people... Staff person was helpful but was dressed very, very casually. It was quite inappropriate. There was tension beyween him and the catering staff.

GREAT experience with this venue. Ben & Roxann are a great team - very communicative and clear on what will/won’t fly for the space. We had ~75 people for a ceremony and sit-down dinner wedding and had an incredible time. It is an excellent downtown location close to everything you would need. We have lots of teachers in our family so this was an immediate yes from both of us for the history aspect alone. We also loved that there was multiple rooms for guests to use throughout the course of the evening (the bar area, the "big" room and the schoolhouse).  This venue is a stunning canvas to create the event of your dreams - very DIY friendly. However, it should be made clear this is a historic place first, then an event space as a secondary function. Definitely not for you if you are looking for a full-service venue, everybody is there to help but not to manage your event. Roxann is incredibly good at recommendations for whatever you’re looking for - planners, music, you name it, they’ve got somebody. They have do preferred vendors for catering, DJ and some other services but the options are excellent and can accommodate various budgets. Even better that string lights can be set up by the venue in different configurations for a small fee. A number of tables and chairs are included with the venue; the chairs were recently (mid-2022) upgraded to chiavari style chairs in a dark wood. Would highly recommend this venue as a guest or as a host of an event.

2 weeks before my wedding, The Enoch Turner Schoolhouse began a roofing project. The outside of the venue was a disaster and NO ONE CARED! My credit card was charged without my authorization and all I was given were list of excuses and justifications. Shady business! Buyers Beware!!!

152.name: Prehistoria Museum & SkullStore Oddity Shop
152.formatted_address: 397 Dundas St E, Toronto, ON M5A 2A7, Canada
reviews: As far as I know, this is the only free museum you can go to in Toronto. It is a museum with a gift shop attached that is independently run. The museum part is a bunch of neat stuff put into a smaller space then it needs (by museum standards). However I did hear that they will soon be expanding to the main floor of the building in the future. If you're interested in ancient history, rocks, bones, taxidermy like I am, I recommend checking out this place. Beware if you are a collector you'll be enticed to spend more than you were planning to since they have a ton of cool stuff for sale. :)

This place is absolutely amazing and so is the staff. Highly recommended. So many interesting things to see and to purchase. So much to explore that you will need to make many return visits to be able to absorb it all. Can't wait for my next visit!

Lovely oddities museum in downtown Toronto. Admission is free, but donations are encouraged. Very cool selection of interesting items, all with unique stories behind them. They also run a store where you're able to purchase various skulls/bones, museum quality artifacts, trinkets etc. I've purchased many items from them. I've had one issue while ordering in which both items I had purchased off the website were listed as in stock, but they were actually sold out. They were very quick to rectify and went above and beyond in offering store credit towards another purchase, and when the other item I had selected also ended up being sold out, they swapped it out for a much nicer specimen at no extra charge. My favourite museum in Toronto!

Really cool place for people that like strange things! I went there not expecting much, but their museum has tons of cool things (from real voodoos to real skeletons)! The best part for me was the “museum guide” (which is also a magician). He spent almost an hour showing me around and telling me about the museum items! You can also buy random things at the shop, like human rib bones for $30. Definitely recommended for people that like oddities and strange things.

Best place to go if you don’t want crowds and interesting stories on every little item and I mean everything has a story ! A must little gem in Toronto ! Dundas and Milan 397 Dundas St E - Talk to Jim, he knows it all

153.name: Textile Museum of Canada
153.formatted_address: 55 Centre Ave, Toronto, ON M5G 2H5, Canada
reviews: The textile museum is really a good place to visit, it did has lots of great works. And you can registered the workshop on its website, which I really recommended. Few days before, I joined the “introduction to batik” as a beginner with no experience, but finished with some art work that I haven’t thought of. More importantly, it offered me two hours to relax by freehand drawing. The location is good with lots of restaurants nearby. I would definitely visit again and hope to take more workshops there.

Wonderful experience! Friendly staff, organized and clean space, spacious, with accessibility. Gender neutral washrooms which is a huge plus! I chose the option of ‘do not recommend to buy tickets in advance’ as I went today without a ticket since I wasn’t sure when I would be there and it was optional. Wed nights are optional pay! :)  Also, the Learning Hub looked very interesting and fun, too bad I had to leave. Next time I’ll be dabbling into the activities there. Lastly, cute little gift shop with reasonable pricing and local crafts. They also had books both in the gift shop and the library in the Learning Hub.

The only Museum in Canada dedicated to exploring the human experience through textiles.  This is huge 👏 👏 👏...it ignites creativity and inspires wonders. I really enjoyed my time spent here and the bold and colorful textile exhibits of Simone  Elizabeth Saunders as she explores personal history. It's a small boutique museum easily accessible by public transit.

I was very happy to go there because it was the first time I got to such a museum. There are several temporary exhibitions that can be viewed. I was in love with the interactive part where you could try different sewing techniques.

Being a textile designer, always on look for best textile discoveries!! There were three fiber art shows were going on. Staff was humble and helpful. I loved the vibe of the place. Also workshop area was interesting as well as Gift shop 🌸

editorial_summary.overview: Displays on historic & ethnographic fabrics, plus contemporary art & hands-on exhibits.

154.name: Campbell House Museum
154.formatted_address: 160 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5H 3H3, Canada
reviews: Passed by here on a Friday early afternoon (Dec 9, 2022). Currently it's be pay-what-you-can until December 23 to accommodate holiday programming and private events. Usually admission is $10 for adults, half price for youth and seniors, free for 12 and younger. Highly recommend a visit. The staff gave a really detailed tour of the house, its history and other fun tidbits. I had visited during open door events prior to the pandemic and the tour then was a lot less detailed because of the crowd. I'll definitely be on the look out next Christmas for tickets to a Christmas Carol at the museum next year.

Hidden gem to tour a Georgian home in the centre of Toronto. There aren't many left and a lovely museum. The architectural fragments in the yard come from demolished buildings in the area.  The tour guide we had was fantastic! Energy, knowledge, and great storyteller.  Before you start your day, take pause, have a walk through the gardens to centre yourself. It's very calming as it's set back from the street.  Concrete blocks and high rises everywhere else!!
Beautiful Georgian home right in the heart of downtown Toronto, a real look into the past. Our tour guide was fantastic, would go back again, they host really interesting and unique events!

Netflix Canada turned this place into an awesome holiday house with lots of fun things to do. There was free hot chocolate, free donuts, free sugar cookies and free goodie bags with chocolate. You could write a letter to santa and decorate your own ornament. You can also go to all the rooms to take pictures. It was fun. 👍

I was lucky to be visiting it yesterday on the 10th , I got to see artworks by gord peteran . Great house , learned so much today with the help of guides Sarah and Nishant , if you’re walking around you should def visit the house and see the beautiful Georgian architecture and interiors ❤️  The house was moved in 1970s because of a conflict so has modern extensions to it which is also interesting to watch !

editorial_summary.overview: Tours of this 1822 mansion, decorated in period furniture, offer insight into early life in Toronto.

155.name: Toronto Police Museum and Discovery Centre
155.formatted_address: 40 College St, Toronto, ON M5G 2J3, Canada
reviews: A small museum with lots of potential! (Especially given that the museum does not actually receive funding from the Police Service.) The concept is excellent and I passed by the curator by chance and had a little chat. She is a very friendly and warm person and you could tell she is dedicated to the museum! I enjoyed the interactive features; for example, you could ride on the motorcycle and have your photo taken. However, many of the lights in the gallery were not open/broken, making it difficult to see many of the exhibits/read the descriptions. And as another reviewer pointed out, some of the cases were dusty and the exhibits overall could use some updates. I understanding that it's challenging given the limited funding, so I'm really hoping that the museum receives more funding, as it's really neat to trace the history of a type of service that is so relevant and crucial to our everyday lives. Note that for individual visits, you no longer need to book in advance; just come by during its opening hours and pass through security at the front entrance. The gift shop closed early during my visit (not sure if that's a more long-term hour change), but I'd love to come back to the gift shop and take a look.

Nice little museum and quite interesting. However could do with an update. Uniforms on display could use a dusting. Glass cases give annoying reflections making the text hard to read. Text to several items in such small print it is barely legible. Interactive displays partly broken. No recent items or information. Don’t think it does justice to the work of the Toronto police.
TPS, Pioneers of Canadian Policing. Excellent tour of the museum, very educational.

My wife and I really enjoy visiting museums both large and small. We found what we consider a hidden gem of a museum in downtown Toronto. The Toronto Police Museum is located right in Police Headquarters on College St. This is a small museum but oh so full of the history of the Toronto Police Force from the 1800’s to the present day. We were given a tour of this facility by Norina, a fantastic guide with a deep knowledge of the workings of the Toronto Police.  This museum should be seen by all tourists and residents, for the great service the Police provides us. I am giving this a huge recommendation.

Smooth process at 9am. Really nice and respectful officer's who screened me. Many tellers to choose from, oh my. I had no problems requesting what I needed for employment services and with the correct identification and forms it was smooth crusing! 😎 Then it was off to work on such a hot morning!

156.name: Gallery Arcturus
156.formatted_address: 80 Gerrard St E, Toronto, ON M5B 1G6, Canada
reviews: I have passed by this art gallery so many times  but never went in. Gallery Arcturus is a not-for-profit contemporary art exhibit and education centre located at Church and Gerrard. It is  funded and operated by The Foundation for the Study of Objective Art, a private charity established to promote the study of art. It's not so small and mighty. I enjoyed the exhibits. Staff was super friendly. Oh, and it's FREE!

Stumbled upon Gallery Arcturus by chance I was instantly inspired by the incredible Art  work inside this fabulous gallery Ed and I had a lovely conversation about the serendipity of everything, Ed, absolutely made my day wonderfully charming. Thank you so kindly 🌞
A hidden gem with a warm welcome and a place to view art. Quite enjoy the reading room and comfortable seating. Discover something new and rest while reflecting on it for yourself.

Gallery Arcturus is it’s own little world, despite being packed inside two centennial townhouses. It hosts a variety of art styles, while the showings are fluid, changing gradually with time and providing a fresh experience every time I go.

Amazing gallery tucked out of sight of most. The staff are very friendly, and give you an explanation of what the gallery is all about. It is surprisingly large, and there is a quaint library room on the upper floors where one can sit and relax. All in all, would definitely recommend a trip here!

157.name: shopAGO
157.formatted_address: 317 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M5T 1G4, Canada
reviews: Had a variety of gifts relating to the art portraits and many small gifts such as jewelry and other small electronic related things like led string lights and mini microphones. Definitely recommend if you plan on purchasing some small art souvenirs!

Looking for quality Toronto or Canadian souvenirs? Then this is the place to purchase them. All sorts of goodies: cards, t-shirts, jewellery, art books, home accessories, kids toys, and more. A large and well laid out store.

I haven't been to the AGO in years.  I went to see the 'Black Fragments" exhibit.  A lot of the photographs reminded me of my families' photos.  It was very nice.  I got a free ticket from work.  The COC collaborated with them for some virtual events. The shop was huge and full of so many beautiful items inspired by the exhibits.  There is a book that has all the pictures from the " Black Fragments" exhibit for only $40.  So many lovely things, but I have mo room to put them.  Maybe someday when I have a decent place to live I can by something from the shop.
Great selection of gifts as well as artisans jewelry too!

When I need a gift, I shop at the AGO.  Items range from the whimsical to the elegant, artistic to the practical.  All the staff are exceptionally approachable and helpful; Dylan, especially, has helped me more than once when I have been at a loss.  If you are stressed about holiday shopping, the AGO shop is your salvation.

editorial_summary.overview: Art Gallery of Toronto on-site shop with a selection of arty objects, books, prints & jewellery.

158.name: Dance Collection Danse
158.formatted_address: 2 Carlton St. Suite 1303, Toronto, ON M5B 1J3, Canada
reviews: A Museum, Archives, Gallery and Research Centre. Dance Collection Danse has been collecting and preserving Canada's theatrical dance since 1986, and it should not to be missed if you're visiting or live in Toronto. More often than not, you will receive a personal tour of the space, and current exhibit, from either the Co-founder/Director or the Director of Collections and Research.
It's closed to the public since COVID.
An exceptional organization caring for and preserving dance on all forms and genres

159.name: Museum of Illusions
159.formatted_address: 132 Front St E, Toronto, ON M5A 1E2, Canada
reviews: 2022 March 4★ approximately 25$ or family of 4 for 93$ Off the streets of downtown Toronto you can easily miss this attraction given its narrow storefront and busy juncture.  Enter inside, the service counter serves as both a waiting area and a mini store selling both SWAG, puzzles and optical illusion books. Complimentary coat check is great. Although it's at your own risk, so no valuables should be left.  Once inside there are a myriad of illusions which the pictures really speak for itself.  The museum is divided into two sections. Total space is estimated to be about 5000sq feet of space. Given its size, it isn't really that big but there are a bunch of unique things to see.  Expect to spend about 45 minutes to 1 hour here, though you could spend less if it's not crowded and you fly through the exhibits. Exhibits do change once in a while.  It's worth checking out at least once. Paid street parking or parking lot nearby. Handicap accessible by request.

Museum of Illusion is a fun experience and spot to check out when in Toronto. Lots of cool exhibits throughout the little Museum. Take your camera 📷 and follow the guides set put to get the Illusion. Fun for all ages. It's a little spot but still took about 1 and 1.5 hours to see each exhibit. Felt the price was reasonable and staff is helpful. Tip ** I purchased my tickets online which meant no waiting.

We came here spontaneously and wow this was such an amazing experience. All of the illusions were amazing. My favorite was the True Self mirror. But honestly your kids and adults alike will absolutely enjoy this place.  Staff was very very kind and helpful.  Parking was a bit weird but right behind this building on George Street there was underground parking for $16 for a few hours. It was convenient when you figured it out.  Highly recommended.

We had sooooo much fun here🥰🥰🥰 Please take your time with every piece and delight in them🥰 And you will have a better time... So don't rush. Use your phone and take many different kind of pictures. There are lots of photo ops. At the end, bring some of the magic home with a puzzle piece from the mini gift shop 🧩🎲

We had an absolute blast at the Museum of Illusions!!! There are different illusions at every corner. From trippy pictures on the wall to experiences you can be a part of, the museum is incredibly interactive.  It is a super insta worthy spot and we got so many fun photos. The staff was very nice and explained to us how we can take the best possible pictures!

editorial_summary.overview: Small museum with optical illusions & holograms for selfies, plus logic games & a vortex tunnel.

160.name: Canada Law Book Limited
160.formatted_address: 100 Richmond St E, Toronto, ON M5C 1P1, Canada

161.name: Site of Toronto's First Well
161.formatted_address: Unnamed Road, 149 King St E, Toronto, ON M5C 2Y7, Canada

162.name: Art Gallery of Ontario
162.formatted_address: 317 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M5T 1G4, Canada
reviews: We went to this museum on a weekday and it was still a little busy but still nice. When you’re below 25, you have to register to an annual pass which is free but still takes up a few minutes. The museum in itself was not really my favorite because it had too much of contemporary art which I’m not so fond of. Otherwise, the floor with the miniature boat collection is really nice and the back stairs (accessible from the third and fourth floors) are worth going to admire the view from there. During our visit, there was a nice temporary exhibition which was really nice and intriguing and it seems like they have a nice set of these temp exhibitions !

Where do I even begin?!  I got to the gallery at 3pm, thinking 2.5hrs would be enough time to finish the exhibit. (The gallery closes at 5:30pm)  Spoiler alert: it wasn’t.  I barely made it through the first floor alone. 😭 will definitely be back though!!  If you can, make a day of it or get the annual pass for an additional $10 (day pass is $25).  In my case, I was only in town for a short visit so didn’t make sense for me to get the annual pass.

A huge 5 level of gallery with amazing arts, models, painting and sculpture by different artists. Every room has a story to tell and one can easily spend an hour just in one section. Make sure to eat well and have ample time with you to visit the gallery. Also, they have a stand where you can keep your coat and bag otherwise if you are carrying a backpack, you have to carry it either on the front or the side but not in the back.  I would recommend to get the tickets online or if you are a member of Toronto Public Library you can avail free passes every Saturday.  Overall, a lovely experience.

Great gallery.  Very pleased at the wide selection of art in the collection, including Canadian art, Indigenous art, and foreign art.  The temporary exhibits are also well done.  It’s also always free for people under 25, which is a great way to get young people involved in the arts!  Tickets should be purchased online in advance even if you are under 25, as you may need to wait for an email confirmation.

I spent approximately four hours in the museum just checking out the ground floor. There were four other levels that I didn't have the time to visit. There's A LOT to see here. It's worth it. Just make sure you have ample time to make the most out of it. There's even a restaurant and a gift shop, so you can pretty much spend most of your day here.

editorial_summary.overview: Large gallery with huge Canadian collection, European masterworks & a major Frank Gehry renovation.

163.name: Fort York National Historic Site
163.formatted_address: 250 Fort York Blvd, Toronto, ON M5V 3K9, Canada
reviews: The new visitor and interpretive centre adds a lot to the historic site.  As of June the museum is free and definitely worth seeing.  Do check the website before going as sometimes the visitor centre is closed for events, or the outdoor fort has festivals or other events going on.

Interesting historical site, glad they've preserved some original buildings! Be sure to visit the small visitor center as well. I spent about 2hrs here as I read most of the exhibits fully. Can't beat a museum site with free admission  :)

This is a national historic site.Many written and  interactive displays. There are guided tours in the premises every hour starting 11 am and last one is at 4 pm  that will give you a glimpse of the York Regiment life and details on  US - British war of 1812.  Entry fee : FREE Parking: Available right outside the visitor centre at the site under Gardiner highway.Rate is $1 per half an hour.
Gorgeous visitor centre is free to the public. Friendly and knowledgeable staff. This is a hidden gem of our nation’s history in a beautiful city. Tour was interesting and worth the price.

We loved it. It's a walk through the olden days and history. Each fort houses there's something to check out for. The welcome center has the hidden gem. It has an interactive walk through of what happened when the Americans attacked the fort. We almost missed that part, because we started with the fort visits first instead of going to the welcome center. It was free for when we visited in summer of 2022.

editorial_summary.overview: 43-acre landmark with original War of 1812 buildings & 1813 battle site, plus a visitors' centre.

164.name: TIFF Bell Lightbox
164.formatted_address: 350 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 3X5, Canada
reviews: I was fortunate enough to attend TIFF..In conversation with Taylor swift! The best thing ever happened to me, I love TayTay & had been waiting from so long to see her & FINALLY❤️ I loved the theatre, audio-visual were on point & made a great experience for attendees.

A not for profit organization that screens more artistic movies than the big budget Hollywood extravaganzas we are used to.  This location has multiple screens for large showings (250 or so) to some smaller theatres that seat 20 viewers.  The staff and volunteers here are very friendly and always look forward to the big September festival that brings a worldwide cast of talent to showcase their goods for all to enjoy

Excellent seating arrangement and ambiance. The sound is amazing, I felt the screen size is a bit smaller compared to the regular Cineplex though . Excellent location at the heart of Toronto's Entertainment District.

The theatre is amazing and has a very nice viewing podium. Therefore even if you are in the front the movie doesn't look so close. The movie selections are really good as movies which don't get released elsewhere are present here. Members also get to watch movies for free too and the price of a ticket is also very affordable as well. Definitely make a trip to watch international acclaim movies without fail.

First time in and loved the ambience and the screening rooms. Quite spacious and friendly ushers to direct you as needed even if it's just getting to the restroom. Not privileged enough to get into the lounge so had to settle for the smaller cafeteria experience. Gift shop offered many TIFF assortment of purchase options and very informative staff. Very clean, well maintained.

editorial_summary.overview: This centre of the Toronto International Film Festival features world cinema & events year-round.

165.name: Tatar Art Projects
165.formatted_address: 147 Liberty St #202, Toronto, ON M6K 3G3, Canada

166.name: Better Living Centre
166.formatted_address: 195 Princes' Blvd, Toronto, ON M6K 3C3, Canada
reviews: We were at the CNE on Aug 27 (Tue), the weather was overcast and rained for a bit but cleared just enough for us to enjoy all the rides without lines, multiple times.  Have all the tables to ourselves at the food building and get extra servings when we bought snacks.  We felt like VIPs, like they'd closed the park us.  Best day at the EX ever!
Had a really great time minus a small incident where the staff wasn't watching the kids and our child got hurt. Other than that, we had lots of fun.

In 1962 the Better Living Centre was built on the site of the Manufacturer’s Building which had burned down in 1961. The Better Living Centre is used by a number of various shows and special events.  I came here to watch people gamble from midnight to 6AM.
Clean and easy to find on the CNE grounds. Will definitely be back

I visited this area to see an exhibition named "The Artist Project" which displayed the artistic talent of Canadians all over the country. The venue itself is spacious and well suited for events like this. If other event coordinators are looking for venues to hold exhibitions or conventions I would highly suggest this place.

167.name: The Queen's York Rangers Museum
167.formatted_address: 660 Fleet St, Toronto, ON M5V 1A9, Canada
reviews: Nice clean place. Nice military marches. Nice people all around.
That's a place you meet people who will put their life on hold for love of humanity and country. Hooraa.

Jeffery Thomas smith pleasing evvery thing building structure spells my name Jeffery thomas smith and is a picture of me my fingerprints footprint jenetic palmprint blood-type retnal toeprint DNA rna ribcage spine chromsonal jet palmprint eyeball fleet jetc Jeffery Thomas smith commander chief highest ww1 ww2 star wars 2000 now and whatever Jeffery Thomas smith owner creater of evvery equipment forces planetary evvery of jeffery outer space I put Jeffery trillion here there per day and the Jeffery crown jewels for Jeffery where I also invented the Jeffery kings rangers military boy scouts and sports I invented that coat of arms for real and all of them fort foot right fleet feet port right footprint airport right foot the other body parts are nearby trillion times ways with my name
LAV3 (Afghanistan variant) on display is quite fascinating!!!
Amazing, military staff were very professional and friendly.

168.name: MZTV Museum Of Television
168.formatted_address: 64 Jefferson Ave, Toronto, ON M6K 1Y4, Canada
reviews: Got to experience this museum during Doors Open Toronto and it was brilliant The history of television is quite fascinating and it was really interesting seeing the evolution of it all. Staff were very knowledgeable and enthusiastic. Very impressive overall :)

I had never heard of this place, but my dad is a CARP member and mentioned wanting to go here.  What a fascinating collection they have, stepping back in time.  The museum is in the heart of Liberty Village, so it's accessible by transit, or there is street parking nearby.  Although the museum itself is only one large room, we easily spent a couple of hours in there.  There is a guided tour you can take on your phone that explains everything.  But you can also just read the placards they have, as there is a lot of detail.  The collection is displayed beautifully, and the staff are very friendly and knowledgeable.  We signed up for the mailing list as I understand that they have a ton of stuff that's still in storage.  They set up other exhibits and change things around once in awhile, so I'd love to see what else they have!

A really great place with one of a kind exhibits. Very interesting if you want to learn about the history of television. They also offer an app which gives additional information about the exhibits and is available in different languages. I even got a personal tour by the staff. The museum is made up of one huge room where you go around in a circle, this may sound small but I spent nearly two hours there. And the 10 dollars a ticket was definitely worth it.  -enthusiastic, helpful staff -Great exhibits -good price

Very nice experience .  Tons of information ..audio guides from you own phone in different languages..  the guy who was working there  was very kind and knowledgeable.   Nice facilities .clean.   Parking close by.    Tons of  TVs from the past .

Great museum! Darryl was super helpful and passionate about the museum. Fascinating collection with amazing information, and the interactive app to guide visitors around the museum was extremely helpful. Highly recommended!

editorial_summary.overview: Contemporary museum focusing on the history of television & its technology, with 10,000+ items.

169.name: A Room With a View Gallery
169.formatted_address: 129 Tecumseth St, Toronto, ON M6J 2H2, Canada

170.name: Classic House
170.formatted_address: 103 Gore Vale Ave, Toronto, ON M6J 2R5, Canada

171.name: G Gallery
171.formatted_address: 134 Ossington Ave, Toronto, ON M6J 2Z5, Canada

172.name: Fort York Visitor Centre
172.formatted_address: 250 Fort York Blvd, Toronto, ON M5V 1A9, Canada
reviews: Colin gave us a fantastic tour of Fort York. He was a great storyteller and was able to answer all of our follow up questions. Very knowledgeable!  Taking the outdoor tour is highly recommended!
Small little visitor area with a few exhibits. There is much more in the fort itself. This is a good place to kick off a visit to the fort.
Lots of paid parking out front. Lovely, modern exhibit that orients you to the site before seeing the historic buildings. Does require some walking so bring comfy shoes.
2018 Recipient of the Governor General's Medal in Architecture. A state-of-the-art orientation centre for one of Toronto's most important historical landscapes. Will visit again soon!
Nice place.  Should have actually hired a park/trail planner to design the outdoor space.  This is not enough to accommodate the growing community.

173.name: Fort York National Historic Site Office ( Employees Only )
173.formatted_address: 100 Garrison Rd, Toronto, ON M5V 3K9, Canada

174.name: The Royal Regiment of Canada Museum
174.formatted_address: 660 Fleet St, Toronto, ON M5V 1A9, Canada
reviews: Excellent Museum telling the story of a Fine Regiment of Canadian Infantry and its contributions to our Nation and the world.  The history of this Regiment is the story of the City of Toronto. The windows of the museum even provide a view to the Birthplace of Toronto (Old Fort York).  Learn about The Regiment's noble founding from what is now Ryerson University; the history behind why this Regiment is the only line infantry regiment authorized to wear the Guards uniform (normally worn only by the Guards units in the UK and in Ottawa); its amazing accomplishments in conflict, such as its contributions to Viking Force: Canada's first iteration of Special Operations; its involvement in the Dieppe Raid; and the drive through Holland. Learn about the stories of the Royals who served as Prisoners of War, and how they endured captivity.  Learn about The Regiment's the contributions of its members in warfighting and Peacekeeping operations around the world.  Discover the patriotic story of its founding.  Become familiar with famous members of The Regiment and their contributions, such as Sir Sandford Fleming: the founder of Standard Time and the first Canadian postage stamp; and so on.  Learn why The Royals are truly Toronto's Regiment.  Royals Ready... Aye Ready!!!
Home to The Royal Regiment of Canada, the 709 Signals Regiment, the Queen’s York Rangers, and the 32nd Canadian Brigade Group Battle School.
The best Canadian Forces Regiment in Toronto!!!
Best Regiment in Canada
Finest Regiment in Toronto

175.name: Galería arte contemporáneo de Ontario
175.formatted_address: 6228 King St W, Toronto, ON M6K 1E6, Canada

176.name: Fort York Community Garden
176.formatted_address: Fort York, Toronto, ON M5V 3K9, Canada

177.name: Canadian Agricultural Hall of Fame
177.formatted_address: Royal Agricultural Winter Fair Enercare Centre Exhibition Place, Toronto, ON M6K 3C3, Canada
reviews: The hall is open during the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair. It houses the portraits of 244 Canadians who have made significant contributions to Agriculture Industry. Some very interesting people are profiled from across Canada.
Place where you can have fun and education at the same time. Glad to see the agricultural side of Canada. Liked the dog show at the venue. Missed the horse show as this was expensive.
Couldn't even find a vendor that sold cowboy hats..at the royal winter fair...how does that work.

178.name: Little Sister Gallery
178.formatted_address: 13 Mansfield Ave, Toronto, ON M6J 2A9, Canada
reviews: A nice little galley, would recommend visiting. The artist is very friendly

179.name: Painted Walls
179.formatted_address: Graffiti Alley, Toronto, ON M5V 2W1, Canada

180.name: Myseum of Toronto
180.formatted_address: 401 Richmond St W LL01, Toronto, ON M5V 3A8, Canada
reviews: Interactive, yes. Waste of time, also yes. Thankfully we were in the neighborhood so we didn’t have to go too far out of our way to visit. From the web site “showcase the history, spaces, culture(s), architecture, and the people, that represent Toronto’s unique place in the world.” Instead it’s just four simple displays in a tiny room. Three where you write out your thoughts on pieces of paper and either stick it on a map, into a paper machete heart, or in an envelope. The other is a poll on an iPad about what you like about Toronto. No history, culture, etc. Had a much better experience at Mackenzie House (even with the main house closed due to water damage).
It was great to see this place. Alot of art gallery to check on.
As an art enthusiast, this museum was a great experience!
Best and Nice Wonderful beautiful fantastic

181.name: shopAGO
181.formatted_address: 317 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M5T 1G4, Canada
reviews: Had a variety of gifts relating to the art portraits and many small gifts such as jewelry and other small electronic related things like led string lights and mini microphones. Definitely recommend if you plan on purchasing some small art souvenirs!

Looking for quality Toronto or Canadian souvenirs? Then this is the place to purchase them. All sorts of goodies: cards, t-shirts, jewellery, art books, home accessories, kids toys, and more. A large and well laid out store.

I haven't been to the AGO in years.  I went to see the 'Black Fragments" exhibit.  A lot of the photographs reminded me of my families' photos.  It was very nice.  I got a free ticket from work.  The COC collaborated with them for some virtual events. The shop was huge and full of so many beautiful items inspired by the exhibits.  There is a book that has all the pictures from the " Black Fragments" exhibit for only $40.  So many lovely things, but I have mo room to put them.  Maybe someday when I have a decent place to live I can by something from the shop.
Great selection of gifts as well as artisans jewelry too!

When I need a gift, I shop at the AGO.  Items range from the whimsical to the elegant, artistic to the practical.  All the staff are exceptionally approachable and helpful; Dylan, especially, has helped me more than once when I have been at a loss.  If you are stressed about holiday shopping, the AGO shop is your salvation.

editorial_summary.overview: Art Gallery of Toronto on-site shop with a selection of arty objects, books, prints & jewellery.

182.name: SHEVCHENKO MUSEUM • LIBRARY • GALLERIES
182.formatted_address: 1604 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6P 1A7, Canada
