reviews: staff is exceptional and very well versed. Really great gallery. Very pleased with my visit. Newly renovated, very clean and modern. Worth checking it out
the lady who showed us around was really sweet and also the bathroom has toothbrushes
I went there to watch the movie night event, has a friendly atmosphere, and I enjoyed watching the movie Shchedryk

Lyudmyla was incredibly kind and gracious. She provided a bit of information about Ukrainian culture, as well as recommendations and backstories of some of the works and artists while I toured of the museum. The museum is clean, with all the exhibits clearly labeled. I was also able to view a lithograph of one of Shevchenko's self-portraits and learn a little bit more about each exhibitor. I wish her and Shevchenko Museum all the best in their upcoming events. :)
Nice place to visit Sunday afternoon and diary queen a few door away mmmm good cioa for now

183.name: Colborne Lodge
183.formatted_address: 11 Colborne Lodge Dr, Toronto, ON M6R, Canada
reviews: Free to visit during May, which is Museum Month. You must show your City of Toronto public library card.
This place was amazing you learn so much and the tour guide Megan seemed so knowledgeable about what she was saying!
Small tour, but worth it. Important fact: High Park is dry! Wow... who knew?

$30 for a family of 5. Guided tour of the Colbough Lodge which this home and owners owned this land. History of how High Park was  made. Apple cider and cookies provided to kids. Then had a long walk to park and the animals. Fresh air. Exercise . Great day

High park has every that most park don't,it has many natural paths in the woods tennis 🎾 swimming, a zoo and more. You won't be disappointed visiting the park, it runs as far from Bloor st to the south at the lake shore, take in the beautiful landscape, this is a 5 🌟!!!

editorial_summary.overview: An 1837 Regency-style cottage topped by a triple chimney, with period furniture & a picture gallery.

184.name: Museum of Contemporary Art Toronto Canada
184.formatted_address: 158 Sterling Rd #100, Toronto, ON M6R 2B7, Canada
reviews: Free Ground Floor entry and very reasonable pricing for paid exhibitions on 1st and 2nd floors. A wonderful space, with great original features (those concrete pillars!) And the most sumptuous cafe for pre or post treats.

Great space with contemporary art in a wide range of mediums. The current exhibit has some painting, photography, and sculpture but also includes works which utilize mixed media and interactivity. The museum occupies several floors and I recommend taking the stairs if you can.  There's a restaurant on the main floor but there is also a brewery and a coffee roastery nearby.

MOCA brings regularly rotated contemporary artists from all over the world and brings them to this gorgeous and spacious building! At the moment, there typically is only 3 floors and less than 5 exhibits/artists being featured, but its always awesome and thought provoking works of art! Every first Sunday of the month is free, sponsored by TD, so consider coming on one of those days.  MOCA has come a long way from their small gallery space on Queen West years ago, so we need to celebrate what they have been able to offer and make use of this beautiful space ❤️
Best place to spend Friday afternoon 🤩 This location has three floors of Contemporary Art. I would advise you to visit the Shirin Neshat exhibition while it is still ongoing (until July 31 2022)

A nice place to visit. One thing to note before going to the Museum of Contemporary Art Toronto is to review their website for the particular exhibition or display that is going on in the week you want to visit else you will be surprised by what you see compared to the art posted by reviewers. For example, during the day I visited, it was the exhibition of THOMAS DEMAND HOUSE OF CARD & MARTIN BOYCE, RIRKRIT TIRAVANIA, CARUSO STJOHN , and this is to run through December 2022. And so if you visit in February, you may not see any of these things.

editorial_summary.overview: Modern works by new & established artists are on display at this leading international art gallery.

185.name: Toronto Centre for Contemporary Art
185.formatted_address: 155 Roncesvalles Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 2L3, Canada

186.name: Mighty Brave Productions
186.formatted_address: 1 Herman Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 1Y1, Canada
reviews: Mighty Brave Productions is a creative powerhouse, rife with incredible imagination and innovation. I love their work unreservedly.

187.name: studio No 125
187.formatted_address: 163 Sterling Rd #125, Toronto, ON M6P 0A1, Canada

188.name: Todmorden Mills Heritage Site
188.formatted_address: 67 Pottery Rd, Toronto, ON M4K 2B9, Canada
reviews: A hidden gem! We were out for a family drive and just happened to turn into this place that we have always just drove past.  Good thing we did! It's an outdoor and indoor historic village, buildings from the late 1880s onwards.  They have building tours; the place is connected to walking trails; and inside the interpretive centre was a free art installation... An interactive one at that!  Washroom facilities are brand new and clean. Outside, there were brand new info plaques that even had a few audio nuggets to drop... Very cool! It's someplace that we will drop by once or twice a year to see what new installations they have on, and catch a tour!

Good place to walk around and get some fresh air. Nice area for a for walk. Interesting heritage site in the city. Many displays that had interactive speakers, now broken, need to be fixed. Current display canoes very interesting.

We visited for a tree-focused tour of the Wildflower reserve, led by conservationist Steve Smith. Fascinating to see the space through the eyes of the folks who built it, plant by plant by plant. The paths (out the South end of the parking areas) are worth the stroll for the birds and native bio diversity on view, even without the guide!

Walk the Don: Lower Don Trail ' Pottery Road (Todmorden Mills) to Cherry Street (Distillery District)  The Lower Don Trail is from Pottery Road to Cherry Street at the Distillery District, a total of 6 km.  Glad to see that the City of Toronto is investing on recreational trails.  The kilometer markers were new and the Corktown Common was likewise a recent development.  I was under the Prince Edward Viaduct and could see the subway crossing the viaduct.  When I am on the subway and passing by the viaduct and looking down, I could see the trail and the Don Valley Parkway to my right and Bayview Avenue to my left (when the train is going  The end of the trail was the Distillery District.

Visited the site in early October, 2022. A great (and free!) site/museum to learn about a neat, hidden piece of Toronto's history! This is a place that so many people pass by unknowingly on the DVP, so it's great to get to know the site and its impacts on the city's development. I especially liked stepping into the homes. They were very well preserved and have very cool artefacts/replicas, such as antique cash, TTC transfers, and what bathtubs (if you could call it so) used to look like. The grounds are also quite nice for a walk; you could take a short loop around the museum. I even spotted a blue heron! Would encourage more people to come and visit. Plus, you could walk from here to/from Evergreen Brick Works to make it a longer outing.

editorial_summary.overview: Restored 19th-century buildings, including 2 residences & a brewery, plus a wildflower preserve.

189.name: Russpanner
189.formatted_address: 45 Gamble Ave, East York, ON M4K 2H4, Canada

191.name: Pax Historia Gallery
191.formatted_address: 421 Bloor St E #205, Toronto, ON M4X 1X6, Canada

192.name: Cabbage Town Mural
192.formatted_address: 491 Parliament St, Toronto, ON M5A 3A3, Canada

193.name: Casa Loma
193.formatted_address: 1 Austin Terrace, Toronto, ON M5R 1X8, Canada
reviews: This was a great experience... very cool castle estate. Gardens were cool. Historical write-ups for the rooms, a horse stable, antique car museum, and a Back Stage Celebrities walk, which has little scenes with (wax?) statues and clips playing for all of the movies that were recorded at the castle. Loved it! I wasn't quite as excited about the 3rd floor, but if you are into military history, you would love it. Getting up to the tower was awesome, too.

Truly a beautiful space! It's a Gothic Revival style mansion and house museum with beautiful grounds during the summer. I can imagine weddings at this place! To get to the highest levels you have to take some very narrow stairs and if you are able to, it's totally worth going to the top. You will see amazing views of the surrounding areas! Can't wait to return here someday when things are back to normal, or as close to normal as possible!

The place was amazing. Last time that I was in here was when I was a child. Everything changed a lot! The guy at the front collecting tickets was super nice! And answered all our questions.  Our favorite was getting to climb the stairs all the way to the top floor! We wish the secret garden was open. I heard lots of good things about it. We also loved the celebrity rooms.  It keeps on running through my mind on what if Casa loma did an overnight thing where they turn off all the lights and everyone used a flashlight. That will be amazing. Maybe do this for Halloween?  We will be back for sure!

When visiting Toronto don’t miss the opportunity to visit this beautiful castle. The grounds and fountains and gardens are beautiful. So much elegance and history is packed in each room. This castle was really interesting and fun to explore. There are plenty of places to relax and just take in the views. It’s like a museum but more engaging and fun. Apparently they have a Halloween show but my visit was before then. I bet this place looks fabulous decked out for Christmas .

More than the castle and its architecture, I enjoyed the history of the castle presented in a documentary movie in the basement. So, be sure to check that out which is included in your ticket. Another perk is that you get audio guide devices which were very cool. The ones that we got did not have headphones so you had to hold them like you are speaking on the phone, but I saw some other people with devices having headphones. The most enjoyable part of the experience was that there are 2 towers that you had to climb very narrow stairs to reach the top. They were decorated and designed for escape room game purposes which was fun to see. Overall, it was a very pleasant experience.

editorial_summary.overview: Grand 18th-century castle featuring regular tours & gardens that are open seasonally.

194.name: Royal Ontario Museum
194.formatted_address: 100 Queens Park, Toronto, ON M5S 2C6, Canada
reviews: It is absolutely amazing, you can spend a whole day in the museum. It has different sections of historical ages from all over the world. You can see many things from different civilizations. I loved the geology part. You can find brilliant minerals and stones. It is one of the best museum I have ever seen. Highly recommended to visit.

The ROM is World Class, all the way! Better then any of the Smithsonian in Washington DC. It is really a natural history and art & culture museum rolled into one! I only spent a few hours here, however you could come here for days and still be able to take in everything. I would recommend visiting the museum website in advance and prioritize what collections you want to see. Some rooms are going to be more busy then others based on the content. Lots of child friendly exhibits, ask the curators as to which ones are best suited for children. I bought the city pass in advance. NOTE: For the city pass the museum does require you to pick a day of visitation in advance. The city pass made it easy to access the museum. I recommend a visit to the geology collection. Some of the biggest geodes I have ever seen!

Clean and organized. Big and spacious museum. The dinosaur floor is a win for the kids and the most packed. In other floors/exhibits, Not so much of the Displays are so archaic but still worth a visit.. The artist's exhibition is also a nice one, they help in introducing promising artists. We enjoyed our visit. We enjoyed it. There’s so many things to see at the ROM. We had less than 2 hours before closing, and wish we had more time. Each floor is full of amazing artifacts! Very informative, quick lines to get in, and worth visiting - especially with the CITY PASS. We will be back!

ROM has an amazing collection. Every section you go seems better than the previous. Even if you have specific interests you can't help but appreciate others. If one wants to take a glimpse at every exhibit it can easily take 3 hours to complete the museum. But if one really wants to examine and learn they can spend the whole day in one section

A day well spent at the ROM, from the Dinosaurs display to the Bats cave, from learning about the ancient to modern history of the World. The museum is large with pretty nice interiors and well-displayed artifacts; my favourites were the Minerals and Precious stones section. The staff was also polite and helpful. One thing I would suggest is that they should increase the closing time from 5:30 to 7 PM. Overall it's a nice place to spend the day.

editorial_summary.overview: Sprawling natural history & world cultures galleries, plus dinosaurs in the Libeskind crystal wing.

195.name: Spadina Museum
195.formatted_address: 285 Spadina Rd, Toronto, ON M5R 2V5, Canada
reviews: I was able to visit this place as a part of Doors Open Toronto. The house is fantastic - they've done a wonderful job maintaining the historical finishes inside - to match the photos that exist.  There was staff in every room, explaining details about the house. They had a video playing in the basement that went into even more detail.  The grounds are even more stunning. They had little games like they would have been playing in the 1800s. The trees were flowering(!!!), the gardens were perfect... It was breathtaking.

I really liked this museum. Excellent preservation of the home with very knowledgeable guides to take you on a tour of each room. There’s also the beautiful, really well-maintained grounds where you can grab a drink, do some reading or just sit and soak in the peace and quiet.  Highly recommend a visit, especially on a nice summer day.
Beautiful place! We spent amazing time here. Thank you so much for the tour, it’s was fascinating!  Recommend booking in advance to avoid disappointment, cause now spaces are limited.

Visited during Doors Open on a gorgeous sunny day; a fair number of visitors to the awesome gardens. Very peaceful and colourful. Noted many plants I know.  Lots in bloom.  The building is a historic landmark & is free entry always, according to the signage.

Nice historic landmark and pretty exterior- was here for the Dis/Mantle exhibit and it was great to learn briefly about Black history with a modern artistic interpretation.  It is currently a free exhibit!  There is a greenhouse in the garden but that is closed to the public.

editorial_summary.overview: Heritage home demonstrating domestic life in the 1920s & '30s, plus a Victorian-Edwardian garden.

196.name: Gardiner Museum
196.formatted_address: 111 Queens Park, Toronto, ON M5S 2C7, Canada
reviews: Such a unique and beautiful collection of ceramics. The first floor consists of pottery from the Americas and some new exhibits. The second floor has a wide collection of Japanese and Chinese ceramics - vases, tea sets, plates, and figurines. There is a beautiful  set of figurines in the European section on the same floor. If you appreciate decorative ceramics and glass, then this is a must see!

Collection -They had a large varieties of pottery from around the world. I was impressed by the pieces but also the conservation. They look like they were plucked out of time.  Staff - Friendly and knowledgeable, they have amazing people working at the museum.  Services - They do classes on clay pottery, so be sure to check it out. Also, it is free currently in 2022 Aug. Which is an amazing way to give back  to the community.  Highly recommend if you love pottery, ceramics, and art in general. 👍
Small museum with a very interesting collection of ceramics and porcelain from many different cultures and centuries. I really enjoyed it. There is a nice cafe/restaurant on the top. Friendly staff.

This is a smaller Museum and there is lots to see for sure. But my friend and I noticed that the curation wasn't very great and didn't speak to the diversity of the pieces that were there. There are a lot of pieces collected by older white folks for many years and while that might be the case the curations didn't speak to the pieces themselves and the history of the pieces in terms of how they might have been obtained and the difficulties with that.

I can’t believe the number of times I’ve been to the ROM and didn’t even know this gem of a museum existed so close! I went in to see the pieces created by Japneet Kaur and ended up really appreciating how much of the content was Southern American (esp. Peruvian) and south East Asian (esp. Japanese and Chinese). Very clean and low key so you can just have a quite stroll through the place!

editorial_summary.overview: Besides exhibits, this ceramics museum offers classes, lectures & tours, plus a bistro & gift shop.

197.name: Bata Shoe Museum
197.formatted_address: 327 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1W7, Canada
reviews: It's an OK museum. It won't take too long to finish unless you are checking the design of each shoe. It kind of gives an idea of how shoes evolved and also what's the future design may look like. We definitely found some interesting shoes that showed creativity. Don't forget to take the Match it game cards to make your walk through interesting. Honestly, it felt like the cost is a bit high for the size and shows of the museum.

Superbly laid out museum. Very structured and shows the entire history of shoes intertwined with world history, which makes for great reading, not boring at all. 5 floors of exhibits. Start from the basement which is fascinating. Can easily spend two hours here going through the loads of displays and attached descriptions.

A hidden gem a block over from the Royal Ontario Museum. Learn history and the history of shoes. Designer shoes-check, shoes for dolls-check, shoes for celebrities and royals-check. Some amazing historical facts are also presented in great detail and keeping in mind the sensitive nature of some of the topics. Kids can have fun trying to find the different images in a scavenger hunt, paint a shoe and even try out different styles of shoes. Overall a unique experience that will surprise you.

One of my favourite museums in all of Toronto. Their exhibits are apparently always changing so I’ll have to come back but just really cool learning about the history of footwear and all the evolutions of it in different cultures. Also it’s free on Sundays right now so don’t miss out.

The Bata Shoe Museum was ok, but a bit underwhelming. It’s $14/adult to enter. You enter on the 1st floor but have to go to the ground floor to get started. Then climb each floor to see the rest of the museum. I wish it was the other way around so you can take the elevator up and then walk downstairs.  The ground floor exhibit was interesting. It talks about the history of shoes throughout generations and by cultures. Each example had 1-3 shoes.  There was a small exhibit about dolls and breaking barriers which was neat, not not really about shoes.  The top floor exhibit was beautiful, but didn’t make sense and didn’t offer a lot. One part of the museum was closed.  What I wanted to see was more modern examples of shoes throughout generations. I wanted to see more “famous shoes” from celebrities or significant moments in time. Apparently the museum has a huge collection of shoes. I wish the ground floor exhibit was more robust.

editorial_summary.overview: The 4,500-year history of footwear is explored through hundreds of shoes such as specialty clogs.

198.name: Canadian Friends Of Israel Museum
198.formatted_address: 262 Warren Rd, Toronto, ON M4V 2S8, Canada
reviews: A house?
Loved it.
so so

199.name: Ukrainian Museum of Canada, Ontario Branch
199.formatted_address: 620 Spadina Ave., Toronto, ON M5S 2H4, Canada
reviews: Today was a special day .. as I got to know about Ukrainian history....  the exhibit was great ... Want to thank everyone involved, specially your ancestors . Thanks to them and their hard work, somehow we all “emigrants” have better way to start our lives in our new home ... ❣️
Highlight of my trip to Toronto. Thank you so much for the tour!
This small museum has an excellent collection of Ukrainian textiles (clothing, embroidery, etc.) and puts together some wonderful exhibits.
Nice place with interesting exhibitions.
Well organised exhibits

editorial_summary.overview: Large facility with 5,000+ artifacts & displays documenting the history of Ukrainians in Canada.

200.name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto - Justina M. Barnicke Gallery
200.formatted_address: 7 Hart House Cir, Toronto, ON M5S 3H3, Canada
reviews: I visited specifically for the exhibition Drift: Art and Dark Matter. It was excellent. The immersion of art in science that these artists expressed was so impressive. Take some time away from the university streets and just rest and intake something quiet.
Small gallery but it’s free and still nice! And there’s another one close by in the university.
It's a small gallery but definitely worth a visit. Would be nice if the staff were a bit more welcoming, but i take it they don't get many visitors
Certainly worth a visit.

The Justina M. Barnicke is a continuation of University of Toronto's Art Museum. The gallery showcases mainly contemporary art from both local and international artists. Featured exhibits rotate about every six weeks. The gallery is just two rooms, but is only steps away from the Larger half of the gallery, the University of Toronto Art Center . The Justina M. Barnick Gallery is a continuation of the University of Toronto Art Museum. The gallery mainly showcases contemporary art by local and international artists. The gallery is just two rooms away from the University of Toronto Arts Centre.

editorial_summary.overview: Gallery showcasing contemporary Canadian artists, plus select historical works.

201.name: Canadian Broadcast Museum Foundation
201.formatted_address: 1000 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4W 2K2, Canada
reviews: An important organization doing great work for Canadian history.  This is however incorrectly categorized as a museum- it is the office for the foundation. They have a small selection of artifacts that they are happy to show off, depending on what has arrived and not yet moved into their storage. Staff was informative and interesting.

202.name: Queen's Own Rifles of Canada Regimental Museum (The)
202.formatted_address: 1 Austin Terrace, Toronto, ON M5R 1X8, Canada
reviews: A very enlightening place to visit. Highly recommend for anyone that’s fascinated by the history of military intelligence and is interested in exploring the various aspects of military intelligence and international security (war). You will be blown away by the achievements and activities of Camp X
Great place to visit with the kids
Current and former soldiers volunteer at this museum. Great place to learn about Canada's role in various wars.
Would highly recommend

203.name: Lord Cultural Resources Inc
203.formatted_address: 1300 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4T 1X3, Canada

204.name: Tollkeepers' Cottage Museum
204.formatted_address: 750 Davenport Rd, Toronto, ON M6G 2B3, Canada
reviews: Back in the 1800's in what was then known as Upper Canada, private companies were contracted to build, improve and maintain roads, in return for which they were permitted to collect tolls from users. This museum represents such a cottage. It is a lovely small place that has friendly volunteer staff.

In the 19th century small tollkeeper's cottages were built to house tollkeepers who collected tolls on the roads that lead into the city later known as Toronto, Ontario. Private companies were licensed to maintain the province's roads, and they were allowed to levy tolls from those traveling on the road to pay for that maintenance. Tollkeepers were provided with cottages, so they could work from home.  The first tollkeeper's cottage was built in 1820, at the corner of Yonge and King streets, when that intersection was on the outskirts of York, Upper Canada. The tollkeeper system was retired in 1896.  In 1993 what had been tollhouse number 3, one of five tollhouses on Davenport Road was rediscovered. It had been moved, and repurposed, and was about to be demolished. After a long period of restoration it was turned into a museum, and turned into the centerpiece of a park, near its original location, at the corner of Davenport Road and Bathurst Street.  John Allemang, writing in The Globe and Mail, contrasted the poverty of working class citizens, as documented by the cottage, to the luxury of the rich, as documented by two nearby former mansions, Casa Loma and Spadina House, now open to the public. Allemang wrote:  For visitors not entranced by the history of tolls or roads, by the lost stories of the city's French roots, or the shameful betrayals of the Mississauga Indians who once lived here, the cottage can offer up a revealing picture of lower-class existence in 19th-century Toronto. If Casa Loma and Spadina House on the brow of the escarpment represent the aristocratic Upstairs, the tollkeeper's three-room house, with unheated bedrooms where children would sleep three to a bed, is all too clearly Downstairs.
The attention to detail is brilliant! The bedsheets are made of men’s suits. It’s the kind of stuff a lot of history books pass over.
Very nice pleasant place to visit. Very kind and knowledgeable staff. I helped found the cottage with my mother originally. They were very receptive to that.
Makes a great historical feels trip but is small so it doesn't have many artifacts

205.name: Taglialatella Galleries
205.formatted_address: 99 Yorkville Ave, Toronto, ON M5R 1C1, Canada
reviews: This could have been a really good experience but unfortunately because of one artist’s ignorance about mental health ruined everything for us. My son has been hospitalized with his mental health issues. But finally he was discharged a week ago and since he’s very artistic himself  I brought him to see this place. While we were admiring and enjoying all the art work he started commenting about this picture and went in his delusional state and started talking about who created that painting which wasn’t the name on the painting. Unfortunately that artist was right there and it seemed like he took it extremely personally. That artist took his wallet out and started showing my son his Id’s and credit cards and drivers licence to prove this is created by him in a loud and angry tone of voice. My son was in shock and still in his delusional  space and my son felt so confused and embarrassed. At that time my heart as a mother just broke into million pieces. My son couldn’t even stand. I offered my shoulder for my son to stay up. He held on to me and we had to get out of there right away.  This person rudely interrupted our private conversation and ruined our a potentially beautiful day just for his own insecurities I wish u weren’t there to spoil our fun day. If u weren’t there my son and I could have a memorable day. U r a terrible person to do this. I wish I would have never brought my son to this place. 😭 U had no business to intrude in our private conversation. Yet u took it and made it to your business.

Bought a piece of Mr. Brainwash art from Taglialatella at the Art Toronto Convention. Mackenzie and her partner were amazing to work with, sent me my receipt in a timely manner and kept me in the loop when my painting was ready to be picked up. Would recommend this gallery to anyone looking for a modern and unique piece, they have a great mix of Canadian and global artists!

Stumbled upon this pop-up gallery filled with Pop art works of Mr. Brainwash. Stepped into a world of iconic works of mixed mediums and elements in a very well spaced out show space that was comfortable in current times to walk through and view. The paper, sculptures were quite unique along with the various pop-art works showcasing Marilyn Monroe wearing mask was very chic and relative to our time. Jimmy Hendrik piece was a home run. I do hope this showcase gets to be seen.
Ran by Pros, the art collection covers all styles and tastes and they go out of they way to make things happen for you. Shout out to Alan, & JORDAN
Brainwash Pop-Up Gallery is top notch

206.name: Muzeum Inc
206.formatted_address: 128E Cumberland St, Toronto, ON M5R 1A6, Canada

207.name: VEMU Estonian Museum Canada
207.formatted_address: 310 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1W4, Canada

208.name: Performance Terrace Helga and Mike Schmidt
208.formatted_address: Royal Ontario Museum, 100 Queens Park, Toronto, ON M5S 2C6, Canada

209.name: The Studio Building
209.formatted_address: 25 Severn St, Toronto, ON M4W 1M7, Canada
reviews: Built in 1914 by Eden Smithand used by Group of Seven as their working studio (Tom Thomson,  A.  Y.  Jackson,  Lawren Harris,  Franklin Carmichael). Visited by Emily Carr as well as later by Gordon MacNamara who owned it from 1948 to 2006.

210.name: TD Gallery at Toronto Reference Library
210.formatted_address: 789 Yonge St Main Floor, Toronto, ON M4W 2G8, Canada
reviews: Such a gem in the Toronto Reference Library!  The current exhibit showcases images of Toronto's past as seen through the eyes of a number of Toronto artists, each with different styles. The gallery is located on the ground floor, to the right  of the elevators.
Block By Block Exhibition is IMPORTANT in understanding Toronto's immigration story from 1960 to now.
Gives a detailed background about the man behind Sherlock Holmes.
I went to see the Alice in Wonderland exhibit. It was beautiful and the guided tour was exceptional. I suspect most exhibitions here are equally impressive.

211.name: H by u
211.formatted_address: 230 Lonsmount Dr, Toronto, ON M5P 2Z1, Canada

212.name: Wedge Curatorial Projects
212.formatted_address: 800 Bathurst St #503, Toronto, ON M5R 3M8, Canada

213.name: SHEVCHENKO MUSEUM • LIBRARY • GALLERIES
213.formatted_address: 1604 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6P 1A7, Canada
reviews: staff is exceptional and very well versed. Really great gallery. Very pleased with my visit. Newly renovated, very clean and modern. Worth checking it out
the lady who showed us around was really sweet and also the bathroom has toothbrushes
I went there to watch the movie night event, has a friendly atmosphere, and I enjoyed watching the movie Shchedryk

Lyudmyla was incredibly kind and gracious. She provided a bit of information about Ukrainian culture, as well as recommendations and backstories of some of the works and artists while I toured of the museum. The museum is clean, with all the exhibits clearly labeled. I was also able to view a lithograph of one of Shevchenko's self-portraits and learn a little bit more about each exhibitor. I wish her and Shevchenko Museum all the best in their upcoming events. :)
Nice place to visit Sunday afternoon and diary queen a few door away mmmm good cioa for now

214.name: Fresh Never Frozen Art
214.formatted_address: 258 Wallace Ave Studio 108, Toronto, ON M6P 3M9, Canada
reviews: Organized, prepared, easy to deal with.

215.name: Museum of Contemporary Art Toronto Canada
215.formatted_address: 158 Sterling Rd #100, Toronto, ON M6R 2B7, Canada
reviews: Free Ground Floor entry and very reasonable pricing for paid exhibitions on 1st and 2nd floors. A wonderful space, with great original features (those concrete pillars!) And the most sumptuous cafe for pre or post treats.

Great space with contemporary art in a wide range of mediums. The current exhibit has some painting, photography, and sculpture but also includes works which utilize mixed media and interactivity. The museum occupies several floors and I recommend taking the stairs if you can.  There's a restaurant on the main floor but there is also a brewery and a coffee roastery nearby.

MOCA brings regularly rotated contemporary artists from all over the world and brings them to this gorgeous and spacious building! At the moment, there typically is only 3 floors and less than 5 exhibits/artists being featured, but its always awesome and thought provoking works of art! Every first Sunday of the month is free, sponsored by TD, so consider coming on one of those days.  MOCA has come a long way from their small gallery space on Queen West years ago, so we need to celebrate what they have been able to offer and make use of this beautiful space ❤️
Best place to spend Friday afternoon 🤩 This location has three floors of Contemporary Art. I would advise you to visit the Shirin Neshat exhibition while it is still ongoing (until July 31 2022)

A nice place to visit. One thing to note before going to the Museum of Contemporary Art Toronto is to review their website for the particular exhibition or display that is going on in the week you want to visit else you will be surprised by what you see compared to the art posted by reviewers. For example, during the day I visited, it was the exhibition of THOMAS DEMAND HOUSE OF CARD & MARTIN BOYCE, RIRKRIT TIRAVANIA, CARUSO STJOHN , and this is to run through December 2022. And so if you visit in February, you may not see any of these things.

editorial_summary.overview: Modern works by new & established artists are on display at this leading international art gallery.

216.name: Zalucky Contemporary
216.formatted_address: 3044 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M6P 1Z3, Canada
reviews: Perfectly displayed artwork. Knowledgeable staff welcoming and informative to the non artist. Easy to find location.
The owner was lovely and the exhibit was extraordinary!!! Really special work, must see.
Small space and a great addition to the Junction especially with the small town feel of this area.  Great little spot during your afternoon.

217.name: Track and Field Gallery
217.formatted_address: 76 Miller St, Toronto, ON M6N 2Z9, Canada

218.name: Artusiasm
218.formatted_address: 1682 St Clair Ave W A, Toronto, ON M6N 1H8, Canada

219.name: studio No 125
219.formatted_address: 163 Sterling Rd #125, Toronto, ON M6P 0A1, Canada

220.name: Mighty Brave Productions
220.formatted_address: 1 Herman Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 1Y1, Canada
reviews: Mighty Brave Productions is a creative powerhouse, rife with incredible imagination and innovation. I love their work unreservedly.

221.name: The Bayou
221.formatted_address: 1053 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6H 1M4, Canada
reviews: The bayou helped me understand that I am a mantis reincarnated. Highly recommend
It was so cute and funny!
How many hetdegs does it take to make a disco?
No shortage of cheetos
A great place to sweat

222.name: Gallery Of The Portuguese Pioneers
222.formatted_address: 960 St Clair Ave W, Toronto, ON M6E 1A1, Canada
reviews: A small cozy place that occasionally has get community get togethers for special guests.

223.name: BiJunk
223.formatted_address: 202 Delaware Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 1L6, Canada

224.name: Psychic Crystal ball Reader And Healer
224.formatted_address: 886 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6G 1M5, Canada

225.name: The Rex Hotel Jazz and Blues Bar
225.formatted_address: 194 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1Z1, Canada
reviews: Don't forget to use ʜᴏᴛᴇʟʙoʟʟʏ.ᴄᴏm when booking a room. This website will compare hundreds of hotel sites and typically will have rooms much cheaper compared to others! Thank me later! This resort is the best rated in this area. I've been coming here for a long time. If you stay for a few nights you definitely will love it I'm sure!  Great place for live music, and amazing seats to view the band as well. Food servings were surprisingly filling and staff were amazing. Can’t go wrong coming here for a good time.

I stayed one night recently. The Rex was awesome in every way. Extremely clean, friendly and willing to please. Room was small but it cost one third of next cheapest hotel in area. Parking next door was only $25 for 24 hours so we parked it and enjoyed the great neighborhood.  Food and jazz band was great part of trip! Mike was helpful on desk..all aspects were great beyond expectations!!

Beautiful old timely diner with an open mic stage. Good audience and drinks. Best to go with your friends or family. Lovely staff and service. Polite and quiet people who love jazz blues and acoustic. I loved this place I'd come back with a date. Good if you love old timey and vintage.

The Rex Hotel Jazz and Blues Bar are located at the heart of Toronto Downtown. This place defines a 'cozy place.' The music started at 8.30 PM, as they mentioned on the ticket.  We bought a ticket for Roberto Occhipinti Quartet. We preferred to sit in the bar section, which was very influential in comparing the price and quality.  I can suggest buying a ticket from the bar section. you can see the main scene, don't worry. To have the best personal music listening experience, my advice is to go with a maximum of 2 people. You can even feel meditating on the music while you go alone and sip your drink. Rex Jazz and Blues Bar are highly recommended if you want to give yourself a relaxing night experience. Prices are fair; you must wait a while to deliver your order. That is the only negative side. Overall good experience.

The steak and sweet potato fries are amazing, the atmosphere is terrific, the service is nice, friendly, and timely. Its just small enough to feel cozy but not cramped. The drinks are a bit pricy but the food makes up for it! They host some amazing musicians I highly recommend it!

editorial_summary.overview: Unpretentious hotel with streamlined rooms & casual dining, plus a hip bar with nightly jazz.

226.name: Oliver & Bonacini Café Grill, Yonge & Front
226.formatted_address: 33 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M5E 1G4, Canada
reviews: 3.5/5 First time here for lunch on a Friday and it was a lovely setting with friendly service. The server was continually topping up our glasses of water & wine. The fish and chips was tasty but had just an extra amount of salt. The bolognese was disappointing as it tasted like a freezer made one with better presentation. For the price it was fine but I don’t think I’d return.

The staff was very friendly and attentive. It was a pretty laid back environment. I had the impossible smash burger which was good. The drinks were good as well. I would have only wished the drinks were slightly larger same with the burger. All in all a pretty good experience. It is a good place to try if you are in the area.

Came here to celebrate my Wife's birthday. The food, service and ambiance were awesome. The carrot cake is a legacy recipe and must try here. We enjoyed our food and the complimentary cake! Will visit again. 5/5.

Went here when on holiday in Toronto in October 2021.  This was a fantastic place to stop for food and drink.  We sat outside and the service was excellent.  The food was of the highest quality and absolutely lovely.  Would definitely recommend if you are in Toronto

The service was great. Everything was quick. We did also order the tempura shrimp, I forgot to take a photo bc I was so hungry, that was overpriced and it wasn’t real shrimp tempura.. more like a spring roll type crust. Still good

editorial_summary.overview: Pastas, wood-fired pizzas & international dishes in a sprawling, minimalist setting with a patio.

227.name: Phoenix Concert Theatre
227.formatted_address: 410 Sherbourne St, Toronto, ON M5X 1K2, Canada
reviews: Grateful to have small old venues like this in Toronto.  For the first time we sat at the upstairs balcony rather than the standing floor downstairs. It was not bad. Upstairs has separate bar ( if you are interested) and the views were still good.

Great venue for concerts. Grab a beer and enjoy the music. Fortunate to see I Mother Earth and Sloan here last night. Fantastic event with a great atmosphere of music lovers. I will be coming to more concerts here in future.

Been here a tone of times, one of my favourite venues for sure! It’s small and intimate and old and just full of soul. Very thorough pat down on the way in. Pretty chill on the weed smoking last show I was at. But I have seen them super strict about it on the past.
Not known for the best sound, or for opening their doors at the scheduled time (no matter the weather). They do host an incredible array of bands. Just don't use the washrooms if you can hold it.

Sweet place! It was perfect for the concert we seen. Quick access bars. Lots of room. Friendly staff. Even found a plug So I could charge my phone.  Seeing Matt Maeson was everything I wanted and more. Thanks for hosting!

editorial_summary.overview: Spacious standing-room-only concert venue with 3 separate rooms, several bars & weekend dancing.

228.name: The Reservoir Lounge
228.formatted_address: 52 Wellington St E, Toronto, ON M5E 1C7, Canada
reviews: A true Toronto gem. Easily the best jazz bar in town. What a true jazz bar is meant to be, intimate, unpretentious, all about the music. Still one of my favourites hangs and one of the nest spots in town for live performances. Get the sliders when you're there, they are heavenly!!

It's a really nice place to go out for a date. The music is good if you like jazz. We went there on a  Saturday night. The sliders were nothing special but the appetizer with the wild mushrooms on bread was really good. We had to pay a $15 cover charge each to get in. Normally I would give three stars but because of the service and the band Ill give a 4.

The food was delicious, the music and the atmosphere was amazing. It was little bit crowded for post COVID. It has a $15 entrance fee. I recommend to make a reservation if you like to sit down. If not, by around 11, some of the seats will be empty, you may be able to sit on those. We went there on Friday night and Alison Young and her band were amazing.

We had one of the best nights here!!! The live band was amazing and the food delicious !! You need to try the Wild Mushroom Devil Toast! Great time at a great price! You should make a reservation if you want a table. If not, you can drop by and stand around the bar.

A lovely way to enjoy some blues and some jazz! Our server (and the owner) were so kind—it made our experience that much more special.  The cocktails are expensive, but delicious. The food is also so good—I got the mushroom pizza and it was perfection. The vibe is the reason to go; it’s very chill and has some wonderful music. We suggest going to dinner so that you have the table for the entire night.

editorial_summary.overview: Intimate basement joint with live jazz, swing & blues 5 nights a week, late-night tapas & cocktails.

229.name: Pravda Vodka Bar
229.formatted_address: 44 Wellington St E, Toronto, ON M5E 1C7, Canada
reviews: Great place to for dates and events!  Great 2 storey bar. Themed and decorated well.  The staff are super nice and can recommend some awesome drinks.  The foods is good and comes out at an appropriate time so it's noce and hot.  They have a good martini menu full of interesting flavours, they can also substitute if needed.  They have a live DJ every Thursday, Friday, Saturday, with a different DJ every night.  Very funny for birthday parties, corporate events.
Went here for an event, the drinks and hodeurves were pretty solid. The drinks had silver and gold sprinklings on them 🙂 Not sure if that is usually on the menu though.

Such an amazing vibe and services. They were so accommodating. The bottles are so reasonably priced. And the owner is an amazing woman that went over and beyond what I would have expected from any club. This is my go to spot for all events. Always lively and great entertainment
Amazing, amazing, amazing. I’m definitely going to make this my must go spot. The DJ on Saturday night was great, great entertainment and I loved the mature crowd.

Belly dancer is amazing and the music is good. The set up is cool too. Definitely a place you need to go to with more people because everyone seems to cling to their own groups even though it’s a small enough setting to rub arms with most of the people there.

editorial_summary.overview: Chic Soviet resto-bar offering an eclectic menu with Russian touches, plus happy-hour specials.

230.name: bar244
230.formatted_address: 244 Adelaide St W, Toronto, ON M5H 1X6, Canada
reviews: Terrible and unsafe.  Went for New Years Eve, which was supposed to be a ticketed event. Purchased 6 tickets on club crawlers before and got to the club around 11. Line was on wrongside and wasted 20 minutes after they made everyone shift to the other side. Bought tickets thinking that it would be better than a place which was open access and could get crowded. But in line they were letting mostly everyone in (with and without tickets) and the place was filled to the point that you couldn't move freely upstairs. People were packed so tightly that it was definitely a fire/stampede risk environment and certain men took advantage of the zero personal space situation (grabbing and touching my female friends and I inappropriately). Coat check was full so we had to carry our jackets and we wasted time after midnight waiting for drinks downstairs that we never got because they ran out of glasses. Bought two shots of rum at the other bar upstairs for $15 and left asap when it reached the most crowded that you couldn't even dance or breathe.  Overall, it was a horrible first experience at bar 244 and hated the hour we spent there. They were still letting people in as we left. Extremely unsafe environment and do not recommend women to go here, especially for NYE.

It used to be $3 all night, every night for bar rail, which is reasonable (cause honestly, bar rail is bottom of the barrel). Went tonight and Bud Light was $9.25, like.. are you serious? lol. Also, the downstairs club (one of the best parts) doesn't even open anymore??? The best club to go to years ago, and now they've sold out for expensive drinks, and shoving people in the top, and small, space. Lame. Won't go back.  Edit: I will say, 244 used to be my regular place, I loved it. Sure, no cover but if you made a guestlist and showed up before 11pm, you wouldn't have to pay cover anyway. I would have happily paid ten bucks for things to be at least a little similar to how it used to be, what made the place so great. Bartenders told us ALL beer was the same price, which contradicts what is said below.

drinks not even that cheap. worst dj ever - playing constant jamaican songs. overselling tickets and creating a dangerous environment. one loud muffled speaker upstairs and thats it.. really need to renovate the place.
This is a local watering hole with a dance club downstairs. Upstairs there is no cover with music. Good service at the bar.

Nice place -opens after 9 and crowd comes in after 11 -experienced both the non crowded and crowded moments -fun all through! No food -just a bar and dance joint though most nights the underground part is closed ..great bar tenders-parth served us well and the ladies were all smiles too all night despite the crowd

editorial_summary.overview: Nightspot with 2 levels: a main floor bar with casual food & a lower-level club where DJs spin.

231.name: Buddies in Bad Times Theatre
231.formatted_address: 12 Alexander St, Toronto, ON M4Y 1B4, Canada
reviews: After the Club Q shootings in The USA, I appreciate our safe Queer spaces in Canada. Buddies gives us quality theatre, performance art & entertainment for diverse Queer audiences and I appreciate it more than ever after 4 decades. It is such an important community hub.
Lovely folks had such a great time also felt safe there going to the bathroom since it was a super nice all genders restroom which rarely get at venues  super stoked to go to an event there again!!!!

New management is terrible. Incompetent, difficult to deal with, certainly not customer-service oriented. Not an exaggeration to characterize them as borderline hostile to rental clients. Something needs to change

So disappointed! First, the place looks old. Besides of that, music was not good, very few people there, but the worst thing was the drinks. They gave me a beer with a lemon and a long hair inside the lemon 🤢🤮 we stayed there for one hour or so.

I normally go to Buddies once a month for the Throb Party. Last Saturday (June 11) I waited in line for a drink for almost 50 minutes. Missing 1/3 of my time there trying to have fun in line while other people just cut the line and get served first. Just two bartenders working on their own time. My suggestion is or hiring more staff or sell drink tickets at the entrance so the bartenders don’t have to waste time computing the sales. Don’t understand me wrong, I love going there but there’s no organization by the staff, I work as a bartender and waiting for that much for a drink at a party with less than 200 people is an absolute mess.

editorial_summary.overview: Venue for bold gay & lesbian theatrical expression that doubles as a vibrant bar & nightclub.

232.name: Cake Bar & Nightclub
232.formatted_address: 214 Adelaide St W, Toronto, ON M5H 1W7, Canada
reviews: Has Cake tried playing good music? There’s a reason there’s a total of 10 people in the building all sitting on the couches… Also, why are 2 drinks $40? Go elsewhere!!
Didn't let me in. Said I was too ugly. Jokes on them, I was just looking for the McDonald's. They also said I could use some work but at least I got my nuggets.

It is a cute club but the music selection could definitely be better. Definitely for more of a younger crowd. We were harassed by the bartender for not tipping even though we didn’t have cash on us nor was there an available ATM at the time? The club was packed Im sure we did not put a dent in his pockets. It was a dumbfounding experience after that I will admit.

One of our favourite clubs, my friends and I are here almost every weekend! The bouncers are always super nice, which makes for a great start to the night. Haven’t met friendlier bouncers anywhere else. The owner is also great, very involved and attentive. He’s always there and takes the time & effort to resolve any issues. Great price for drinks too, $3!!

Went here for my birthday and got a booth and bottle service. Had an absolutely amazing night! The staff is extremely friendly and the music was great! The bottles are also very fairly priced compared to other clubs in Toronto that charge way too much. 10/10 experience here!

editorial_summary.overview: DJs spin Top 40 music & party anthems in this unpretentious, 2-level club with private VIP booths.

233.name: Crews & Tangos
233.formatted_address: 508 Church St, Toronto, ON M4Y 2C8, Canada
reviews: The performers are really great and the staff were very nice to us. Going on a less busy night such as a Wednesday will give you the opportunity to see more and be up close without a big crowd. There was no line up outside so it's great because we got to just get in and enjoy the show right away! I did not take any photos of the performers even though they were great because I didn't know what the content policy was on photos. But definitely recommended especially on a less busy night! The entrance is stairs so it's definitely not an accessible space but for those who can, it's worth it. Halloween decor was on point!

We went here for my friend's birthday! We really enjoyed the performances and whole night. I do recommend it and probably will be back some years later. The show was entertaining.  Things to improve: cleanness and payment method which is cash-only. They have an ATM inside but I prefer using my credit card. The price seems reasonable. Our table was great but some seats are farther and have hard time to see the scene. Many columns block the stage.

Come for a drag show, don’t stay for the alcohol or dancing. The queens are always fun to watch (if you can find a spot that’s not behind a poll…) but drinks are really ridiculously overpriced and the sounds system for the dance floor is completely shot. The club is also super run down, like for price of cover and the alcohol they charge you’d think they could make the space a little…spacious…and a little more modern.

My first time at Crews and Tango. It is cash only, and sure, it looks a little rundown I side but that's the atmosphere. Drinks are on the expensive side. The performances are great, though.  What I will say is the staff is amazing. It's not often I feel uncomfortable but there was one guy who immediately gave me bad vibes and a few others commented on it. I asked the bartender to keep an eye on him and he was eventually escorted out by security. Made a few of us feel much safer.

Always love going to Crews, but the vibe has definitely changed in the last 2-3 years.. They should incorporate different drag queens and more of a diverse set list. Some nights the shows get repetitive so I don’t frequent as often as I used to. Still got Love for Crews though but mix it up a bit.

editorial_summary.overview: Gay & lesbian drag bar with 2 dance floors featuring DJs spinning, live performances & karaoke.

234.name: Parlour
234.formatted_address: 270 Adelaide St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1P6, Canada
reviews: Nice atmosphere. Artists bring the crowd. However low A/C and ine bartender thought they were slick and didn't give me my change. Common ethics to always return that. This is the real reason why I made this review. Sorry lady, you shouldn't have thought I was intoxicated.
Great music nice outdoor patio even on a chilly night. Loved the intimate setting inside. Staff inside not friendly no smiles from anyone. Bouncers we’re nice outside. May try it again.

We came here for a party with friends and it was great! Music was awesome while the place wasn’t packed at all. Then we tried to book a table on our own and didn’t get a response for a week! Their Instagram says “dm to reserve a table”. I dm’ed and got a quick response that someone will reach out via email. Nothing. I followed up and got the same response. Still nothing. Then I sent an email to them instead of waiting for them to reach out to me. A few days later, the night before the party (!), I finally receive a templated email which I had to wait for a week?!! At that point, we already had other plans. It was a very unprofessional treatment from the Booking Manager. If the business says “dt to book a table” then be respectful to actually timely book your customers and not make them wait for a week. As much as I liked my first visit and wanted to introduce more friends to Parlour270, this unprofessional experience just ruined it all.

I visited this business with my wife for a drink for our anniversary.  I accidentally hit with my shoulder another guest while dancing and apologized for it. As a surprise he brought the bouncer and asked him to kick me out. The guest started grabbing me  from my hands basically wanted to fight  with me  while the bouncer being present and not doing anything I was forced  to leave so I didn't make a scene in front of my wife.  I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE AT ALL

I went to this place only once. The interior design is very good and stunning. They have two big hall and patio as well. Their music is not the best and it wasn’t my taste and I was wondering with playing good songs this place can be amazing for Friday/Saturday night. We got bottle service and it was pretty pricy. I think this place is good for having parties and they do that too, because when we were there it was a group of people getting ready for birthday party.

editorial_summary.overview: Speakeasy set in the basement of a 1895 rowhouse, with exposed-brick walls and red velvet curtains.

235.name: The Comrade
235.formatted_address: 758 Queen St E, Toronto, ON M4M 1H4, Canada
reviews: Great for cocktails but the food is also amazing! The server gave me recommendations and I loved what he picked. You definitely have to try the burger, it’s seriously so good.

A dark, moody and loud cocktail bar in Riverdale that also looks like a hunting lodge with all of the taxidermy. Super neat spot but a little hard to have a conversation, but that’s Friday night at a bar in Toronto for you. The cocktail I had was great and the service was prompt and friendly.

Cocktails were reasonably priced and tasted great. The service was efficient and friendly- though I did see some taking shots, it only slowed down service a tad. The bar itself is unique and it’s decor is really cool. Would definitely return. Can’t speak to the food though as we only had cocktails.
Always a great atmosphere here. If your looking for a bar that isn't stuffy and makes good drinks you've come to the right place!

It's dark. Even the bathroom is dark. Small menu. Ordered the prime rib burgers and I truly haven't had a burger that good since Mike's Fish and Chips on Eg West shut down like 50 years ago.  My son had a smoke and mirrors cocktail and really enjoyed it.  He also had a ginger beer, which I tried and it was really refreshing.  Back to the burgers, very simply dressed, bun had a crispy edge. Can't wait to go back for another. Service was friendly and efficient.  Go early if you want a table.

editorial_summary.overview: Propaganda posters & Chinese lanterns decorate this laid-back, exposed-brick hangout.

236.name: On the Rocks
236.formatted_address: 169 Front St E, Toronto, ON M5A 3Z4, Canada
reviews: What an experience!!!  My girlfriend and I were walking back to downtown from the distillery district and stumbled upon On The Rocks. We were only planning to grab one drink before seeing a show at Meridian Hall, but we enjoyed our time here so much that we came back after the show. Jay at OTR went out of his way to make our experience memorable - thank you Jay! If we lived here, this would be our regular - lots of food options, ice cold beer on tap, and a hidden gem. It looked like there was a dope patio out back too- noted for warmer summer nights. There is karaoke on Saturday nights (maybe others too) and it was a fun crowd of all ages that came out. A great time!
The Cantonese Style noodles tasted good but when I was 3/4 finished it…I noticed it was swimming in liquid

I've come here twice so far with my dance class, mainly for the karaoke. They've been very accommodating for our groups, and the deposit I put all goes towards food, and I get a bunch of apps for the tables- I like their fries, the sweet chilli shrimp, and the crispy calamari. We have a great time every time, and we'll definitely be back!

Food was great we had YPT soup (a meal in itself), wings which were perfectly cooked with great fries. The service was excellent, thanks J. Not a fan of karaoke so he opened the patio for us. We'd go back for sure.
The food here is amazing!! Came with some friends for the first time. We will def be back! Great vibes, karaoke it was dope. This will be our spot when we are back in town. Thanks!!

editorial_summary.overview: Traditional Chinese fare in a sports bar-like atmosphere, with drink specials & late-night karaoke.

237.name: Star Productions Inc.
237.formatted_address: 100 Front St W, Toronto, ON M5J 1E3, Canada

238.name: Centre Place
238.formatted_address: 101-320 Richmond St E, Toronto, ON M5A 1P9, Canada
reviews: Well I'm an atheist but I find the quality of their online lectures on history and theology to be quite exceptional. Packed with interesting material and well researched and delivered. I've learned a lot without being preached at at all - I'd highly recommend to anyone. They're very inclusive too.

This is THE place to go if you are looking to 'center' yourself, &/or learn more on a variety of aspects of history as it pertains to theology. To say that Center Place is run by good people is a genuine understatement! Of the dozens of meditation 'leads' I have ever experienced, Leandros consistently comes out in the top 3 of all time❣️

A welcoming and inclusive space for connecting in community with others through authentic conversation, meaningful activities and holistic wellness practices. A sleek, modern and stylish place for gatherings workshops, presentations, meditation and more, including a kitchen to service socializing with coffee, tea, snacks and meals, all with warm and friendly hosts.
Like their youtube lectures.
I listened to a couple of their presentations and found them to be thoughtful and accurate. Looking forward to watching more in the near future.

239.name: CC Lounge and Whisky Bar
239.formatted_address: 45 Front St E, Toronto, ON M5E 1B3, Canada
reviews: I visited tonight for the first time The bouncer guy at entrance door was nice helpful The atmosphere and music is nice ..mostly hits from late 80s and 90s too Plus most recent hits ..the ones guests usually come for to enjoy. Food and drinks were tasty.. but no variety for non alcoholic guests! Dry cocktails are so limited Food is nice tasty but took too long to arrive i had to remind the waiter twice actually. I didnt like the bartender with the braids though..not very friendly...focusing on one side rather than all guests sitting at the bar Food arrived very late we asked for burgers without bacon on top. It came one hour late and with bacon! They had to send it back to the kitchen  & replace it... I would visit again..i liked the atmosphere though..price is okay.

I recently came back to CC lounge and whiskey bar after quite some time and I’m glad I did! This place is sort of a hidden gem in Toronto but worth a visit!  They have a great lineup of cocktails and beverages including the classics and unique twists. The staff here are very accommodating and knowledgable as well. They have a great lineup of weekend and late night events and it’s a great vibe!

Everything here was really good. From the food, cleanness, staff, drinks, ambiance! We had the the Jack Daniel’s and Kiss me I’m Irish whisky flights and I was very pleased to know that the servings sizes were very generous! I’ll recommend for both big and intimate events, birthdays etc

Celebrated my birthday here last week.  My group of 12 people were very well taken care of. Beautiful ambience, excellent food and super classy cocktails. To top all that , everyone who worked there was very friendly and welcoming. The tunnel tour was very informative. There is a whiskey for everyone from all around the world!! All in all, you get what you pay for... and thats a damn good time !!

Hands down one of the best lounges in Downtown Toronto for the service, ambiance, and price point! The lounge is 25+ and dress code is dressy.  CC lounge is a great place to go clubbing at if you’re looking for a club with actual service and a more upscale experience. It has the perfect amount of crowd but is not packed like sardines, which I really appreciate, unlike some clubs where you’re constantly being shoved around a sea of sweaty people.  I booked bottle service here 3 times this year and every time has been a great experience. The price point was a lot cheaper than other hyped clubs in Downtown Toronto, the service was superior, and you actually get treated like VIP (unlike many other Toronto clubs where you throw down a few grand and still get treated like a peasant). If you book a booth they also give a bracelet for unlimited bar rail drinks to the person celebrating that night or whoever booked the booth. The bracelet is good for that night only and you can have as many drinks as you want through your server. A free food platter is also provided to the table around midnight, the food is actually really good and consist of sliders, grilled cheese, and fries.  CC lounge is definitely a hidden gem! If you’re looking for fairly priced bottle service, and a great clubbing experience with actual service then this is the place! It’s also located near union station for those who are commuting into Toronto to party.

editorial_summary.overview: This swanky nightspot boasts 100+ whiskies, cocktails & comfort food amid disco-ball chandeliers.

240.name: Stages Restaurant & Lounge
240.formatted_address: 200 Victoria St, Toronto, ON M5B 1T8, Canada
reviews: I chose the pasta dish named Canadian Ribs. It didn't taste very good.  But, the pineapple French Martini was positively surprising and the rum and cook was good.  The restaurant is not very open so it is not convenient for residents.

Summerlicious menu was decent, but service was not. Painfully slow and inattentive, food arrived before drinks (and only two other tables occupied!). Although I commend the all-gender restrooms, can't say I enjoy wading through urine. Wish the experience was better.

We came here for winterlicious, which was somewhat overpriced. The service here is terrible. We were not offered water when we sat and had to ask for it. The server told us several items which we were looking forward to, were unavailable, but tables after us were able to order those "unavailable" items. The water was refilled very few times, and we had to wait a long while in order for the table to be cleared and for each dish to come. It was also difficult getting the bill, we were done for almost half an hour before the bill came.  The food itself was not bad, the presentation was good for the butternut squash puree, beef papardelle, and desserts, but it was nothing special. A horrible experience for the price, especially given the non-existent service.

Booked Stages 2 hours prior to a show at Massey Hall - it's a very small place inside the Pantages Hotel and there were still a few open tables.  Unfortunately Management seems to think that having ONE disinterested employee to work the bar, wait the tables, bus the tables and attend to all the guests' needs is sufficient.  It's not.  At all. but this evening was so ridiculous it was comical  15 mins after being seated we still didn't even have water or menus 20 mins in we get menus and order drinks 30 mins we order our options from the small set menu 50 mins in the wrong appetizers arrived (we ordered soup he brought hummus) 55 mins - he brings one soup and one hummus (again!) (BOTH were supposed to be soup hence why we sent the hummus back...we repeat the full order.  Again.) 65 mins - the other soup arrives.  We specifically repeat our mains option and the dessert option and tell him to bring everything together 85 mins - he brings 2 pasta entrees...one was correct the other was supposed to be salmon (even though we JUST repeated the order AGAIN 20 mins prior) he said he'll be right back with the salmon 95 mins - he comes with dessert and the bill...NO ENTREE WITH HIM!! He says he "FORGOT" 100 mins - comes back and says the kitchen can't make the salmon in time, he also says he cannot get us hot water, or coffee to go with this dessert (which is about to be my Mother's main meal)  Over a span of 1 hour and 50 minutes they were not able to provide a very simple set menu to a table of 2 people.  When we left there was no one else there.  HOW DOES ONE SCREW UP SO BADLY OVER 2 HOURS?? Now the server himself was also obviously not that concerned with getting things right after the first mess up as he didn't even write anything down. By far the WORST and MOST RIDICULOUS experience I've ever had, anywhere. Just Shameful.
The bartender is very nice , I enjoyed his hospitality and the food was great

editorial_summary.overview: Pre- & post-theatre option at the Pantages Hotel offering contemporary Canadian plates & cocktails.

241.name: Jazz Bistro
241.formatted_address: 251 Victoria St, Toronto, ON M5B 1T8, Canada
reviews: It was our first time visiting the Jazz Bistro, and we had a really great experience! Loved the cozy atmosphere and the food was delicious too. The roasted chicken with gnocchi was so tasty and my husband loved his burger. I requested a cocktail menu and was informed they were in the process of updating it. Quality cocktails would definitely add to the amazing vibe of this place. Rémi Bolduc and the band were fantastic and the sound was perfect! I appreciated that they requested no talking during the performances but unfortunately the two young women sitting beside us talked the entire time. They obviously weren't there for the Jazz, but we did not let that take away from the enjoyment of our evening. After 2 years, it was gift to have an evening of live music at The Jazz Bistro!🎶

Saw Wild Blue Herons live here, they were incredible! Beautiful venue, great food and service. About $30-40 for main course, wine starting at about $50 a bottle. Menu is small but we'll executed. Acoustics are great, seating done well so everyone can see and hear properly (not a given in a music club, sadly). Staff are very lovely.

Was an amazing time! Went on a first date here, the atmosphere was really relaxing, great jazz trio playing while having a nice tasty dinner. Had the rigatoni and it was well done. It was hard to find parking nearby so anyone who needs to park I recommend coming a bit early to find parking. I was also able to use Open Table to book our reservation.  Will definitely come back again one night soon

The Jazz bistro is a fantastic place for jazz lovers and a hidden gem in Toronto's busy entertainment vibe. They perform both on main level and 3rd floor and have a nice semi open patio upstairs. Going back there after 4 years, the quality of service and food is still outstanding. The performance of the band (Club 350), jamming was astonishing.

Sooo we went to the Jazz Bistro to celebrate my mothers birthday. The service was impeccable our host for the evening Veronica was amazing and helpful made everything super easy. I just have a couple little issues, the food was good but for the amount you pay not worth it. $20 for 2 pieces of braised beef, 41.99 for rack of lamb that came with 3 pieces not 4 also should have came with somthing like wild rice or something I get the dishes were to be upscale but they should also be filling. We had to pay for bread which is normally free everywhere else. We also paid the entertainment fee which was well worth it, however we we decided to move upstairs for the late night session we were going to be charged again for an entertainment fee. I feel as if we paid once we should have to pay again especially if we will be buying drinks etc... However all in all we enjoyed ourselves the taste of the food was great and again service was amazing.

editorial_summary.overview: Atmospheric haunt featuring a schedule of live jazz performances & Canadian bistro-style fare.

242.name: Teller's Bistro & Bar
242.formatted_address: 1 King St W #1A, Toronto, ON M5H 1A1, Canada
reviews: Amazing staff, drinks and food. First ever place that made drinks with good amount of alcohol for the money they charge. Food was very tasty and the staff were very friendly. We visited the vault downstairs and its a must see. It’s so nice to see age old vault still intact.

Amazing experience! I sat at the bar on a weekend evening and the bartender Brooke provided excellence service. She always ensured I had a drink, and a water. Brooke made fantastic cocktails, both from the menu and free- hand when I requested she made me a surprise drink. Will definitely return- thanks Brooke!
One King West is the story of a teller and a vault.  Historic location. Don't forget the elephants.  Good Burger too

This bar is situated in the corner with tables sprawled around the lobby. The food is your usual bar food on pretty plates. Over cheesed pizza, wings and sweet potatoe fries are of your average bar variety. Brownie feels like it's a microwaved one topped with ice cream. Does the job if you're in a pinch.  Drinks: Around 6 beers on tap with a good variety of cocktails. Salted caramel apple and the pineapple melon splash are both excellent choices.  Service: great service given the number of tables to server ratio.  Long story short, I would stop here again for drinks but the food is nothing to write home about.

Entrance is provided in the second picture! They don’t say or mention but you must go and seat yourself And you will be met with a waiter or waitress shortly which are very friendly and attentive! -I order the Korean bbq ribs and they were honestly 10/10 a must recommend, dont shy away from the price since you do get 6pieces with a small amount of vegetables and rice and I’m a big eater and it filled me up nicely! -Menu is QR scanned or you have to ask for the Physical menu. -If you can’t find a drink on the menu, you can kinda ask and they will make almost anything you ask at the bar. -Recommend this resto 100% PS: if you need something you have to ask or else it won’t be provided ! Which is good or bad depending on how you perceive it!

editorial_summary.overview: Bank-turned-bar at One King West Hotel for upmarket tavern fare & drinks in a sophisticated setting.

243.name: King & Bay Custom Clothing Inc.
243.formatted_address: 161 Bay Street #2515, 25th Floor, Toronto, ON M5J 2S1, Canada
reviews: I purchased my wedding suit from King & Bay with help from Michael. It was easily the best experience I've ever had purchasing a piece of clothing. I think even my Bride was jealous of the overall experience! The care that Michael took to make sure my garment was perfect for me, suited all my needs and fit absolutely perfectly was amazing. He took everything into consideration from the themes and colours of our wedding, to the venue and our bridal party. Anything I needed help or opinions on Michael was right there to help in any way he could. I would recommend King & Bay to anyone who is looking for custom clothing. 10/10.

Michael was absolutely wonderful to work with. This was our first time doing custom suits and they are worth every penny. This was for our wedding and we weren't sure what direction we wanted to go and Michael guided us through the process. He was meticulous, kind, and very accommodating. Thank you to Michael and the King & Bay team!

As someone who has been buying suits off the rack, and has used custom suit companies such as "Suitsupply" in the past, King & Bay is a whole other level of the suit buying experience.  I had the opportunity to work with Michael on the creation of my suit. He was extremely professional and took the time to understand my needs and tastes as I was tired of looking "boxy" in every suit I wear. The entire process was an enjoyable experience! I was able to pick out patterns/materials/fabrics that I liked and with Michael's high attention to detail and recommendations I was able to create a suit that not only looks great but fits me perfectly. I will definitely be returning to King & Bay for my next suit purchase! 10/10!

Michael at King & Bay set me up with my suit for the wedding day. By far the best and most personalized suit buying experience of my life! Within 2 consultations, Michael was able to put together the perfect garment for me - hopsack material (light and breathable weavable material perfect for a summer wedding) and guided me into choosing taupe because of how it would pop at the winery I was married at.  The suit was created and tailored by the date that Michael promised and it needed no alterations or additional changes - the first fitting of the suit was the final fitting!  My bride came with me to the 2nd consultation and was very jealous of the experience I had and how intimate & personalized it was. Thank you for making the perfect garment for my wedding Michael. Cannot wait to get my next blazer from King & Bay!

King & Bay will provide you with the ultimate, lavish suit-shopping experience unlike any other. Michael, who is extremely well-versed in men’s fashion, meticulously curated my morning and evening looks for my wedding that perfectly matched my style and personality. After a couple of consultations with Michael, he got to know the kind of person that I am and he recommended the right fabrics, the right colours, and the right patterns. Ultimately the finished product was flawlessly tailored to my exact proportions while still being comfortable. I have never owned suits of this calibre before. But aside from the high quality of the product itself, Michael was a consummate professional and the experience that he created at King & Bay is one that I wish to recommend to any and all men seeking the best suit to compliment their fiancées elegance. You will not be disappointed.

244.name: Earls Kitchen + Bar
244.formatted_address: 150 King St W #100, Toronto, ON M5H 1J9, Canada
reviews: Delicious food,  great beer, not super loud with music. The crowd is a bit older than I expected like 40s or 50s. Our service was great!  Parked in the TD center building for $10 so not bad.  There were also a few daily specials so you don't have to break the bank to go there.  Enjoyed it thoroughly- will be going again.

Saw all the reviews and decided to visit this place during my stay in Toronto . We were 4 of us and there was a 45 minutes of wait . We got the table eventually and ordered our drinks and food . One of the drink had an insect in it so we had to return it . Then later when the food arrived and one of the meal was not what we ordered so I waited for my food while everyone else ate . Now for an establishment like this one I would have expected some sort of service recovery but literally nothing was done from their end.  Not a single server checked on us during this time to see if the drinks and food was okay specially when they messed up twice . I’m still giving them a good rating because the food and drinks were decent and the restaurant itself has a good ambiance. But service could have been better .

great place! we went on a Sunday during happy hour and despite the crowded place, the service was excellent! Our server (John Henry) was very vigilent and quick. They were amazing. The food was delicious too. We ordered the burger and street chicken tacos. I highly recommend! 😍😍

Came here for a work lunch and enjoyed a good meal and fast service. I enjoyed the poké bowl as it was balanced, fresh and filling. Vibrant location, good ambience and efficient service to get in and out during the lunch hour, without feeling rushed. Quite pricey for what you get but that is to be expected in the financial district, catering to the office crowd. On separate occasions I've enjoyed happy hour, after work drinks. Overall a reliable option for a work lunch and drinks.

Service needs improvement. We booked for table of 5 and confirmed many times yet our table was registered for 4 for some reason. Had to keep asking the server to add one more place. Guests came at different times and server wanted to wait until everyone came before we ordered our drinks. I wanted my drink immediately but had to wait.. same with my friend who repeatedly asked for more drinks throughout the night and server kept forgetting so that was very disappointing. The food took forever to come. The manager finally came to our table to explain that they overcooked the steak so they’re redoing it and we had to wait longer before they could serve the entire table. Everyone was very hangry at that point after waiting over an hour for food. They could’ve offered us a snack while they asked us to wait even longer but they didn’t. Server rarely checked up on us too. We ended up paying through the app ourselves and we left. The server caught us looking for the washroom and finally asked if we paid.
