The garden is a good place for family. Can see Toronto Harbour front. A short walk with family or friends to enjoy the flowers and tress. You may see guitarist singing songs so you can relax to enjoy the performance. Flowers blooming hence can take nice photos

Picturesque gardens by the waterfront create a gorgeous backdrop for this casual amphitheatre that both music and nature lovers alike can fully appreciate. Kid- and pet- friendly. Take a blanket to stretch out on the sun-soaked lawns or under the tree canopy of your choosing. Times are listed for performances but check in advance so you don't miss great local talent. (Visited during Summer, August).

I spend my summers down here. Sitting by the docks bring me a sense of calm. When I listen to concerts in the park, presented by Harborfront, in truly is my happy place. I am so glad summer concerts are back! These truly save my sanity!
A small and lush green park to spend time on a sunny day. There was some ceremony going on as well as the top of amphitheatre. Maybe you can reserve/book the spot.

editorial_summary.overview: Yo Yo Ma contributed to the design of this scenic garden with summer concerts & seasonal tours.

331.name: Clarence Square
331.formatted_address: 25 Clarence Square, Toronto, ON M5V 1H1, Canada
reviews: The park itself is nice. But unfortunately it’s full of tents now. Lots of litter, and people screaming and fighting eachother. Best to avoid after sunset.
It’s a tented homeless encampment where there are a lot of people with serious mental health issues .
So sad to see this park not being maintained properly and now become a place to not to be at. Had fond memories with my kid playing all around which is all now been taken over by tents such a shame.

Nice little park in downtown Toronto. 30% of the park is an enclosed dog park. Very popular with dogs. On a warm sunny afternoon, its great to sit on the bench near the central water fountain and people watch. Many people grab a beer or two from the next door LCBO and chat with friends after work. The grass is not well kept, but is acceptable. There are often sketchy homeless people drinking in this park, but they are pretty harmless.
My dog hates it here. It’s probably the ice cold people and poorly socialised dogs. But hey, it’s a leash free dog park, so that’s something.

editorial_summary.overview: Small tree-shaded urban park with a central cherub-topped fountain, an off-leash dog area & benches.

332.name: Margaret Fairley Park
332.formatted_address: 100 Brunswick Ave, Toronto, ON M5S 2L7, Canada
reviews: This is a very unusual wooded park, tucked in a quiet residential area. Though it is a small park, it has many interesting features. A fountain with a large play area, a chess board table, many benches and an interesting sculpture dedicated to a local community member who had helped the people in the area in many ways. The park is named after her.
The kids really enjoyed the splash pad and sandbox with water spout. The very clean porta potty was extremely helpful. Nice to have trees providing shade from the sunshine.
Pretty good... But small...  Handy for those that live nearby...  Gets a lot of wear and tear.... Has fun water tap and sand pit .. tiny splash pad and sprinklers often broken...  Overall nice park
Nice park, great for kids and very pretty design. I especially like the wooden log seats. It's way too small for walking though.
Nice place for kids to play in the neighbourhood! Low speed limits, one way streets! Really safe  Thanks Margaret for this gift.

333.name: Alexandra Park
333.formatted_address: 275 Bathurst St, Toronto, ON M5T 2S4, Canada
reviews: Small but very beautiful park. Get a book or sip on your favourite drink out here. Perfect spot/weather to enjoy with friends & family or to just cut off & have that alone time.
There are two different cherry trees between the pool and library. A great spot for a picnic

Nice park with a splash pad, playground and pool. However, when we visited it didn’t feel family friendly. Albeit, the tents were gone, there were homeless people, hazardous garbage etc.  Also bigger part of the park is closed for the renovation. Hopefully, it will be back to normal soon.

This park has a fairly large area with grass which is perfect for dogs. They have public restrooms and both a play structure in the sand and a water play area this park is perfect for smaller children.
Great place to explore something.... Skate groud is awsome

editorial_summary.overview: A 6.7-acre park with a playground, baseball diamond, volleyball court, skate area & wading pool.

334.name: Ontario Place
334.formatted_address: 955 Lake Shore Blvd W, Toronto, ON M6K 3B9, Canada
reviews: It's an escape from the city. You still hear the planes take off from Billy Bishop, but still much quieter compared to being next to Lake Shore. There is a long trail for walking and cycling to travel around the island. There are parks and little areas to rest and picnic. There is even a shoreline to access the lake to swim (too many rocks to be considered a beach). Overall, this is a good outdoor space.

I have been going to Ontario Place since I was a kid. Now almost 60! Still a great place to hang out! Sad that some of the exhibits have gone, but new ones still keep cropping up! Centre piece is the Budweiser Stage! Good venue! But being the old buy, I miss the old rotating stage. But that is me! Good place to visit and take the kids ( or not )

This is a beautiful place.  I have had great memories coming to this place as a young adult...great fireworks, live bands, drinks...  Well , it's a bit sad to see white paint is covered with rust spots...and pavilions are left in poor conditions.  The architecture is still a sight to behold after all these years.
Couldn’t get enough of sunset views! This will take a whole day to enjoy the whole both islands which Ontario Place is located on. Variety of fun activities for everyone!

The place was awesome, great views and serene ambiance. The only problem when I went to watch a show (Cirque du Soleil), was that we had to walk ~30 mins to reach the venue. There were no buses allowed in the area, I think

editorial_summary.overview: IMAX theatre inside a geodesic structure showing educational films & hits on an 80 ft. screen.

335.name: Victoria Memorial Square
335.formatted_address: 10 Niagara St, Toronto, ON M5V 1C2, Canada
reviews: The square has a nice toddler park which is why we go there.  Totally enclosed with padded surface and lots of equipment.  People have left their old toys there so lots of things for kiddos to play with.  The rest of the park is nice and chill but it definitely needs an enclosed dog park as lots of people let their dogs of leash.   The grass alsol needs a reseeding  in spots.

A lovely park with historic significance. This site was the location of a former burial ground for military personnel. Some old gravestones at the east end of the park serve as a remembrance. A monument in the middle of the park pays homage to the war of 1812.

Great spot in downtown away from the bustle of King West.  Lots of benches to sit and a good mix of shady and sunny spots throughout the day.  Playground looks top-tier for younger kids.  As with most TO parks, could use a drinking fountain.
Really cool lil hook in heart or downtown. There's performances, great place to sit and enjoy the views of the harbour and CN tower.  Recommended for a date or just hang out with friends
On a warm sunny early autumn afternoon, a book n some coffee, made for great spot, especially with the awesome Muskoka chairs to kick back in

editorial_summary.overview: Grassy area popular for dog-walking, with a playground, plus skyscraper & harbor views.

336.name: Canoe Landing Park
336.formatted_address: 45 Fort York Blvd, Toronto, ON M5V 3Y2, Canada
reviews: This is a fairly big park. There is a dog run for dogs and a playground for kids. My daughter likes the playground. However, there aren't many things to do here so it gets boring for her after 5 minutes. There are better playgrounds in downtown Toronto so I don't know why this playground got short changed. There is also a field with artificial turf here. It's for the school mainly. However, when school isn't in session it is free to use. Unfortunately, that doesn't extend to dogs. Some dog owners don't care and will unleash their dogs here. Very dangerous.

One of the best revitalization projects in the city. This park really has it all. Fantastically well-maintained and situated. Contains a rare public turf soccer field, basketball courts adjacent to the community centre and a dog park. A variety of terrains and world-class Toronto views give energy to any visitors. Also, one of the few water fountains remaining in the area.
Great park. Lots to do in and around the park. Plus free soccer game...😊
Great place to play soccer. Nice view of the city. Refreshing place

My young children loved it. There is a water park, an enclosed climbing playground with bouncy floor for younger children, another one with wooden structures for older children. Also lots of grass and art interactive features.

editorial_summary.overview: Open space featuring 2 multi-purpose sports fields, various contemporary art pieces & walking paths.

337.name: Stanley Park
337.formatted_address: 890 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1P2, Canada
reviews: Out of all parks I’ve visited in Toronto I can’t say this is the best one. No water fountains, very few benches, and the baseball diamond is out of shape and without a single shade.  Location is a big plus though!

The park is big and beautiful. We visited the dog park which is gated. Based on the three times I’ve been there, it’s more common for smaller dogs to play in the field outside of the gated zone; as larger dogs tend to spend more time there. The pool was also nice in the summertime.

Well maintained off-leash dog park. It doesn’t have a separate section for smaller dogs but it is large enough that dogs can play separately if they want to. Lots of seating space is available too. My dogs love going there :)

Its a good park with all the basic stuff (basketball court, picnic tables, kids playground, public washrooms) and it is in a very central easy to access location. The playground is old and has sand that can be annoying on the feet depending of the footware. The north side has more shadow than the south part.
Good park for young kids lots. A nice big public pool in the summer and a nice bowl for skate borders. There are also baseball diamonds.

editorial_summary.overview: This public park offers a playground & splash pad, plus a basketball court & field for sports.

338.name: McCormick Park
338.formatted_address: 66 Sheridan Ave, Toronto, ON M6K 2G9, Canada
reviews: The park is located in a cozy, tight and rustic neighborhood in downtown Toronto. Home to a lot of squirrels, it's a great place to bring your kids and to walk around. The old neighborhood houses really display their serene timeless atmosphere. I come here for ice hockey at the local rink. Great place to visit.
Always fun to see how people decorate for the holidays. Nice quiet street
Nice big park at main Brock Ave at few blocks north of Queen St. W. Specially the children play area is very attractive.
Nice park with a plaground, baseball diamond, and basketball courts
Great park, don't miss out on the delicious sandwiches out of a shipping containers!

339.name: Stanley Off Leash Dog Park
339.formatted_address: 700 Wellington St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1G7, Canada
reviews: Group of Karens spotted at the dog park. Their dog would not stop mounting ours and these people did nothing to stop it, until we asked them to.  When we asked them to watch their dog, their response was “this is a dog park, if you don’t want your dog to be mounted then hold on to your dog” followed by a bunch of expletives. It’s unbelievable how people who have zero dog park etiquette bring their dogs who show aggressive behaviours that can easily escalate if not intervened, and they have the audacity to swear at you for trying to protect your dog. Apparently because “no mounting” is not a written rule, these people believe that it is accepted.
Perfect! Takes a few minutes to adjust the straps and get used to putting it on but when that is figured out it is an amazing harness, far better than my last one
Was here for an hour and saw 7 dog fights. Owners please stop bringing your aggressive dogs to the off leashed dog park and expose other dogs to danger.
A good size, friendly people, lots of dogs for mine to play with and in a great location.
It is a decent dog park

340.name: Trinity Flower Cannabis
340.formatted_address: 890 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M6J 1G3, Canada
reviews: Great vibe of the store, great customer service. Loved the variety of products available for customers! The associate Kevin went above and beyond to provide an excellent and exceptional experience. 👏

I absolutely love their delivery service. Fast response, and always on time whether it’s snowing or raining, never experienced any cancelled delivery orders! Thank you guys for being reliable! Hands down, you guys are my favourite dispensary ^_^~

First experience at Trinity Flower, I was beyond impressed with the level of personable service Cayman gave us. Definitely one of the best experiences I’ve had at a dispensary. Will be back for sure and recommend my friends to stop by!

I’ve been here on several occasions now. Every single time I’ve been here, the staff has always been helpful and knowledgeable. I find they have a lot of unique strains I can’t buy anywhere else; and I’ve enjoyed a lot of what I have tried.  Thank you!
staff is super nice, really helpful, AND they have a bunch of cool rolling trays and whatnot!! defs will come again!!

341.name: Massey Harris Park
341.formatted_address: 945 King St W, Toronto, ON M6K 3M2, Canada
reviews: The Splash Pad is open, and its a great little place to take the little ones to cool off.
Nice green space has a water fountain and some benches
Nice and quiet park

I was one of the original owners in the Massey Harris Building lofts. I no longer live in Canada, so can someone please tell me that old men still play bocci at the south end of the park? That was one of my favorite aspects of this little park, after the magic fountain.
I give it 3 stars for the dancing fountains splash pad, but beware of tonnes of dogs illegally off lease, leaving scads of poop their owners can't be bothered to pick up.

342.name: DSMS Plants
342.formatted_address: King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 2X6, Canada

343.name: High Park
343.formatted_address: 1873 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6R 2Z3, Canada
reviews: Very nice park! One of the best free park that I have ever seen. Especially during cherry blossom season! People is packed during weekends so better go during weekdays to appreciate the nature and peacefulness of the place. It does not feel that it was situated inside a city. Finding a place to park your car near the park is kinda difficult, we have to park near the lake and walk which is okay since the weather is good. We will definitely go back! You also have to walk to find restaurants

It may be the best park in Toronto! It's suitable for hiking or walking dogs in summer, and there are many facilities and trails to choose from. There are a zoo, nature trails, and a dog walks area, a swimming pool, a tennis court, playgrounds, and many trees! There are a lot of parking spaces here and many shared bicycles to rent. It is also convenient to have a subway station next to the park. We visited this park for the first time and had a great afternoon here.

High park is my favourite part of Toronto especially when you want surround yourself with nature without getting out Toronto. Fall is so stunning here. There are lots of small trains for a easy hike in the park. And btw, this park is huge, with a beautiful lake with swans and ducks. Must visit if you are a tourist, or looking to go for a trail run or just to spend some peaceful time in nature. Heads-up: weekend can be busy, especially in summers and everyone is here taking lots of pictures.

It’s beautiful. Very nice place to hangout with friends, family or alone if you like. You can see various types of bird, goose, swans. On top you will find parking, washroom, food place for convenience (not sure if they are open around the year). Rent a bicycle or walk around to see beautiful nature. Only issue I would say it’s busy sometime

It's a huge park, very beautiful and great for a lot of activities. Parking inside is closed during weekends, nearby street parking is usually full and finding a spot becomes bit of a hassle sometimes and has 3 hours limit. But once you get inside, it's great for spending time with family in a beautiful natrual serene environment. Great for a walk, cycling, picnic with friends and family, there's also a free zoo where kids enjoy watching and interacting with the animals. It's specially beautiful during the cherry blossom season and offers great spots for taking beautiful pictures. The play area is also great for kids of all ages. Overall it's one of the best parks in the city!

editorial_summary.overview: Sprawling park with hiking trails, a zoo, sports fields & a large children's playground.

344.name: Ritchie Avenue Parkette
344.formatted_address: 77 Ritchie Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 2K1, Canada
reviews: Small park but kids love it. Swings, a playground set, concrete ping pong table, and in winter a small ice skating surface.
People keep stealing the F---ing ping pong paddles. But overal a nice place to take your kids of you are in the area
Cute little parkette. A little out of the way but really popular with the locals. To be honest, I come here because of the Ingress portal.
Friendly Park. However really small. Has a ping pong table though 😁
Small, quiet with a ping pong table! A lovely parkette.

345.name: High Park Zoo
reviews: I like the fact that it is free to enter. There are donation bins set up if you choose to donate. Not all animals are out during thr fall and winter but there is definitely enough to have a good time and see some cool creatures. I also really liked the info graphics about each animal. You can learn some interesting facts. And I appreciate that dogs are allowed to enter.

Love coming here with my son. My parents used to take me when I was growing up. Loved just being close to the animals. A nice long walk through the trails. Sit down for lunch. Good place to have a day in nature.

High park Zoo has a good collection of animals. Since the weather was nice, a lot of the animals were outside their barns.  If you are visiting on a weekend, the parking within High park is closed and you have to park on the street outside and walk all the way in.

Really surprised that there's a free zoo in the middle of high park. We saw llamas, deer and mountain goat. For a second I thought the mountain goat was a statue until it moved its head. I was so pleasantly surprised and then realized that the mountain goat was true to it's name - it climbed the top of the little wooden shed. Wish they had more animals. A beautiful spot to visit in the fall!
An adorable little zoo tucked away in High Park! I will definitely be back to see the capybaras as they were not out the day I went. Lots of benches and picnic tables to relax and watch the animals!

editorial_summary.overview: Fenced-off grassy areas for animals like capybaras & bison, plus llamas & rabbits kids can pet.

346.name: High Park Children’s Garden & Teaching Kitchen
346.formatted_address: 1873 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6R 2Z3, Canada
reviews: Newly created area for children activity & learning . When we visited it was closed . Taken picture from outside. Nice place though. I would like to revisit with my child during spring time. Nice picnic area available near by. Parking available as well. It’s free of cost entry.
Very nice park in heart of GTA
Was here for a Kid's birthday. Great venue, crafts and gardening and learning for kids.
Beautiful park. Clean and well maintained, lovely trails and very popular for cherry blossom season. Excellent selfie location.
Nice huge park but could be better not that much thinks to do .Could be made more family places kids playgrounds parking space, huge lake with could be made some thing in .

347.name: Colborne Lodge
347.formatted_address: 11 Colborne Lodge Dr, Toronto, ON M6R, Canada
reviews: Free to visit during May, which is Museum Month. You must show your City of Toronto public library card.
This place was amazing you learn so much and the tour guide Megan seemed so knowledgeable about what she was saying!
Small tour, but worth it. Important fact: High Park is dry! Wow... who knew?

$30 for a family of 5. Guided tour of the Colbough Lodge which this home and owners owned this land. History of how High Park was  made. Apple cider and cookies provided to kids. Then had a long walk to park and the animals. Fresh air. Exercise . Great day

High park has every that most park don't,it has many natural paths in the woods tennis 🎾 swimming, a zoo and more. You won't be disappointed visiting the park, it runs as far from Bloor st to the south at the lake shore, take in the beautiful landscape, this is a 5 🌟!!!

editorial_summary.overview: An 1837 Regency-style cottage topped by a triple chimney, with period furniture & a picture gallery.

348.name: Hawk Hill
348.formatted_address: 285 Colborne Lodge Dr, Toronto, ON M6S 2T9, Canada
reviews: Best time of the year to visit is during April and May when cherry blossom blooms.

Hawk Hill lies inside High Park. It was easy to find the place using Google maps. Lots of people watch birds. There are several types of prey birds in this park. Ranging from Hawks to Bold Eagle. However, most of these birds, don’t land they just fly over the park. The best time to see these bird is noon (September to November). I came in late, but I was lucky to find a pair of Falcon hunting. These birds were on a tree waiting for prey.
The hill has a decent enough view but when I visited it (in late August) I didn't see any hawks.
A nice tourist attraction . Great fishing at Grenadier Pond . Snak bar and picnic area close by
Beautiful place to be in touch with nature

349.name: Sunnyside Park
reviews: It was a busy Saturday morning, the weather was good. Went from the Sunnyside Pavilion , cross the Humber Bay Arc Bridge, stopped at the Sheldon Lookout, to the Palace Pier and back. It was about 6km. The lake view was beautiful. The temperature was pleasant. Paid parking spaces were plentiful. There were public washrooms along the path.
Great place for a walk or a bike ride, can be nosy if there is traffic.
Beautiful park in particular summer time is amazing around here. The vibe, hanging out, plenty of activities and exercise. Youth and families having party and BBQ. A nice refresh from the lake draft.
Beautiful views calm place to hang around and get some nice tanning, just try not to go into the water.
Walk west of the park for quieter scenery, no life guards, enjoy the sailboats to bird watch PS perfect place to launch canoes 🛶 or kayaks

editorial_summary.overview: Lakefront park & picnic spot with a beach, playground, cycling trails & boardwalk.

350.name: West Lodge Park
350.formatted_address: 165 Lansdowne Ave, Toronto, ON M6K 2W1, Canada
reviews: Nice little park with a community garden and a small skate park.
Nice during the week to hang out play Frisbee and picnic on weekends nice for the children
Nice place to chill lookout for the junkies tho
It's OK small great for doing a few runs but could use a little ledges
Nice park. Just need lot of patience to ignore ill-mannered people who passes through park to other street. Seriously who smokes in kids play area

351.name: MacGregor Playground
351.formatted_address: 346 Lansdowne Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 3Y1, Canada
reviews: This is a great park for family's! Not so much for fur babies. This area is not dog friendly although I do break the rules lol

The red clay field is awesome to play on but the batter's box needs work; please note wood bats only at this location! Dog friendly place to socialize with nice grass to play, secluded shady areas available. Clean washrooms and the splashpad is so cool on a hot day. Love the train that pulls by every so often adding to ambience of Toronto. Quiet spot among the noise.
Field, track,  baseball diamond,  play structures, new splash pads, washrooms,  shade, Adirondack chairs, picnic bench, parking on street or behind school. Great place to spend hours
Great park for the kids to attend the splash pad!! My kid loved it. Ice cream truck goes by it frequently.

Such a great park! The splash pad is top. And there is a little park for the kids to play in after they’re done splashing around. There is usually free street side parking along the street. Must most importantly there are bathrooms which are relatively clean all things considered.

352.name: Sorauren Avenue Park
352.formatted_address: 289 Sorauren Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 2G4, Canada
reviews: Lovely little park. Lots of places to sit. I went for the farmer's market which was nice. It's a good neighborhood park for jogging, cycling also. It's good for taking your kids for a walk for just chilling with friends. Some corners are good for nature close-ups.

A beautiful Farmer's Market. It is open on MONDAYS ONLY, Rain OR Shine! We've gone during the Summer and colder months and there are always great options there! (I will add more photos the next time I go!)

What a beautiful park located in the agreable Roncesvalles neighborhood, every time I go to Toronto I go to this park. I just like to sit on a banch and watching people,childrens,dogs and all the activities, the residents of this neighborhood participate a lot of the life of this park by organizing family activities, in the summer there are films screening and once a week a public market and without forgetting you people who playing tennis, baseball, running.... For myself the pumpkin ball in October is the most grandiose. Love this park 💚💚

Sorauren is a gem of a park. Great place to have a picnic or play some games in the summer. There is a decent sized dog park that is accesible all year. In the spring/summer/fall there is a farmers market ever Monday night.  A new community centre that will be located at the southeast cornber of the park is currently  in the design phase. It will maintain most of the current amenities but add gym and pool spaces among others.

Has a great cafe right by the park, everyone seems to come for the soft serve, I enjoyed the chia pudding which was an option for people who don't consume sugar. I got to enjoy myself while my son was at a birthday party at the park, lots of room to run around. Very family oriented, although coming to the cafe is not the best place to study as it is a busy place, at least it was on a Sunday. Overall pleasant experience, thank you.

editorial_summary.overview: Simple neighborhood park offering outdoor tennis courts, sports fields & drinking fountains.

353.name: Rennie Park
353.formatted_address: 1 Rennie Terrace, Toronto, ON M6S 2X2, Canada
reviews: Good park. Lots of play space for the kids. Slides, swings and sand pit too.

nice park, well maintained, there is tennis court, soccor field, playground and surrounded hills ideal for toboggan in winter. A wild but short hiking path along the pond. There is a bridge which seems to be abandonded.Free parking.
This park has it all. Lots of big shady trees, perfect for a picnic. There's also a covered pavilion for larger groups. Skating rinks, tennis courts, and a nice little hiking trail.

I love this park. Public tennis courts, playground, skating rink in the winter and a large field for soccer and baseball. I always visit with my pets and so do many other people. If you have a dog, definitely check out Rennie park.
Great park and playground. Lots of space for everyone and all ages. Small splash pad for the little ones.

editorial_summary.overview: A 24-acre park with an ice rink, wading pool, tennis courts, playground, picnic shelter & ponds.

354.name: Howard Park Children's Centre
354.formatted_address: 30 Marmaduke St, Toronto, ON M6R 1T2, Canada
reviews: The staff are so attentive and welcoming.  The children are well taken care of.  I trust my child in their care during the day. 😊
Went here for 6 years of my life, great staff, and getting better every year.

355.name: Jamie Bell Adventure Playground
355.formatted_address: 185 Spring Rd, Toronto, ON M6R 2Y8, Canada
reviews: Absolutely awesome playground. Unfortunately the puddles gather at the bottom of the slides after a rain storm. Bring extra shoes and socks for the little ones. Very popular playground that gets pretty busy. Recommend bringing a small camp chair as the benches and picnic tables fill up fast. Public restrooms are close by.
Great play park. Huge wooden structure, lots of swings. Plenty of in shade seating for parents. Water fountain and bottle filling station too. Car park and toilets nearby.

The little ones really loved it. Its a giant wooden castle themed play ground. Some  parts are worn down but overall it's still standing fairly strong there are lots of platforms to walk and climb on. Swings,slides  a little "zipline" type thing . Its free and right near high park zoo which is also free and great for small kids
We call it the castle park, always fun for smaller kids mostly. Apparently it's open to vehicles during weekdays so you can park inside.
The playground itself was nice, many kids playing around, parents chatting, overall it was clean. Sadly food choices are extremely limited around the area...

356.name: High Park Greenhouse
356.formatted_address: High Park-Swansea, Toronto, ON M6R, Canada
reviews: The cherry blossoms are hidden here
Interesting.

357.name: High Park Allotment Garden
357.formatted_address: High Park-Swansea, Toronto, ON M6R, Canada
reviews: It was alright I went in fall/winter nothing really going on I went for a school assignment it's says restricted unless you have a plot but if you ask someone they most likely will let you in
It's nice but they put this ugly rusty red fence around it which ruins the perfectly good looking garden
Beautiful

358.name: High Park Dog Off Leash Area
358.formatted_address: 1873 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6R 2Z3, Canada
reviews: What's not to love? A huge open space with woods and trails fully open to off leash dogs.  This area makes up a small portion of High Park, which is Ontario's version of Central Park. No vehicles on weekends, which really opens it up.

I love this dog park and trail! I would recommend trying to avoid peak hours since it does get quite busy but most of the people and dogs I've met here are super friendly and the trails are wide and fenced-in. One of my favorite dog-friendly places in the city!

Great hiking, the biggest off leash area in Toronto, you can easily lost your dog among the tries there :)  There were many dogs on Monday, so I can imagine how many it is going to be on a weekend.  Take some water for our dog, because there is no such facility in the off leash park.  There are some places to seat add relaxso you can bring anything you would like, from a book to make a picnic.  There was a lot of squirrels, if your dog doesn't like them us mine, make sure to follow him along the way :)

Was smaller than I expected and a lot of the ground is sand; so my white dog needed a bath as soon as we got home. Other than that we had a great time there. I loved the forest area and so did the dogs. Water was on already so that was a bonus, as we have been bringing our own water to dog parks since it’s still only spring. Will definitely go again but only on bath days.
Great trail and wooded area with friendly dogs and owners! Moderately busy with lots of folks walking with and without pups.

359.name: High Park Labyrinth
reviews: A simple premise - walk along a defined path in a labyrinth to get to the center of the pattern; take in the tranquility and simplicity of the task. It’ll take you less than 10 mins. Appreciate the flutter of the leaves on the trees around you and the breeze as you do. Sit in the center for a moment once you get there.

A beautiful park to take a walk or ride a bike. May is usually time for the cherry blossoms and the park is packed with families from all walks of life enjoying the sheer beauty of these trees and the park in general. Bring good walking shoes as it takes a while to see the park in its entirety. Pack a lunch and some patience too while finding parking.
Cherry blossom May 7th 2022. Almost fully blossom 🌸.
Great spot for shoots, walk, run etc
Had a great time here. Sat in the middle for a while and contemplated life. Felt like I lost track of time on the way out, went into a bit of a trance-like state.

360.name: Hillside Gardens
360.formatted_address: High Park-Swansea, Toronto, ON M6R, Canada
reviews: Nice place. Specially in spring , summer , autumn 🍂 must visit . Lot of seats available to take rest . Good place for small picnic in garden. Kids like it very much. I love the lake it’s blue water is amazing 🤩. Lot of duck n duckling 🐥. There is no entry fee for visitors. This place is very near to high park metro station. Parking available for visitor in high park , but it’s mostly full during holidays . Paid parking available on the road. Best time to see this place during Sakura bloom.
A great location to take in the grand view of the garden and surrounding areas; there are benches to take a rest and just enjoy the scenery.

This is a great hill to toboggan on. It's steep enough to go fast and if you're not careful you will fly into the circle bush at the bottom but that's better than a fence! This is also a gorgeous view looking across the water.

Loved it. Very nice place for nature walk. A lake side garden with very beautiful scenery. There is fishing point near this garden. There are many benches placed in garden for sitting with lake view. A good place to bring kids. No public washrooms are available at site. The parking lot near this place is pay and park.
Gorgeous view, a bit of a hike.

361.name: Sir Casimir Gzowski Dog Park
361.formatted_address: 2001 Lake Shore Blvd W, Toronto, ON M6S 5B5, Canada
reviews: There is plenty of parking to start off. There is plenty of space at this dog park, enough shade for the hot days, and benches for owners. The park is comprised of mostly sand. There are plenty of pups to socialize with throughout the day, due to the fact that the majority of visitors are dog walkers. The one thing missing is a drinking fountain for dogs, do not forget your water bottle.
Lovely big dog park close to the city and right by the lake.

I love the Sir Casimir dog park. I'm there several times a week. It's fenced with two double gated entrances and there are plenty of garbage and recycling containers as well as several well-maintained benches. It's set away from the bike path so the surrounding area is quieter.  The fence is a bit low so if you have a dog that jumps fences, take care. There is also no water access for the dogs although there is a water fountain on the path between the bike path and the park that's handy for refilling water containers.  The ground is sand so you can avoid the mud that can become a problem in most dog parks and almost everyone is careful about cleaning up after the dogs. It is frequented by great dog walkers during the day.

Named after Sir Kazimierz Stanislaus Gzowski. An engineer best known for his work on Canadian railways, the Welland Canal and also serving as acting Lieutenant Governor of Ontario... and possible dog lover?  Oddly shaped off leash dog area with soft sand underfoot, so no winter mud in this one.  Few benches to chill on while your dog checks out the butts on offer.  Something to note and a possible problem for our nervous four legged friends. Dog walkers use this park a lot! Mostly during the week, you can have more than one with 4-5 dogs each.  Although always friendly but sometimes manic and in very large groups, if you dog is nervous, they can have a hard time here.

Fortunately it’s close to my house, unfortunately it’s also for commercial dog walkers that flood this place at all times of the day. I’m not a pretentious dog owner and i appreciate dogs will be dog but a lot of these walkers have no licenses and literally take any kind of dog. A lot with some attitude problems (dogs & walkers alike). Also the gravel and lack of shade make it one of the less favourable places to bring your dog to run.

362.name: Gzowski Monument
reviews: I found the Gzowski Monument today and was very interesting to see this for the first time. Very nice area and parking lot right there with walkway going up to the monument.
It’s a historic monument with tribute to Sir Gzowski’s contribution to railways and development of Canada 🇨🇦
Nice monument. Gzowski Monument.
Respect to the monument and those it represents.
Beautiful monument and lake side park.

363.name: Beaumont Park
363.formatted_address: 9 A Beaumont Rd, Toronto, ON M4W 1V4, Canada
reviews: Very good place, loved the fall colours and luxurious properties with private swimming pool
Excellent trail for a walk or bike. It would be even better if there were at least one porta potty in the middle of the trail. Not much to see as far as birds and nature, literally just a trail.

The place is close to nature and nice retreat for weekend, easily commutable via bike for ones who are living in downtown Toronto or around. However, certain necessary infrastructure is either missing or not maintained to an acceptable level.
This park is my winter summer favorite place to hang out. It has a nice river stream next to it which rarely freezes.
Awesome place to walk with your dog, lots of furry friends, great place to scape from the city stress even though you are still in the city

364.name: Wellesley Park
364.formatted_address: 500 Wellesley St E, Toronto, ON M4X 1H9, Canada
reviews: Greenery is soo good for summer. This place is quite and has a good treat to walk. They have benches here to chill around along with nice huge trees.  There is also a green space and stair case to trek down and above. It’s pretty quite and cool here.  There is a dustbin and and recycle bin for maintaining the cleanliness.  Make sure you don’t get here when it’s raining as it might get very mushy and sticky.  Good place for a small family picnic and enjoyment.
Good park for kids to play. It has  water splash and play area
Quiet cute little sand park with water park. Accessible swings and entrance

Beautiful small park anytime of the year. We take our evening walks though here every evening and love the fall views as the trees turn color each year. Always very quiet and relaxing anytime of the day or week.
Park has a badminton court but no net.. also has a children's play area as well as water fountain. Good place to laze around. Has multiple parks in the surrounding.

365.name: Evergreen Brick Works
365.formatted_address: 550 Bayview Ave, Toronto, ON M4W 3X8, Canada
reviews: A great place to enjoy nature as it is. The walking trail is natural with multiple humanmade wooden bridges over water bodies. You can walk up to the top to have a better view of the entire place. Great place to go alone, with friend or family. They don't have toilets everywhere so make sure to visit one at the building one before going in or after coming out. The bus stops right at the parking lot. They also have a cafe at the entrance building but they close up by 5 pm. The sound of the leaves when the wind goes through then is what I found most amazing about this place. The place is quiet even though there were a lot of people with kids and pets.

Lots of trails to enjoy a quick hike.. still so close to the city but feels like you're in a forest. The views of the city are also fantastic from here. We always bike here and find it quite challenging to dock our bike share bikes. It's great that there's bike path all the way here. There's always a farmer's market or vintage clothes going on here. So it's super vibrant but pretty expensive. We love it and visit in all seasons except in winter of course. Fall and spring are particularly beautiful.

I recently visited this place for the first time and loved it! What an awesome way to keep the history alive while breathing in life into it. I plan on coming back during their Saturday market but the Sunday I went was beautiful. It was a great day to go walking on their paths, reading about the history and learning about the wildlife. There needs to be more places like this that help us reconnect to nature.

Well maintained paved trails at the top and bottom level with nature all around! Going up to the top starting from the right side (or left, it's a loop) gives a great view of the hills and the city skyline. Once you reach the Don Valley Parks lookout, there's a small dirt path that takes you to the railway tracks. The path also connects to the Beltline trail.  There is a small shop containing lots of knickknacks and potential souvenirs at the main entrance area. The cafe is also a lovely place to get refreshments or a meal. Plenty of seats and picnic tables around as well, although it does get crowded during popular times in autumn.

One of Toronto’s true gems, this urban oasis has it all. Great walking paths, tons of wildlife and a real sense of nature in the middle of our city. On a daily basis in the spring and summer you’ll see turtles, frogs, snakes and a plethora of birds.  Originally where most of the bricks in Toronto came from this amazing place has been transformed.  The farmers market in the summer months is a huge bonus. From fresh strawberries to delicious street food and if you’re lucky a live music performance I highly recommend a trip to the Brick works.

editorial_summary.overview: Eco-oriented complex with a weekend farmer's market, a gardening store, event space & nature trails.

366.name: Withrow Park
366.formatted_address: 725 Logan Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 3B9, Canada
reviews: IMO the best park in Toronto. Perfect place to have a picnic or chill on the bleachers and watch people play soccer. Many lovely summer afternoons spent here just enjoying the world. Relaxed environment - clean and no one bothers you. There is a public washroom.

I love coming to this park and i am so glad it's just a 20 min walk away from home. The place is very well maintained, there are beautiful trees all over, play ground for kids, a big wide open field for kids to run around, or for people to chill. There a pretty big dog area as well, for all the dog owners and dog lovers to come around. I personally love to come here on days off just to look at dogs interacting. This park gives me a sense of peace, everyone seems to enjoy their time here. One of the best community parks in East York area. Definetly worth a visit, especially now with all the foliage.
I love this market so much, not in my neighborhood but it's worth making the trip out there on Saturdays in the spring, summer and fall.  They use reusable programs like Muuse.ca too🙌😎
Good place for tennis. Only two but surface is better than other public courts. Really crowded and line ups.

Always my favorite park beside my work. I eat my lunch here. It is very relaxing here. I like to sit down under the tree and feel the cool breeze. Lots activities for kids here but you can still have your little corner and have peace and quiet time. Soo love the place well mentained.

editorial_summary.overview: Recreational retreat featuring tennis courts, baseball fields, a playground & seasonal skating rink.

367.name: Lower Don Parklands
reviews: Beautiful trail with a nice view of the Don River that runs alongside it. Bridges are installed with colourful RGB lights which makes for quite the view after dark. Cyclists, prepare for some uphill climbs, and pedestrians must be careful at the bottom of the hills.
One of the greatest in the city. This is probably the single greatest hub to connect to all the other parks in the city.  Toronto truly is a city within a park.

Scenic trail that connects Edwards Gardens to Thorncliffe Park, Evergreen Brickworks, Victoria Park, and downtown. You can catch rabbits and deer along this trail that runs parallel to the Don River. It is mostly wooded with patches of grass space and some seating along the riverbed. Repaving is overdue on many points along the trail, particularly near Riverdale Park.
Amazing trails, makes you forget the city life. Come here to enjoy some tranquility

Perfect day for a walk around the trails. Minus 7 and sunshine today. This area is amazing and parking free on Beechwood at the very bottom under the Don Valley Parkway. Endless areas to walk, bike, even mountain bikes in the area. Great for families, children and furry kids. Trails are plenty wide enough to social distance and really not that many people can be seen as the trails are off in many different directions. You can travel north or south, towards the Brick Works or away from that area. You can cross the Don River over a foot pedestrian bridge and or walk along the small water side trails.

editorial_summary.overview: Oak- & maple-planted riverside park with a hiking, cycling & art trail & an annual salmon run.

368.name: Langford Parkette
368.formatted_address: 13 Woodycrest Ave, Toronto, ON M4J 3A5, Canada
reviews: Small playground , but great for few minutes of play time, mostly geared towards younger children , water fountain, sandbox, small play equipment (under 5yrs) 2 swings and some climbing equipment . There are also bars for adults and older kids just a few steps away. Great location just off danforth and kept clean.
Sweet little park. Bring your hot wheels- there’s a super fun ramp for them on the play structure!

Beautiful little okay structure for kids. It's especially good for 1 or 2 year olds because they have some tiny slide and places to climb and some swings. Overall a nice place to spend some time... And quiet.
Cute park, nice equipment, clean and well maintained. My kids love the faucet in the middle of the sandbox. My youngest would sit there digging canals all day if she could 😁

Great little parkette. It was just rebuilt last year with all new equipment. There are a couple swings, climbing apparatus, slide and play building, as well as a big sandpit with running water. There is also a grassy area with fitness circuit on the west side of the parkette. Great place to play with the kids!!

369.name: Bennington Heights Park
369.formatted_address: 465 Heath St E, East York, ON M4G 1B7, Canada
reviews: Nice park off Bayview to relax, walk the dog and watch a tennis game. Tennis courts are open to the public 8-11pm on the weekend. Steps from Bayview take you right to the school, keep in mind it is private property so better to take the route from Heath St.
Its next to my child's school and the place is green with loads of trees with sunlight makes it a good place to spend some time.
It's not a really a park and not really a school. It's both. But some will consider it their own personal space and not mind others. Keep your dog on a leash around kids. Neither are predictable.
Fun park & if you go to south end , can catch great views of the sunset! My daughter & I enjoyed together
Benningtion Height. Is a small prak near School, great place to relax and look at the sky,

370.name: Rosedale Park
370.formatted_address: 20 Scholfield Ave, Toronto, ON M4W 2Y3, Canada
reviews: Beautiful and historic!  Used to be the sports field of St. Andrew’s College - over 100 years ago the first Grey Cup was played there!!  Every year May it hosts the famous “Mayfair”.  One of the true gems of our neighbourhood!

Rose sale park is huge in size One of the best places in Toronto to hang around in summer and spring.  It’s got these beautiful entry and exits points that you may discover when you hang around the place.  There is also a bridge that shows you the mini lake entry as in the picture below
very good maintained grass field  have bathroom close by. tennis club’s  court is open to public in the weekend’s afternoon around 5 or 6 pm
Super big park . Attended Mayfair today . My kid absolutely loved it.
Very clean and maintained well. Lots of children and rec league sports but good for dogs if you go after hours or during the weekdays

371.name: Riverdale Park East
371.formatted_address: 550 Broadview Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 2N6, Canada
reviews: Perfect picturesque picnic spot for you and your pet!  You have a lovely view of the Toronto skyline, while enjoying your picnics in the summer!  Reach early in the evening to ensure you get a spot as per your liking, as this park tends to get crowded in the summers.  There is a running track for those looking to get moving as well as enough space to place soccer.

Excellent place to come and have a break from the hustle and bustle of the city. There were a lot of people just hanging around, enjoying the view and having picnics. Saw some people walking their dogs as well. The views of the Toronto skyline are just breathtaking.

My son n daughter in-law took me to the Riverdale park today on 7 May 2022 as the temperature was 16°C pleasant n pleasing sunny..with their baby for an outing. There were many families with children relaxing on the grass with some drinks n snacks, looked like a picnic spot.. It was nice to spend some time in the pleasant weather though it was windy

Rode pass this place couple of times while making a delivery, lots of people hanging out here. Enormously field with a track and baseball diamond area. However a great view of Downtown Toronto. No wonder why it's so unique to look at. Great positive energy for sure 😊

Beautiful park! I had a picnic there with friends and I couldn't believe how big it was. There's a track you can use or huge field space to play anything you want. The slopes will definitely see tobogganing this year.

editorial_summary.overview: A popular tobogganing spot, this sizable park with skyline views offers an ice rink & sports fields.

372.name: Chorley Park
372.formatted_address: 245 Douglas Dr, Toronto, ON M4W 2B9, Canada
reviews: Chorley Park  Toronto has its own Golden Encore, the last trees to change colour.  I love this park, it has history in it and the trail leads to a lot of other trails around Toronto.  It is always worth going back to.
Isn’t it so beautiful in autumn? It is a small park in a quite neighborhood but I was lucky to see multiple shades of fall here. There is also a stair connecting to don valley trail.
A must see for a quick weekend hike. Photoes are from my hike last spring. Lots pf greens and beautiful sceneries to take pictures. There's also a beatuiful pond with green leaves on top.
Beautiful park, well kept. People who use this park seem responsible and clean after themselves. I never find garbage or dog feces anywhere on the ground. Please don't ruin it. Thank you

We had a birthday party at this park. It was great. Lots of space for picnicking, playing soccer, trees for climbing😁, natural life ponds, hiking, cool place. There is paid parking or if you lucky you can get free parking on the road near the upper level of the park.

373.name: Todmorden Mills Park
373.formatted_address: 67, Todmorden Mills Park, 67 Pottery Rd, Toronto, ON M4K 2B9, Canada
reviews: Cool park, history and plaques. The pedestrian Bridge was easily my favorite remnant from when the river Don used to horseshoe around here.

Had a great walk, looking at all the trees and animals throughout the area. Had an art show going on when we were there as well. I wish the trails were a bit longer but I was pleased by the fact I didn't feel like I was in the middle of the city. Nice relaxing day...
It's beautiful and Peaceful. Makes us feel away from city. The pond in the park is amazing as yoi can witness Tadpoles, Frogs, Fishes and Turtles
Nice little historical park in Toronto. Surrounded by woods and a wildflower preserve. Gives great info about Toronto's past
Will go back when it is a bit more green and the trail is less sloppy.  But it seemed kinda nice in there.

374.name: Parking Indigo Toronto - Evergreen Brickworks
374.formatted_address: Evergreen Brickworks, 550 Bayview Ave, Toronto, ON M4W 3X8, Canada
reviews: East side usually plenty of spaces. West part is closer to the park entrance but busier. A good spot for fall’a sceneries. Could plan 30mins-60mins walking around.

375.name: Don Valley Brick Works Dog Park
reviews: Nice sized dog park. A lot of vegetation (I only go in the winter/snow). Beware of the dogwalkers, especially the ones that bring huge packs (there's one women dog walker that brings too many dogs with her and brings treats and drops them to the ground. she has almost no control over the dogs, one of them almost started a fight). I would recommend only going in if there's little to no dogs.
Small dog park. I like that there are trees and it's more than just an open space. Too bad parking is paid though
I'm going to the park for the first time. Google Maps can you show the parameter aka fence to the dog park...
You won't even notice there is a dog park here.
Sweet bike ride

376.name: Don Valley Park
376.formatted_address: Don Valley Pkwy, Toronto, ON M4K, Canada
reviews: I give the park and the Lower Don River Trail 4 star for it's natural beauty and the way it's kept untouched at the heart of the city. But I got one star back because there are no seats or any washroom facility along the trail (unless we get further off the trail).  I understand that we don't want to disrupt the natural environment by construction, though, at least seats along the trail at safe places and environmentally-friendly structures and washrooms do help to attract more people and the ones who can't walk long trails without getting rest along the way on seats.  This good trail also needs more access by providing more entry paths to the park from all neighbourhoods around the area.
Great place to take your kids to ride.  It is paved trails and it is very flat.  I can't believe we saw deers too.

Perfect place for a Park with so much foot traffic and or bikes traveling the trails of the Don River. Just needs some picnic tables for the summer months. We made our way from Riverdale Park West today and hiked along the Don River up as far as Pottery Road and so much has changed over the years. I miss that wooden structure that we used to walk or bike on that passed under the bridges. Now the trail takes you away from the 2 bridges and no sign of the past.

The bike trail from Canary District is a great cycling workout along the River. Many cyclists along the way. The trail is located within the city, and in the summer, it gives you a feeling of riding in the villages of India. Didn’t see any wildlife other than the insects that fly into your mouth and nose while cycling. Try to get done with the trail way before sunset to avoid the insects.
It’s now become a ritual to go on the David Balfour trail to the Brickworks and back on Moore Park trail (refer photo 3)

377.name: Main Gates
377.formatted_address: 550 Bayview Ave, Toronto, ON M4W 3X8, Canada

378.name: TargetPark
378.formatted_address: 550 Bayview Ave, Toronto, ON M4W 3X8, Canada
reviews: Got the city to issue my friend a parking ticket at my building even though he paid for parking. He strung my friend along until he had to contest the ticket in court.

379.name: Broadview Subway Station Parkette
379.formatted_address: 769 Broadview Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 2P7, Canada
reviews: Not much to this place. You can cover the entire grounds in 10 steps walking diagonally across the park.  Their is usually a bird feeder or a very Shabbir dressed man or women taken a break here.  I appreciate the place, it's better then more concrete in this jungle of a city.
TTC subway/bus/streetcar station. Work in progress. Somewhat clear signage. Probably needs some freshening up.
Convenient place to sit down....really just three benches on the corner of the street. But it's useful if you're waiting for someone etc.
Generally clean station with the amount of foot traffic As with all stations announcements hard to understand

This is the place to be if you are looking to kill some time, or watch for streetcars as they try to enter or exit Broadview Station without running into people, bikes, speeding cars, and their own buses. Also the best place in the area to pigeon watch. I'm sure people are feeding the flock of birds because they are fat even in winter.

380.name: Playter Gardens
380.formatted_address: 2L1, 4 Cambridge Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 2L1, Canada
reviews: A gorgeous little park that looks pretty in the fall. Has benches where you can sit.
If ever walking or biking around Danforth and Broadview this might be a spot to relax for a bit right at the entrance of the bridge heading downtown

Not the best spot for a green space squeezed into a corner by bustling Danforth/Bloor and a bunch of apartments. Only 2 benches so sometimes they're both taken. Many close options for better green spaces

Playter Gardens is a tiny parkette just before the bridge that crosses the Don River.   There are a couple interesting historical plaques located here and certainly you won't get lost in this park.   It's quaint.  - A Richard Trus review
If you're a people watcher or just enjoy the good ol' cops meeting there quota.. this is the park for you 👍

381.name: Charles Sauriol Parkette
381.formatted_address: Charles Sauriol Parkette, 4 Hillside Dr, East York, ON M4K 2M2, Canada
reviews: A nice memorial park for Charles Sauriol who wrote about camping in the valley as a boy scout in the 1920's then build a cabin there when he became an adult.
Some cool shaded benches. Usually an exceptionally brisk breeze. Minor traffic noise
A nice green space.
Very small.
Beautiful park

382.name: Don Valley Brick Works Park
382.formatted_address: 550 Bayview Ave, Toronto, ON M4W 3X8, Canada
reviews: Very beautiful park in middle of city. You cant imagine there would be such a remote place just besides a highway. You can also continue your walk toward mount pleasant cemetery if you’d like to walk more

Pretty good. The park is pretty small but well maintained. Probably not suitable for older people - you need to go up the hill quite a bit. The parking is plentiful at $8/day but it gets busy on the weekends.

This is one of my favourite parks in the city! I first went there many years ago before the buildings were restored as part of a field trip. I learned about the wonderful geological features, like fossils of trilobites and even a giant beaver! However, the beautiful wetlands were what captured my heart. It’s so amazing to see wildlife like snapping turtles and blue herons in the city! I highly recommend hiking up to the lookout, especially in autumn to take in all the glorious colours.

This is a hidden gem in Toronto. Once in the park it seems we have reached the country side. Fall is the best time with the riot of colors. Great place for all ages. Must visit if you live or visiting Toronto.
Lots of parking. Nice and quiet park. Gentle slops and easy to walk. Great areas for neat brick back drop pictures. Dog friendly.

editorial_summary.overview: Natural 40-acre park on a former quarry site with trails, ponds & Toronto skyline views.

383.name: Wychwood Barns Park
383.formatted_address: 76 Wychwood Ave, Toronto, ON M6G 2X7, Canada
reviews: This is one of those ‘Private neighborhoods’ Elegant houses neatly tucked behind old and humongous trees, not for effects, just how it is..There’s a buried creek here that pools to a very nice pond being used for skating in the winter months. The roads are uphill, downhill and turned all the way to loops, you’ll get confuse, I think that’s the idea so you don’t wander around here. So anyway, Taddle creek winds under those big houses and ends at Davenport Rd.  Wychwood Barns Park is a dream! Go visit and say your oohh aaaahhhh. Enjoy!
Nice multipurpose park and facility for events.  And it even has a volleyball court (but bring your own net).  Farmers market every Sat morning.
Large park with dynamic space for indoor and outdoor events. Very limited parking options around.

This review is for the Saturday farmers' market. It's quite a social scene for kids of all ages and their dogs. Music plays! You will find local purveyors of vegetables, mushrooms, meats, fish, cheese, honey, bread, pastries and more, plus fast food and drinks of various styles and ethnic origins. Quality seems universally high and prices are reasonable for such an  entertaining atmosphere. There's lots of green space, many TTC options, plentiful parking, and that stretch of St. Clair provides a variety of interesting shopping opportunities. Highly recommended!
A great community space that is inviting and open.  Went to the Garlic Festival and enjoyed every minute of this event.

editorial_summary.overview: Park featuring a playground, a sports field, volleyball, an off-leash dog area & the Wychwood Barns.

384.name: Nordheimer Ravine
384.formatted_address: 326 Spadina Rd, Toronto, ON M5P 1N5, Canada
reviews: This ravine has a built in off leash dog park. I go almost everyday to walk my dog and escape the city. You feel like your out of the city. It also connects with the Belt Line which is a beautiful walk.

Nordheimer Ravine to Cedarvale Park  We started the hike at the Spadina Station and passing by the Baldwin steps leading to Casa Loma.  We bypassed the Baldwin steps and went on the trail to Cedarvale Park. There was a nice display of fall colours.  There was also an off-leash dog-park.

A whole different world within a city..  Wonderful for those who want to experience forest bath. I didn't experience anything odd but hopefully they have security in place in case any issue occurs or any anti-social elements attack.
It's really small but I guess it is a nice spot for walking your dog
Walk off St Clair and you're there - one of the many hidden oasis right in the middle of Toronto!

editorial_summary.overview: This ravine features a walking path through native trees & plants, plus local wildlife.

385.name: The Tollkeeper's Park
385.formatted_address: 750 Davenport Rd, Toronto, ON M6G 2B3, Canada
reviews: Visit the Tollkeepers Cottage and learn about history of life in 1860 which is a little museum in the park. Run by volunteers open Saturdays entrance  by donation

Interesting obscure piece of Toronto history. Realistically, this spot is more of a bench and open space near an old building that's generally locked. Will check back in if I ever see it open. Should be a museum.

Step back in time. This is a recteation/restoration of an actual toll keepers cottage from the time if the BNA act. They so hold regular events and when 5he house is quiet the surrounding garden and grounds provide a sweet respite from modern life.
Nice little parkette, it is small, but it is not used very much.  I take my dog there once a day for a little off leash training
A nice park

386.name: Frank Stollery Parkette
386.formatted_address: 1 Davenport Rd, Toronto, ON M5R 3M3, Canada
reviews: The pigeons have taken over this park ... never been a fan of it..only sat on the benches there to tie my shoe and continue on my walk
Simple corner on a middle of the street with lots of sitings.
Marks the historical Ancient Trail of indeginous people of North America. Unfortunately the land is still in dispute of unpaid treaty settlement to the Mississauga New Credit nation
Shelter for pigeons

387.name: Vessel
387.formatted_address: Lowther Ave, Toronto, ON M5R, Canada
reviews: The highlight of Taddle Creek Park is a water feature and sculpture called the "Vessel". It commemorates the Taddle Creek that used to flow underneath.
My most favorite park in Toronto. Perfect for a quick outdoor lunch.
Nice! Good place for kids.
Very cool sculpture
Lovely area

388.name: Vinci Park Svc Canada Inc
388.formatted_address: 1560 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4T 2S9, Canada

389.name: Orchard Parc, Inc.
389.formatted_address: 1200 Bay St. #202, Toronto, ON M4W 1J2, Canada

390.name: Oriole Park
390.formatted_address: 201 Oriole Pkwy, Toronto, ON M5P 2H1, Canada
reviews: 2022 August 3.5★ If your in the area, this isn't a bad park to stop by. Especially since there's a public washroom and it's connected to trails nearby. The park itself is fairly clean. On nice days, the park will be full of people given the amenities: Ping pong/table tennis table Baseball diamond Tennis court Children's playground with swings and climbing structure Small splash pad Small garden Free book exchange Public washrooms  There's also a public bike rental in this park.
The park is medium in size. Popular among local people. Baseball area in one corner. Ice cream truck in another corner. Good for picnic and spending good time with your family and friends.

As someone who has relocated from Dubai which has fantastic parks, I was pleasantly surprised with the number of parks in Toronto. Oriole park near davisville subway station is a fantastic clean park for kids. My daughter loved open space, greenery and the water splash area where kids love to cool down. It also has couple of tennis courts and a very unique table tennis table and lots of space for jogging.
Such a good vibe park. Everyone has something for them here. Table Tennis and Tennis court adds extra attractions. Toddler water splash area is a huge hit too. Colorful, pretty park

Clean and well maintained park. Not huge, but certainly worth a stroll through.  There's a baseball diamond, a playground, benches, and a ping pong table (paddles and balls not provided, of course).  On the weekends it gets fairly busy, and during the warmer seasons, there are often peewee baseball games (which can get loud, be mindful of this if you're seeking serenity).  This park connects to bicycle routes in all cardinal directions, including the beltline trail.

editorial_summary.overview: Park with a playground & splash pad, plus sports facilities, washrooms & many shade trees.

391.name: Lawren Harris Park
391.formatted_address: 145 Rosedale Valley Rd, Toronto, ON M4W 1P7, Canada
reviews: Nice quiet place to sit without feeling the crowdedness of downtown. Its in front a all glass condo so as long as you don’t face toward it, its all good.
Nice small park covered by many large trees. Some seating and grass covers throughout.

I used to visit this park as it was close to work and dispite it being very close to the road it was a nice spot to spend lunch. Recently traffic has picked up in the area making it not as ideal as it once was.
Amazing view from this park
The park is small. Not well maintained. The designated historical building was inconspicuously situated which is easily missed by the passers by.

392.name: Ramsden Park
392.formatted_address: 1020 Yonge St & Ramsden Park Rd, Toronto, ON M4W 1P7, Canada
reviews: There is convenient free parking off Yonge Street (check out maps). The park has 8 tennis courts, large grassy area and a playground with splash pool. The playground has soft "cork-style" flooring to protect children who fall.  The large splash pool is to one side with two levels of equipment for small and older children. At present, only the washrooms located beyond the tennis courts are open. The men's room has very strong urine scent. Some of the equipment is not the "standard" city equipment which makes it attractive to kids. The playground is wheelchair accessible and so are the washrooms. There are also 2 basketball courts, an outdoor hockey rink and a baseball diamond.
Very kids friendly park with a decent public washroom.  There are a number of benches that you can sit together and eat. With lots of parking around.
Medium size park near ISCKON Temple. Extends from Avenue Road to Yonge Street. It has Children play area, Tennis Courts, Dog off-leash area and washroom.

Ramsden Park is a great park, literally right across the street from the Rosedale Subway Station. Plenty of amenities here for children, families, young adults and pets! Some of the facilities include a ball diamond, playground, wading pool, tennis courts, basketball courts and an off-leash dog area! There plenty of trees to provide shade, picnic tables and other benches. A good place to spend a couple of hours relaxing or getting some excercise!

It's an impressive park with lots of public facilities. There's rubber trails on the park to ease your walk, there's kids playground and basketball park not far from each other. This park is quite the size, they even have 8 tennis courts and a descent dog park. The neighborhood seems nice and quiet as well. The only downside is their washroom is poorly maintained as the smell so horrible I had to put my mask on coming in. Overall, one of the nice park we have in TO.

editorial_summary.overview: Park with playgrounds & a wading pool, plus a dog park, an ice rink/tennis court & other sports.

393.name: Sir Winston Churchill Park
393.formatted_address: 301 St Clair Ave W, Toronto, ON M4V, Canada
reviews: Great view of the city but the real gem here is the tennis court. It was privately financed so it’s received a massive upgrade. Open to the public though. Probably super ideal for dogs and a picnic

Nice open space surrounded by lots of trees! Great walking path around perimeter. There's a off leash dog area, but generally find a lot of dog people consider entire park off leash. Just be aware of you have any concerns w/off leash dogs...
Tennis court Saturday Sunday and public holidays for public 7-11pm , playground for kids , spacious
Very spacious,no shade for children at play but great playground. Tennis courts are also there.

It's a very accessible park that is flat. So flat that it's suitable for playing sports like catch and frisbee. It's also got a great running track that loops around the park. Because there are no inclines and declines, the track is great for beginner runners. I do wish there are more trees at the park, which is why I'm giving it 4 stars.

394.name: Vermont Square Park
394.formatted_address: 819 Palmerston Ave, Toronto, ON M5R 3G5, Canada
reviews: This park had supposedly high rating. However, we didn't find the park alluring enough. The Park has a playground which has one play structure, splash pad, few benches, sandplace, and a small open area.  There is a enclosed rink area besides the park. Overall an average park, worth visiting for 2-3 hours.
Cool park for the kids! Gated, lots of space and searing for the adults, cool water/mud pit for digging in. My 9 year old loved it.
This is a nice little park that generally has people and dogs occupied there. It's a nice place to gather, hang out or play fetch with the dog
Great off-leash dog park (check times as is a few hours in the morning and at the end of the day).
A little crowded at certain times, but happy to live near a park with off leash dog hours.

395.name: Village of Yorkville Park
395.formatted_address: 115 Cumberland St, Toronto, ON M5S 2W7, Canada
reviews: The Village of Yorkville Park is a great place for photo ops and hanging out with friends and family.  Every winter, around Christmas time they host the Cavalcade of Lights with beautiful Christmas light displays.  In the winter they also have the ice sculptures located here (February I believe) and they’ll have the Festival of Lights and different themed events here throughout the year.  Centrally located in Yorkville, there are lots of coffee shops and restaurants to grab a snack and make a day out of it with some great shopping.  This is a fun place to bring the family whether you’re from Toronto or visiting, if you happen to catch an event at the park, chances are it will be well lit and picture perfect!!

A beautiful park right in the heart of Yorkville village. Right on the top of the Bay subway station it's well connected to all the places. It has some amazing restaurants and shopping centres surrounding the park. Several festivals are held at this park, Yorkville Christmas holiday, ice sculpture festival etc.

Lovely park in the middle of Downtown, surrounded by the best stores of the city. With a boulder that is over a billion years and diferent sections, it's a little oasis, great to take the kids or enjoy a quiet time in your day relaxing with a cup of tea or coffee. Beautiful Christmas lights and decorations turn it into a Winter Wonderland on this Holiday season.

Not worth the hype. To be honest I expected a bigger area worthwhile to walk around but was greeted with a tiny park. While the decorations looked amazing the overall image it gave off was a cluttered mess. Quite disappointing.
We love coming here a few times in December to check out the lights with the kids. They love it here and have memories attached to it

editorial_summary.overview: Upscale shops & restaurants surround this small open space & events site with a fountain.

396.name: David A. Balfour Park
396.formatted_address: 75 Rosehill Ave, Toronto, ON M4T 1G4, Canada
reviews: Quiet park in midtown, away from the city noise.  Lots of benches to rest and talk or read. Paved walking track for your exercise that goes around the entire park. Quiet garden area to relax. Play area with swings and slides for the little ones. Public washrooms available. Highly enjoyed the park.

One of the more quieter parks of Town. Perfect location that is isolated from the traffic and the city noise.. Lots of benches and amenities to enhance the quality. Only thing that I would change is the size of the park. It is pretty small compared to some other parks and would greatly benefit from being bigger or additional trails.

Nice trail with natural springs and brooks. Lots of stiff heights for those who want rigorous cardio. Within town (just 5 mins walk from st Clair) but still feels like deep forest remote area once entered …. Beware of slips and trips due to no maintenance

This park is beautiful, well maintained and so refreshing. There's a ravine trail that connects from the little park besides, and this park as well. It's just an amazing experience. It's green, beautiful and lush. Although I think a little bit maintenance is required in some parts of it.

I can't believe it took so long to discover the David Balfour Park trail and Yellow Creek. This hike follows several trail connections and we decided to follow it south,  down to the Mud Creek trail - aka the Brickworks - so that we could turn back up and create a loop. For a truly inner city hike, I give this a score of 4.5. The trail is mostly packed ground and well maintained but our route did have a couple of exciting crossings of Mount Pleasant Ave. that require attention and care.  Easy to get your steps in, a few mostly gentle inclines and great tree canopies that keep you shaded for most of the hike.  And how many hikes end with a reflection on life as our loop took us through the cemetery to finish off the day. Just shy of 10 k but you can easily do more.  We loved the last set of stairs that end it off. - NOT! 😁

editorial_summary.overview: Scenic, serene park with trails leading into a forested ravine, plus grassy areas & a reservoir.

397.name: Picnic table
397.formatted_address: 59 Poplar Plains Rd, Toronto, ON M4V 2N1, Canada
reviews: I waited a long time and staff never came. Seats weren't that comfortable. Like sitting on a plank of wood. I tried to pull in my chair and couldn't. It's like it was stuck. Nice rustic finish on the table though. They must have tried hard to get that weathered look.
Become woke in this wood
The wokest of woods

398.name: Poplar Plains Parkette
398.formatted_address: 125 Boulton Dr, Toronto, ON M4V 2V5, Canada
reviews: It's a small slice of nature sandwiched between Boulton Ave. and Poplar Plains, just south of Russell Hill Rd. A couple of park benches and no garbage or recycling bins, but you are surrounded by mature trees on a steep slope down to the entrance to Roycroft Parklands, a gem of a dog walk just a few blocks west of Avenue Rd., just east of Spadina Rd. And just south of St. Clair Ave. W. In the winter, the parkette has a wicked sled run. Only lasts 10 seconds or so, but they are among the most terrifying seconds of your life.
Beautiful green space in the neighbourhood
Nice little park in a great area.
Nice serene spot
Woke woods

399.name: Roycroft Park
399.formatted_address: 150 Boulton Dr, Toronto, ON M4V 2V6, Canada
reviews: Perfect for jogging as it is a small park. Very clean and quite. Smell of fresh air, loved it!
Nice spot for taking a break from the city landscape

Rycroft cuts a path through the ravine that runs northwest from Boulton all the way to St. Clair. There's a park at the south end with a couple benches, a leash-free dog park (Roycroft is perfect for dog walks) and lots of woods that lets you forget you're in a city. Limited available street parking.
Lovely park hidden from the city
Cute little park after you come out of the ravine

400.name: Boulton Drive Parkette
400.formatted_address: 15 Boulton Dr, Toronto, ON M4V 2V4, Canada
reviews: It's a little slice of pie bordered by Boulton and Poplar Plains. Shady, a couple benches, garbage and recycling bins. Not much else. But on a long walk, it's a great pit stop.
Better than filling it with overpriced homes. Some wonderful pre-1910 homes hidden under the refinished facades along the east side of Poplar Plains to look at while sitting here.
Another great piece of nature in this neighbourhood
The amount of bench/sit was enough but took down one and sad about it. Hope it will get replaced
Safe for kids to play.

401.name: High Level Pumping Station And Park
401.formatted_address: 300 Macpherson Ave, Toronto, ON M4V 1A3, Canada
reviews: A great place to visit if you get a chance during Doors Open. Learn about the history of the station, water pumping in Toronto, etc. The old machinery is fantastic to look at, and the whole building is a beautiful example of public infrastructure.
Nice old building in this old part of town. Casa Loma is up the street as well. The building is very old but have been updated over the years by the city of Toronto. Very cool pumping station .
They have some old pumps moving water up hill. Some of the old pumps are steam powered.
I grew up here many years ago.  Nostalgic visit.
Huge pumping station.

402.name: Glen Edyth Drive Parkette
402.formatted_address: 5 Glen Edyth Dr, Toronto, ON M4V 2V8, Canada
reviews: 2022 September 3.5★ A nice park closely connected to a larger path. For a parkette, this green space has a decent playground with lots of structures. Good for younger kids up to about age 10. Sand based, so great for those who also enjoy playing in sand. Right across the park, public rental bicycles are available.  Free parking right beside the park on the weekends.
Great playground and a green extension on the other side of the hill
Beautiful park. Lots of shade,great for young and older children. Swings,slides, climbers,sandbox, nice areas to eat also.two picnic tables or just throw a blanket out on the grass.
Great park. Kids playground structures are taken care of and the whole place is clean. Recommended.
Very nice midtown park with playground equipment, benches, picnic tables, and lots of large trees providing plenty of shady spots. Not a huge park, but very picturesque, lovely, and tranquil.

403.name: Dufferin Grove Park
403.formatted_address: 875 Dufferin St, Toronto, ON M6H 3K8, Canada
reviews: We attended the Native Child Centre Powwow and it was an amazing atmosphere. The park was very accessible via parking and transit. Plus since it’s right next to the mall we were able to get drinks and use the washroom without any issues through the day (since we didn’t want to use the opera potties).
