Thanks for hosting a wonderful event and hope to attend next year.
Every time I go out shopping I pass by here and have some coffee. Very beautiful colours in the fall and very green during spring and summer. I wish there were a clean bike trail.

Great playground with lots of unique structures. There's areas for all ages, a 4 person see saw and a kids outdoor kitchen. Some stuff is starting to look dated and it's not great when it's muddy, but it's got charm. Good sledding Hill for smaller kids. It's been ages but have fond memories of visiting the farmers market, but I live too far to come for weekday markets. Today I discovered they have a city run fire pit too.
I absolutely love this beautiful park!!!  We want to an awesome pow wow there in October.
haunted as helllll I freaked myself out at 3:30 (yeah it’s superstitious but I was scared and I always chill there at any other hour np)

editorial_summary.overview: Large park with an ice rink & playground, plus basketball, picnic areas & a weekly farmer's market.

404.name: Don Panos Parkette
404.formatted_address: 3 Prescott Ave, Toronto, ON M6N 3G6, Canada
reviews: A tiny park with chess tables, a huge power pylon and lovely murals of roses, makes it an overall oddity but also a great place for teens and young adults to go an take memorable photos.

Lotta hydro wires. Tiny. But connected path is fun. Unfortunately this green space isn't the best for relaxation, however the park just passed the bridge is. The arch makesit look good. Recently cleaned up and used for local neighborhood events - like a cornroast and Santa.

This is one of the many hydro parks in Toronto.   The St. Clair Gardens features very cool outdoor chess tables and some sort of half sphere for goal posts perhaps not quite sure.   In the center of the park is a huge hydro electric tower.  - A Richard Trus review
Very nice park. Chess boards and seating are  welcoming.
Small parquette, the community celebrates festivals here a few times a year

405.name: Really Really Free Market
405.formatted_address: 225 Campbell Ave, Toronto, ON M6P 3V5, Canada
reviews: I would say some better crowd control is needed. Be aware of the aggressive hoarders who bring carts and grab anything in sight just because it's free. Really unfortunate as in principle the idea is great but the fact of humanity in general being terrible brings it down.  I did bring a bunch of unneeded items and left with some items that could make my home better. Overall an average experience.

Visited 3 times this year and I always find things for home decor, clothes, laundry basket, seasonal items... make sure you check the clothes very well, sometimes people donate damage clothes and I don't understand why, it's supposed to be clean and in Good conditions.

People work hard to create and maintain the market for everybody to enjoy. If you haven't been there, it's a market run by volunteers that open to the public to take and give away (you don't have to) usable stuff. You meet nice people there and it's worth checking out.
Arrived at 11 and found only few clothes and some books, everything else worth it was probably been already taken. Spent 3 minutes there. Appreciate the spirit of this event, but wasn't for us

as others have said, this is a place where friendly volunteers help keep things out of landfills to get them into the hands of those who need them. The system is well organized in the rules for participation are clear. Look forward to visiting again.

406.name: Susan Tibaldi Parkette
406.formatted_address: 357 Margueretta St, Toronto, ON M6H 1N3, Canada
reviews: A small park offering some playground activities for children. Not a lot of playground equipment. Wood chips rather than sand which is a definite positive feature
Lovely park for a date
Not as clean as Toronto 2 b.
Great little park for kids and adults in the neighborhood.
Tiny neighborhood park tucked in behind Bloor St. laneways, with nice trees, benches, and simple playground stuff for kids.

407.name: Ritchie Avenue Parkette
407.formatted_address: 77 Ritchie Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 2K1, Canada
reviews: Small park but kids love it. Swings, a playground set, concrete ping pong table, and in winter a small ice skating surface.
People keep stealing the F---ing ping pong paddles. But overal a nice place to take your kids of you are in the area
Cute little parkette. A little out of the way but really popular with the locals. To be honest, I come here because of the Ingress portal.
Friendly Park. However really small. Has a ping pong table though 😁
Small, quiet with a ping pong table! A lovely parkette.

408.name: MacGregor Playground
408.formatted_address: 346 Lansdowne Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 3Y1, Canada
reviews: This is a great park for family's! Not so much for fur babies. This area is not dog friendly although I do break the rules lol

The red clay field is awesome to play on but the batter's box needs work; please note wood bats only at this location! Dog friendly place to socialize with nice grass to play, secluded shady areas available. Clean washrooms and the splashpad is so cool on a hot day. Love the train that pulls by every so often adding to ambience of Toronto. Quiet spot among the noise.
Field, track,  baseball diamond,  play structures, new splash pads, washrooms,  shade, Adirondack chairs, picnic bench, parking on street or behind school. Great place to spend hours
Great park for the kids to attend the splash pad!! My kid loved it. Ice cream truck goes by it frequently.

Such a great park! The splash pad is top. And there is a little park for the kids to play in after they’re done splashing around. There is usually free street side parking along the street. Must most importantly there are bathrooms which are relatively clean all things considered.

409.name: Wallace Emerson Park
409.formatted_address: 1260 Dufferin St, Toronto, ON M6H 4C3, Canada
reviews: This is a nice little park with a small ice rink next to a larger hockey I rink. If you’re coming to skate this is a nice place to go, but that’s pretty much all there is. It is next to a plaza so you can go do a bit of shopping after you are done skating. Lots of free parking.
Amazing place with amazing people. Enjoy it while you can before they remove the rinks.
Fantastic little skate area with both a proper rink with boards for hockey and independent skating area. They have change rooms on site and lots of oarking in the adjacent plaza (for now).

The playpark is large and stuffed with activities like a bball court, waterpark, playground with lots of things I wish I had as a kid plus a mighty fine skate park is located within a two minute walk! What else could you want?! Other than a pool I suppose!!!!
Love the ice hockey rink ( the one with the boards ) and leisure skating pad . Its a shame the condo developers at Galleria Mall are going to remove the ice rink for good

410.name: Dovercourt Park
410.formatted_address: 155 Fernbank Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 3A2, Canada
reviews: It's a good park for evening sunset time. You can play baseball, soccer, tennis and relax on the grass.
Great park - great community and not officially… but very ‘dog friendly’

Nice little park. It’ll definitely be our new frequent tennis spot. If you get the timing right you won’t have to wait too long but even if you do, it’s a nice place to sit around and maybe have a little picnic while you wait
It was great. We were able to use the park for a baby shower. Although it rained we were able to set up pop up gazebos and stay dry. No one complained and we also made sure we cleaned up.
Great new repaved hard courts

411.name: Symington Avenue Playground
411.formatted_address: 360 Symington Ave, Toronto, ON M6P 3W9, Canada
reviews: Nice little park with ping pong table, chess table and tennis courts... Oh and baseball diamond

This is a nicely kept space that offers an open field for soccer or frisbee etc. It has a baseball diamond and two tennis courts also a cement ping pong table. Tucked away in the back of the park is a local community garden where plots can be rented, there is a waiting list to get plots though.  Unfortunately the park does not have any play structures, swings or sandboxes making it more ideal for adults. Thats why Im giving it 4 stars, otherwise it is a great public outdoor space.
A good place to chill on a lazy Sunday... especially if you are a big fan of dogs. Cause a LOT of families bring their dogs here to play and it's just ❤️🐶❤️🐶❤️
Love this place, with community garden, tenis court, and field for families to meet and dogs to play.
This park has an exercise area a baseball area and even a community garden It's a quite park but beautiful.

412.name: Davenport Village Park
412.formatted_address: 18 Foundry Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 4L1, Canada
reviews: Decent public park tucked into the Davenport Village neighborhood. Well-used by the locals, mainly because of the above-average playground structures. Dog Central too, though people seem respectful with leashing and cleaning up. Surprisingly high number of birds hanging out here too, mainly next to the rail corridor. Splash pad being installed now. Hopefully it's ready before summer ends.
Seems like a nice park. I think it is being expanded or rebuilt and will likely be even better in the near future.
Excellent park tucked between the houses. Great for children and people in the neighbourhood. If you are visiting, you will find it hard to find parking

This place is great. Nestled between the townhomes, it has a large kids' playground and plenty of benches for parents to watch their kids and enjoy the coffee they get at one of the finest coffee shop in this city.
Nice park, not to crowded which makes it relaxing to visit with small kids. The coffee shop in front makes it very convenient.

413.name: Campbell Park
413.formatted_address: 225 Campbell Ave, Toronto, ON M6P 3V5, Canada
reviews: Neat park, tucked in the Junction triangle. Kiddo plays in a soccer league there and she greatly enjoys it. There is a wadding pool/splash feature and a playground as well as a hockey rink. Everything I've gone there is young adults having a good time either playing soccer or picnic-ing
Nice little park in the block. Nicely maintained field.

The playground area covered in sand; nice and soft. If your kids love to play with sand this is the one! This place also has wading pool during summer time which is very nice!!! Its open from 12-7pm but come at around 1.30. They should be done with putting chemical in the pool around that time.
Nice place to get fresh air.  There is a hockey ring in this park. The restroom is closed for the season.
Great ice rink and park

editorial_summary.overview: Recreational oasis offering a playground, sports fields, a basketball court & wintertime ice rink.

414.name: Perth Square Park
414.formatted_address: 350 Perth Ave, Toronto, ON M6P 3Y3, Canada
reviews: This park is perfect for picnic. It has sandpit, playground and splash pad! Lots of big trees all over the park even for splash pad! Sometimes when you go to the park and wish it has washroom well yes this park has washroom!!
Best community park I've been to in awhile! Lots of friendly young and old families there . Lots of kids for your kids to play with. Even has a fire pit!

This quiet little park is a hidden gem. There is a fun splash pad for the kids and lots of grass (both shaded and unshaded) for picnicers or sunbathers. There's a Dominos and Tacos Gus just up the street so you aren't far from food. There are swings and other playground equipment for the kids, too. I recommend this place.

Splash pad! The kids love it. Very spacious and washroom is open. There's also a fire pit that's pretty much not monitored at the moment. You can also bbq here if you have coal or gas bbq. Nice friendly family vibe!

Lovely little park.  It has public washrooms, playground, and splash pad. There are big beautiful trees to take a break to sit in the shade as well as sunny open space.   It is a great place for a picnic, and it has public bathrooms. Clean, well kept, and also a nice walkway for baby carriages.

415.name: Carlton Park
415.formatted_address: 20 Edith Ave, Toronto, ON M6P 3T5, Canada
reviews: They have a good playground, basketball court, Wade pool, and a lot of green space to sit down and relax. They also have a space to have a campfire. Every November 1st they host the pumpkin parade there. It's super cool!
Love the play ground here great for older kids and for toddlers and loved that its a sand park my kids favorite.

A hidden gem. The wading pool is relatively warm because it gets full sun all day, but there's lots of shade to be found nearby. The playground equipment is good for kids of all ages and having a sand surface for the entire playground is a bonus. No washroom, but there is a port-a-potty, which is better than nothing.

The play structures are great and suit a variety of ages. There is a splash pad in the summer (just a kiddie pool, no fountains or spraying structures), and the splash pad is equipped with lifeguards hired by the city of Toronto. There are picnic tables and plenty of shade. The park is great! I only wish there was a real washroom here (and not a port-a-potty).
A hidden gem with a real communuty feel. From basketball courts and fire pits, to splash pad and playground ... it has it all! Lots of yummy food options to grab so.erhing nearby as well!

416.name: Primrose Avenue Parkette
416.formatted_address: 120 Primrose Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 3V3, Canada
reviews: Great park to bring your kids, has toys, kitchen a playhouse and cars for kids to play beside the playground area. It is fenced to the street so safe for small kids. Since I went there kids always ask to come back even tho it is not a big park.
Great little parkette. Playground and supervised wading pool in the summer. Sand pit, swings, slides, monkey bars. Lots of trees and shade, 2+ picnic tables and benches.
This little park has lots of grass, trees and shrubs which blossom in Spring, swings and slides for children and a small wading pool. There are also a couple benches. Nothing fancy, but functional.
Great park for kids, has wading pool in summer 5 days a week, as well as some swings and slides. Generally maintained well,   unfortunate that some people who walk their dogs there do not pick up.
Splash pad isn't always running. But the park is setup fairly well. Street parking only.

417.name: Earlscourt Park Dogs Off-Leash Area
417.formatted_address: 1200 Lansdowne Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 3Z8, Canada
reviews: Great place to let your fur baby unleash energy. Friendly neighbors and a great place to socialize your dogs. Easily 4 acres of fenced in wood chipped floor, complete with rakes and water fountain. Fountain is currently off but there's a 10 gallon bucket with a water bowl which frequent dog owners keep full. Filled it once myself. Two double gated entrances and lots of refuse bins. Lots of shade from mature trees keeps the hot sun off you and your dogs. Only bad thing is there is only one picnic table with seating for three, and a regular bench at the northern entrance. Overall a great place to let your dog be a dog. Fountain is now working.
Great park for if u live near it and can't drive to high park .has the wood chips so it helps after rain .does have it's muddy spots.

Well shaded with mature trees and a pleasant group of responsible dog owners. Space to run, securely fenced from the rest of the park. Fence is low in places if you have a very large and agile dog but never had an issue with mine (who regularly jumps the cedarvale fence).

Great park. Has a pool, community center, large outdoor track, exercise fixtures, kids play equipment, etc. Since the park is elevated, it has trees and vegetation around the perimeters so it gives the park and "outside city" feel.
Beautiful community area for all ages. I went to the library to work, then had lunch outside by the track field, and in the evening I went to the swimming pool. All in one place!

418.name: Beaver Lightbourn Parkette
418.formatted_address: 94 Lightbourn Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 2E8, Canada
reviews: What a cool park with a boardwalk down the center of Beaver Lightbourn parkette.   It's a smaller park and it has some cool/scarey homes located right beside it on the West side.   A great place to take some photo's of grafitti - A Richard Trus review
A very small park with a strange boardwalk and exactly 1 bench
A nice little park quiet little park
More benches would be nice.
It's okay

419.name: Pelham Avenue Playground
419.formatted_address: 20 Pelham Ave, Toronto, ON M6N 2W9, Canada
reviews: The park  is so small but it is nice to get peace and quiet time. Also nice to take your  pets.
Fun park with different structures than most of the playgrounds in the area.
Awesome place  park is clean  and where to meet the kids  and people  who live here in this  community  is friendly.
Very small but well planned park.
Small space but good for young kids

420.name: Earlscourt
reviews: Huge enclosed off leash dog park. Water fountain and dishes for your furbabies. Covered almost entirely with majestic mature trees.

TLDR: It's a great park with lots of green space that is well maintained. Rinks, running track, basketball courts, baseball diamond, soccer pitch, playground, gazebo, and lots of space to sit.  Earlscourt has been a life-saver for having access to well maintained green space in York.  Complete with a variety of sport amenities (basketball, baseball, soccer, ice rink, swimming pool, running track, small workout area] a playground, a small splashpad and an off leash dog area.  Even with all these amenities the greatest perk of Earlscourt is just the scale of green space you have to set-up a picnic, lay out in the sun, or for myself draw some of the local buildings is fantastic in this part of York.  If you want a little escape from the stretches of concrete in every direction around it, Earlscourt is a great spot for a little break in your day.  (Next time I'm down in good weather I'll grab some pictures)
Tucked away between neighbourhoods and it's pretty good size. Hills, track, 2 or 3 fields, swimming pool, kiddie pool, bathrooms, dog park!
Great park for exercise, families, dogs, and casual hangs with friends. Big enough for all parties
It's quite the experience. I saw a twerking class being held, bats in the sky, and hawks, tons of people gathered with no masks - the land of the free

421.name: Chandos Park North
421.formatted_address: 75 Lightbourn Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 2E5, Canada
reviews: Chandos Park North is a Hydro park.  That is a huge hydro tower and line run through the park.   It has some cool features like a paved ball hockey rink, complete with nets.   The park is part of a chain of parks that go cut through Toronto and are green areas that accommodate hydro lines.   A Richard Trus review

This is basically my back yard, so obviously it gets 5 stars!! Just so you know there is a transmission powerlines that runs overtop of this park and there is NO playground. Just grass, trees and a hockey rink. The pathway that runs though these chain parks is nice to walk/jog.
Part of Toronto's ever expanding "greenline" perfect spot for a walk.
Hard to call this small and clean green patch a park, but it is well maintained.
Has a ball hockey section with nets

422.name: Chandos Park South
422.formatted_address: 19 Chandos Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 2E6, Canada
reviews: Nothing very much to Chandos park south other than a trail down the centre.  Winding through the park, or meandering as one might better describe .   It's part of a chain of parks that has hydro towers in it and a trail beneath them.  A Richard Trus review.
Fantastic little park.

423.name: St. Lawrence Market
423.formatted_address: 93 Front St E, Toronto, ON M5E 1C3, Canada
reviews: One of my favourite places in the entire city. A must visit whether you’re a local or a tourist coming in - so full of fresh produce and locally made, high quality goods! An absolute gem of a place, there is something special for everyone.  Come early to beat the morning crowd on Saturday mornings (and to get your first pick of the in-season goods)!!! I will continue to visit this iconic spot whenever I get the chance, especially as opening hours have recently been extended.

Cool place!!! So many options to choose from here. Indoor Venue reminds me of a local farmers market; indoors with 2 floors and with tons of vendors selling everything from meats, cheeses, syrup, seafood, souvenirs, various hot food options, desserts and more. Found a bunch of great options. My family grabbed lunch from various places. Crossed this spot off of our Toronto list. Happy we stopped for the experience.  Note: I recommend more seating/dining options.

Visited the market with a group of 6 on a Thursday afternoon. Walked around and looked at all the inner shops and stands. Mostly fresh produce/fish/ingredients but also a handful of food/meal spots to choose from. We enjoyed a variety of dishes (pizza, oysters, Chinese food, meat pies, and pastries). Very clean and easy to navigate. Loved visiting this adorable market!

All seafood products were worth every penny!! Everything we got was super fresh and yummy as always. Best spot for fresh seafood and the fun atmosphere  They will ship out the fresh seafood to your place for you. It isn't cheap but great quality seafood products and fresh vegetable.  Have shipped it back a few times and love the tiger shrimp and oysters.

This is a must to visit place when in downtown. The have all fresh fruits and vegetables, kitchen accessories, fresh meats and many local items. The space is really clean and organized. You can buy good from there and there are ample seats inside as well as outside the market. The food is of high quality, mostly organic and you can buy it in the amount you want unlike the big packaging in super store. This market is on my list always.

editorial_summary.overview: Spacious market with 100+ vendors, bakers, butchers & artisans, with produce & antiques on weekends.

424.name: Harbourfront Centre
424.formatted_address: 235 Queens Quay W, Toronto, ON M5J 2G8, Canada
reviews: One of the best places to go for a walk on a good day. Breezy and beautiful view of the lake. Perfect for viewing the sunset. Lots of people taking their pets for a stroll, others come for jogging along the lake. You can have a picnic on one of the many benches.

Nice community place. Lots of activities in the evening over the weekend. Excellent place for morning waterfront walk. Lot of nice sitting places... Few nice gardens around... Best place if you like to read books or listen to music with headphones on with a cup of coffee

This place is gorgeous! Right beside the lake, there's plenty park seats with outlet plugs to charge your electric vehicle. My buddies and I come down here with our electric unicycles to enjoy the sunny weather. Fantastic! Stay safe out there people and please be kind to one another!

Perfect place to capture sunset. Awesome feeling and calmness this place brings to your heart. Long walkway along the side of sea, good and clean sitting arrangements. Surrounded with multiple food stalls to fill your appetite on the way. Facilitated with water taxi and wide sight billy bishop airport runway.

I’m coming here to enjoy a lakeside boardwalk (without any board) view. Walking there is considered a good exercise from start to finish. On the one side, you can see a grand view of Lake Ontario. The other is a cityscape of Toronto metropolis. You will never got lost as of the landmark CNTower erected to the sky seen at any spot you are. I plan to visit this place every time I come to Toronto.

editorial_summary.overview: Lakeside cultural hub with dance, modern art, craft & theatre spaces, plus many annual events.

425.name: CN Tower
425.formatted_address: 290 Bremner Blvd, Toronto, ON M5V 3L9, Canada
reviews: Great place for anyone visiting Toronto or even staying here. The rotating restaurant is great. Although you may feel dizzy for a few minutes but the experience is at another level. The food here is probably the best in town, tried different dishes and they were all done to the highest of standards. The staff are very knowledgeable and very friendly. This is a great spot for a birthday, anniversary or any special occasion.

Nice experience. Awesome view of Downtown Toronto, Old Toronto, and Lake Ontario. Can easily spend around 40 minutes including taking videos. Elevator ride is good. Better to arrive before 11 am to beat the rush and always precook the tickets. Or else the lines can stretch to half kilometers

Love the CN tower. One of my favorite touristy spots to show around when friends and family come to visit. Great views of the Lake on one side and the downtown on other side. Also able to view the Billy Bishop airport with planes landing there often. Prefer to go during the night time to soak in the City lights but great views during the day time as well. Would recommend buying tickets online instead of standing in the line there.

Wonderful! I went up the elevator, it takes around a minute to get to the top. A person will tell you a little about the CN Tower on the way. The view from up there is wonderful! The glass floor is extremely cool. It's amazing! I didn't go to the restaurant, but there is a revolving restaurant up there too. The gift shop is great too! Nothing is too overpriced. I would highly recommend it for anyone who loves taking photos or for a weekend activity. There is also a light show every night, which looks extremely cool.

The CN Tower is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Toronto and for good reason. It offers stunning views of the city skyline and is home to many different restaurants and attractions. The tower is also a great place to learn about the history of Toronto and the CN Railway. The first thing you'll notice when you visit the CN Tower is its size. Standing at 553 meters tall, it's the tallest free-standing structure in the Western Hemisphere. The tower also has the world's highest glass floor and is the fifth-tallest building in the world.  Once you take the elevator up to the top of the tower, you'll be treated to stunning views of Toronto and the surrounding area. On a clear day, you can see for over 100 kilometers.  The tower also has a number of different restaurants and cafes, so you can grab a bite to eat while you enjoy the views. If you're interested in learning about the history of the CN Tower, there's a great exhibit at the base of the tower. The exhibit tells the story of how the tower was built and how it has become such an iconic part of Toronto's skyline.  Whether you're looking for stunning views, great food, or a bit of history, the CN Tower is a must-visit when you're in Toronto.

editorial_summary.overview: Landmark, over 553-metre tower featuring a glass floor & a revolving eatery with panoramic views.

426.name: Toronto City Hall
426.formatted_address: 100 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5H 2N2, Canada
reviews: Sep 2022 We were staying at the Sheraton and had great views of City Hall from our room. Quite a modern and unusual shaped building. Found in the square with the large Toronto city sign with lake and fountain. Popular spot with tourists and must be photographed with the sign.

Our Toronto City Hall is in the shape of a UFO!  That alone puts it on the map for a destination location.  Nathan Philip Square boasts the public skating rink in the winter as well as a huge Christmas Tree, which has been a holiday tradition for as long as I can remember.  In the summer the NPS hosts numerous events and on Queen Street you’ll find a vast array of food trucks.  I have attended my best friends wedding at City Hall and when you leave the space ship, well, there are those moments where you feel transported at times.  The Toronto sign along with the Indigenous Wheel and Maple Leaf, those are photo ops waiting to happen.  If you’re visiting Toronto I highly recommend City Hall and Nathan Philip Square for some classic but distinguishable tourist shots and if you live here, same rules apply!  📸🛸🍁

Must Visit if you’re in Toronto! You get the actual city vibe and what Toronto stands for with it’s multiculturalism at it’s centre.  With an ice skating rink, you get to indulge in a winter activities right at the centre. Great open space to just spend time alone or meet friends and family  Ofcourse when you’re here you won’t miss the TORONTO sign!  Enjoy Toronto at it’s finest.
Been to this place for few events and also Christmas. Absolutely gorgeous ❤️❤️❤️❤️

Iconic building which use as symbol of Toronto municipal, known as city hall building.  There is a huge open area outdoor, which is usually people come there for gathering and some official events such as new year, fireworks and etc.  I suggest to visit there and take some selfish by this unit administration building while you are visiting Toronto sightseeing

editorial_summary.overview: Contemporary, iconic structure housing the mayor's office & offering guided tours.

427.name: Hockey Hall of Fame
427.formatted_address: 30 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M5E 1X8, Canada
reviews: Oh it was an amazing experience. Walking around seeing all the great scenes and items hanging on display. The shot the puck and shootout were fun for the family. The main item was walking up the stairs into the great Hall. The presentation of the trophies and all the hall of fame walls was amazing. The staff members that took my family picture with the cup was great to talk to, as he even knew the Windsor area where we were from. He was talking like he still lives there and how he went to University and watched lots of hockey. It was a great way to experience everything.

I had a blast here, such an awesome Hall of Fame and a true honor to hockey. Has the humble beginnings of hockey from back in the 1890’s, and brings it forward to the last Stanley Cup Champions Colorado Avalanche. Tons of history, not just NHL, but Olympics, Women’s, Minor leagues and international leagues. Loved the summit section, such history there. The mask exhibit was cool with a nice shout to Plante for being the first to insist on a mask. Plenty of things for kids too, interactive shootouts and also goaltending drills. Had a wonderful time and for $20 or so a person it’s a superb value. The gift shop at the end is also nice, nothing outrageously priced.

What an amazing display.  Our game is represented in the most amazing way, as is the international game.  Featured 9 & 99 display was super cool... 2 of the very best ever.  If you like hockey... even a little bit... thisbis worth a stop.  You'll need a couple hours though,  it's a BIG display.

What a cool experience for any hockey fan! Amazing displays, plenty of history and memorabilia. Enjoyed the 9 & 99 featured display, two of the best to ever play the game. You can get your photo taken with the Stanley Cup for a small fee.  Interactive games can get quite busy. There's plenty to see for all ages, I'd budget about 2 hours here as there is a lot to see!
Really cool place! I really enjoyed it. First time in Toronto. Great experience if you are a sports fan!  You'll need at least an hour to get through the exhibits.

editorial_summary.overview: A vast collection of hockey memorabilia, including famous gear, interactive games & the Stanley Cup.

428.name: Art Gallery of Ontario
428.formatted_address: 317 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M5T 1G4, Canada
reviews: We went to this museum on a weekday and it was still a little busy but still nice. When you’re below 25, you have to register to an annual pass which is free but still takes up a few minutes. The museum in itself was not really my favorite because it had too much of contemporary art which I’m not so fond of. Otherwise, the floor with the miniature boat collection is really nice and the back stairs (accessible from the third and fourth floors) are worth going to admire the view from there. During our visit, there was a nice temporary exhibition which was really nice and intriguing and it seems like they have a nice set of these temp exhibitions !

Where do I even begin?!  I got to the gallery at 3pm, thinking 2.5hrs would be enough time to finish the exhibit. (The gallery closes at 5:30pm)  Spoiler alert: it wasn’t.  I barely made it through the first floor alone. 😭 will definitely be back though!!  If you can, make a day of it or get the annual pass for an additional $10 (day pass is $25).  In my case, I was only in town for a short visit so didn’t make sense for me to get the annual pass.

A huge 5 level of gallery with amazing arts, models, painting and sculpture by different artists. Every room has a story to tell and one can easily spend an hour just in one section. Make sure to eat well and have ample time with you to visit the gallery. Also, they have a stand where you can keep your coat and bag otherwise if you are carrying a backpack, you have to carry it either on the front or the side but not in the back.  I would recommend to get the tickets online or if you are a member of Toronto Public Library you can avail free passes every Saturday.  Overall, a lovely experience.

Great gallery.  Very pleased at the wide selection of art in the collection, including Canadian art, Indigenous art, and foreign art.  The temporary exhibits are also well done.  It’s also always free for people under 25, which is a great way to get young people involved in the arts!  Tickets should be purchased online in advance even if you are under 25, as you may need to wait for an email confirmation.

I spent approximately four hours in the museum just checking out the ground floor. There were four other levels that I didn't have the time to visit. There's A LOT to see here. It's worth it. Just make sure you have ample time to make the most out of it. There's even a restaurant and a gift shop, so you can pretty much spend most of your day here.

editorial_summary.overview: Large gallery with huge Canadian collection, European masterworks & a major Frank Gehry renovation.

429.name: Nathan Phillips Square
429.formatted_address: 100 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5H 2N1, Canada
reviews: Went on a cold winter evening with my wife. A great place to walk to. I did the first part of my walk above the floor viewing all great buildings in downtown and returned to the go station through THE PATH. A nice place. Loved some pictures near the Toronto sign.

The Toronto City Hall also known as the New City Hall took 4 years to build. It was built on land that was once housed by Toronto's first Chinatown. It looks futuristic, so it appeared in several movies such as Resident Evil.  Our City Hall consists of 2 curve shaped office towers with one of those 2 towers higher than the other by 7 storeys high. At the centre of it is a dome shaped roof. From the sky looking down, it looks like "an unblinking eye."  Right in front is the Nathan Phillips Square, an open place where one can enjoy many free public events like New Year's Eve celebrations, Canada Day's Fireworks, Nuit Blanche, etc. There is a non wading pool off to one side that is converted into a skating rink during the Winter.  One can find the famous LED TORONTO sign here. It was temporarily installed for the 2015 Pan Am Games, because of its popularity amongst the Tourists and the Locals, a permanent one was unveiled to the City in September 2020 during the pandemic. It started off with the City's name, TORONTO, then a 🍁 leaf was added to it in December 2016.  There is a paid underground parking available at this site accessible off Bay Street. There is a public library located inside City Hall with washroom facilities. You can get here too through the underground PATH walking system. The Queen Subway Station is within walking distance to this location, and so is the famous multilevel Eaton Center Mall.  The last 2 photos were taken this month during one of those cultural food venues. The rest of the photos were taken earlier this year in April 2022.

This is a must day trip for the ice skating fan! It will become a once a year tradition for sure.  Ice is always nice and smooth, lots of spots to get ready. You can rent skates or bring your own, parking underneath / underground is always reasonable on the weekend.   The other best part is it’s cloister to shopping and great spots to go for food after.

Nathan Philips Square ...Whatever be the event this place never disappoints ...Every event here is celebrated in a king style...We went here on 26th Dec Night and we totally were aghast with the lights it had decorated with...  The most famous word /letters of the city "Toronto" was shining bright and we didn't leave the chance to click few photos here.  Many kids and youngsters were also skating in the big ring... Decent crowd... With some good food option of coffee and sandwiches to relish on... Some special heart accent lights with heart was a special attraction of this place this time....  Not sure if its still around but if it is...Don't miss a chance....You will love it for sure

A celebration spot or point in downtown Toronto, a nice spot with Toronto sign and signature buildings around it. There is hero burger spot and you will find some food trucks around it. You will feel steep sun rays during summer and will find a skating place in winter. A little garden on one side of square

editorial_summary.overview: Lively public space in front of city hall hosting events year-round & a busy ice rink in the winter.

430.name: Toronto Old City Hall
430.formatted_address: 60 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5H 2M3, Canada
reviews: Nice architecture. Must visit place if you are travelling to Toronto. For best view, visit it’s front side. It looks great at night, especially during summer days and during Christmas lights.
Very cool architecture with a large clock tower.  Sticks out like a sore thumb but that's why it's the old city hall I guess! Had Nuit Blanche events in front of it.

Almost has a mini parliament hill feel to it. The romanesque style makes the building feel heavy when you first look at it. Architectural cohesion isn't Toronto's strong suite so let's just accept that as fact but the variety of styles is something that we might as well cherish. Apparently haunted.
A beautiful place to visit in Toronto downtown. Beat place dor history and architecture lovers
Lovely older building and nice square downtown Toronto.

editorial_summary.overview: Built in 1899, this Richardsonian romanesque civic building showcases a clock tower & gargoyles.

431.name: Toronto's First Post Office
431.formatted_address: 260 Adelaide St E, Toronto, ON M5A 1N1, Canada
reviews: I discovered the first Toronto post office was at the heart of Toronto. The exterior itself was a beautiful architecture and well maintained. At first, it looked like a regular building, but when you go inside you submerged into the 1830's. The place was small, but the best museum to visit. You get to use featured ink pen to write your name and sand it off to dry it, as how people used to do. The staffs were very patience and nice, I got traditional seal wax on my postcards, which were unique. A must go place to explore

It was so peaceful to be visiting the first post office , loved trying to write with feather ink pens ❤️❤️❤️you can write as many and take it away with you . There’s also a small mini shop inside as you enter just opposite to Canada post and as you walk in , there’s a mini museum too ❤️

Visited the post office during OpendoorTO, it was packed. It is a small old post office. You could write messages with ink and take them with yourself. They have beautiful maps of the city of Toronto. It is worth a visit!

was it clean: yes was it efficient: yes was it kind: yes lovely lady wonderfully tackling the tasks all by herself was it straightforward: yes most importantly WAS IT ZEN: yes! Quiet and quaint spot to visit, sit and post mail from the city's first post office!
Great time to visit the First ever Post Office😀✌️

432.name: Mackenzie House
432.formatted_address: 82 Bond St, Toronto, ON M5B 1X2, Canada
reviews: Visited the Mackenzie House today for a workshop on the printing press. The two ladies who gave the presentation shared incredible insight on the history behind the printing press and our first ‘rebel mayor.’ They also guided us through the steps in making our own posters and bookmarks which we were able to take home. Overall, a fun while educational experience for the kids and myself.

Even though the main house is closed due to water damage, the hands on “tour” of the printing press and some of storytelling of the newspapers that William Mackenzie printed and distributed was fun. Vanna did a great job - there were only two of us, so it was essentially a private tour. She also talked about others who printed local newspapers, like Mary Ann Shadd, who has quite a story of her own. It was interesting thinking about the process that used to be used to print and communicate.
The staff are very knowledgeable and accommodating. We had a great time!

As a house museum aficionado, I can say this house is extremely well preserved. The tour guide was excellent and provided a ton of great tidbits. My favorite parts were the textiles and the working interior gas lights!

A small but  interesting museum devoted to publisher and first mayor of Toronto William Lyon Mackenzie. The tour guides were very knowledgeable and passionate. I really love their hands on printing experience. Pro tip for Toronto residents: you can get a free pass to historic sites in Toronto from your local Toronto Public Library. Just ask for the MAP pass.

editorial_summary.overview: 19th-century row house museum dedicated to historic politician & publisher William Lyon Mackenzie.

433.name: Brookfield Place
433.formatted_address: 181 Bay St., Toronto, ON M5J 2T3, Canada
reviews: Beautiful park! Looking forward to Pier 8 development. It is in process. Some maps included :) too bad we can’t swim there.
Great Mall, entrance to Hockey Hall of Fame great visit Delta hockey Academy female U 17 team from British Columbia

Amazing place when you get in. Especially during winter time with the light decorations. Very relaxed atmosphere, despite being crowded sometimes. The "Spirit of Hockey"-store in a must visit for all Hockey fans and there's a Tim Hortons next to it.

The most beautiful and well maintained business block. Staff at concierge is so welcoming and always ready to help.  We often deliver flowers to different businesses. Please check out our website for fresh florals for all occessions. floralsbybushra.ca

An office complex with several floors of office space, two towers (Bay Wellington Tower and TD Canada Trust with a galleria and Hockey Hall of Fame. The Allen Lambert Galleria is an atrium with intricate lattice work and branches that creates a sense of a forest canopy/tree-lined corridor that there's constantly photography happening. The Hockey Hall of Fame also anchors on the northwest corner of Yonge and Front street, which has an entrance in this location. There's also a Tim Hortons for a pit stop as well. A great waiting area to meet up with people as well!

editorial_summary.overview: Modern office tower complex with the Allen Lambert Galleria, a food court & the Hockey Hall of Fame.

434.name: Holy Trinity TO (Church of the Holy Trinity)
434.formatted_address: 19 Trinity Square, Toronto, ON M5G 1B1, Canada
reviews: Small, simple but really lovely and cozy church. I am very lucky attend to Sacrament during my tour visit. It feels me peaceful and touched my heart. Thanks GOD.

Friendly father and sisters. I volunteer there at Christmas Eve as I'm an international student so I have nobody to celebrate christmas with. They perform The Christmas Carol and it's very good, highly recommended. They also sell hot chocolate and cookies before the show.
They are helping many homeless and it's something very important after the COVID period

The Church of the Holy Trinity is an LGBT friendly Anglican church located in the heart of downtown Toronto 's Entertainment District. Established in 1847, this historic landmark is now surrounded by the Toronto Eaton Centre. Today it pays a key role in helping the cities most needy providing services for the urban homeless population. Throughout the early years of the Metropolitan Community Church of Toronto, this church provided this LGBT oriented ministry with a space to worship. This venue plays host to several music, arts and political  events throughout the year. A small Cafe is located on the premises. Definitely a place to visit if your are interested in checking living historic landmarks in the city.
Very nice church.

435.name: Osgoode Hall
435.formatted_address: 130 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M5H 2N5, Canada
reviews: A unique, historical and beautiful location in the heart of Toronto. Features include an architecturally significant building dating back to 1829 and beautiful and tranquil gardens with several areas to sit and take in the surroundings. Large wrought iron fences surround the area and cobblestone drives are a wonderful feature. Large trees offer shade and one would not feel as though they are in the heart of a large metropolitan city.

I can't believe I passed by this beautiful place and never realized what it held inside! This building has a gorgeous library and it's full of paintings of past treasurers, each with their own unique touches! There's a dining hall thats been used for over a hundred years with short little seats because people were tinier back then. Come in for a treasure trove of Canadian law history :)
Beautiful hall anyone can get in. Pretty place for pictures. Has a gorgeous library on laws
Was there two years ago and was interested by the historical and architectural building. Especially the Great Library.

Very beautiful from the outside! The trees are absolutely lovely and the old design and floors were a sight to behold. One of the cooler architecture pieces of Toronto as it was designed more than 100 years ago! Definitely a treat to have explored it during doors open Toronto, as it was a great cultural experience and a fun one too! Definitely recommend!

editorial_summary.overview: Architecturally significant 19th-century building currently housing law offices & courts.

436.name: St Lawrence Hall
436.formatted_address: 157 King St E, Toronto, ON M5C 1G9, Canada
reviews: Went there for the doors open event. The building is well maintained. There were performances in the great hall on the 3rd floor at the time we were there. The visitors were allowed to watch them. The place has an interesting history and significance. I gave an additional star for the volunteers who were very friendly and warm.
Beautifully restored Yesteryears hall. An amazing place to experience art forms nowadays.
Visited this space for the first time this spring as a part of Doors Open Toronto. The history is very interesting and the pink room is stunning!

If you want to see a vintage touch of Toronto then you must visit this Mansion. I was lucky to attend an event there and I was mesmerized with the immense experience I got there when it comes to look and feel of the hall. I did somehow cannot find the exterior picture of the hall and I would surely update when I found or click one asap but all I can say is- beautiful.

The historic plaque in front of the building reads:  St. Lawrence Hall, one of the oldest public buildings in Toronto, was constructed following the Great Fire of 1849 that destroyed a large part of the city's core. Architect William Thomas designed the building in the Renaissance Revival style with Corinthian columns and a domed cupola.  The entrance originally led to a shopping arcade connected to the St. Lawrence Market. The building had shops on the main floor and, on the upper floors, offices and a grand meeting hall used for social events and by prominent speakers, performers, and musicians. Abolitionist Frederick Douglass, Swedish soprano Jenny Lind, and showman P.T. Barnum all appeared in the hall, as did William Lyon Mackenzie, Toronto's first mayor and Upper Canada Rebellion leader.  In the 20th century, St. Lawrence Hall lost prominence and fell into disrepair. By 1965, it was partially derelict and threatened with demolition. A campaign led by architect Eric Arthur resulted in the restoration of the building and its recognition as a National Historic Site in 1967.

editorial_summary.overview: Grand Renaissance Revival meeting hall built in 1850, now used for conferences, events & exhibits.

437.name: Little Trinity Anglican Church
437.formatted_address: 425 King St E, Toronto, ON M5A 1L3, Canada
reviews: We found this to be a vibrant church. It has a liturgical service combined with a good sermon and a strong sense of community. Very encouraging and helpful.  Seems like it would make a good church home.  Also, easy to access by TTC or car.
Wonderfully welcoming! We attend another Anglican Church, with a very traditional approach ... but had heard about "Little T"'s contemporary evening service. We really enjoyed it!

Was visiting this church during open doors Toronto. Thought it was really nice while I was there found out church was celebrating there 176th birthday. Next to the church is a one room school house. The Enoch Turner school built in the 1800s.
Beautiful inside and out.
A historic place that we almost missed. Thanks to the small commemorative stone outside, we appreciated the church's history.

438.name: Daniels Spectrum
438.formatted_address: 585 Dundas St E, Toronto, ON M5A 2B7, Canada
reviews: Not sure what this place is supposed to be. A theatre? A community centre? A rink in Philadelphia? We came here for a "performance" or a "concert". While this place isn't responsible for my bleeding ears, the event lasted two hours. The seats are not comfortable in the slightest. I'm not expecting movie theatre seats or gaming chairs or whatever... But still. The sound was good, a bit loud, but that's the fault of the event organizers. Aside from that, everything was clean. The washrooms were also relatively clean.

Enjoyed the reception and performance at this artist centre.  The local ladies prepared the eats (samosas, kebabs, empanadas), which were delightful and served with a friendly smile.  The performance was also fine, especially the neighbourhood kids' dancing.  Top notch!  Parking is a problem & TTC is erratic.  We got a lift home.  Have had previous dealings with Daniels Corp., which I won't share here.
Amazing space. Went there this past weekend for the Toronto Made Market featuring over 80 vendors. Got myself a mushroom grow kit as a gift and tried some delicious goodies!
Amazing place for any exclusive memorable events

Had a wonderful time at The Toronto Arts Festival,meeting and interacting with new people but as well for the reason for going was to see some Great Fashion and Designers did not disappoint.The 5 day event was Awesome,lots of new designs,some not my cup of tea but interesting none the less. Vanja Vasic organized a fantastic inventful event,just could have had a healthier food option,overall great outing,Cheers!

439.name: Gooderham Building
439.formatted_address: 49 Wellington St E, Toronto, ON M5E 1C9, Canada
reviews: Truly iconic building in Old Toronto. Standing proud in front of downtown giants. Always amazing to see. Particularly in cloudy days. Grab a sandwich at St Lawrence Market an walk towards it on the south side of Front St. A must see!

Finally I made it!! Been here from last 6 years and tried many times to visit but couldn’t. Today I took my son along with me and we had loads of fun in “other” part of Toronto!♥️Bonus was St Lawrence Market but lots of constructions going on and we had to walk a lot due to stroller as the sidewalks were closed
Iconic building in the heart of Toronto. Looks marvelous during sunsets. There's always some sort of construction around this place, the city needs to get it done as soon as possible.
Very beautiful place, I only visited during the day, but next time I come back to Toronto I want to visit at night.
Such picturesque place for taking photos. There's a pub/restaurant at the basement of this building. Looks stunning and so European

editorial_summary.overview: Built in 1892, this redbrick flatiron building features a trompe l'oeil mural & a basement pub.

440.name: St. Patrick's Catholic Church
440.formatted_address: 131 McCaul St, Toronto, ON M5T 1W3, Canada
reviews: Beautiful church near the University Health Network. Very active lay organizations including the Legion of Mary. Home of Praesidium Mother of Perpetual Help.

Best meals, but worst stink bomb smell due to some users not taking bath with clean clothes. Suggest, the church should send them for a shower first at 2:00PM before entering the basement for cozy soup at 4:00PM, then  wonderful meal at 5:00PM, that will be nice and tidy for all users. That's the millennium culture in my mind..
Beautiful church. Great location and staff are very accommodating too💞
I felt soo calm, blessed and wonderful this is the place I go to to get answers to my prayers. I hope St. Anne do answer my prayers this year.

Beautiful mass with inspirational sermon. Sacrament of Reconciliation available before mass. Gift shop with many sacred items such as medals, rosaries. Gift shop open Wednesdays. Priest available after Mass to bless items. Priest also blessed us in the gift shop which was extra special.

441.name: The Power Plant Contemporary Art Gallery
441.formatted_address: 231 Queens Quay W, Toronto, ON M5J 2G8, Canada
reviews: Had an incredible time experiencing the Power Plant's Summer 2022 Exhibition Season! The Mixed media Artworks by Hiwa K in particular were very moving and, eye-opening. Thanks to places like this Contemporary Art Galleries we get glimpses of so much that is beyond our general awareness.

I love coming down here to see the exhibits. It's free and accessible. All located on ground level, you can see fantastic artwork inside and outside. They often rotate, so check online for what is on exhibit.  It's also close to the Harbourfront. You can hit two birds with one stone.  I recommend you come if you can.
I haven't been in the Harbourfront fro a while and I had the impression it is a new art gallery. Crowded because of the Nuit Blanche event.
Small but cool contemporary gallery. Cool to give it a visit as you walk along the waterfront. The entrance is free as well.
We stumbled upon the art gallery by accident & the exhibits were quite different from what I expected. Yet it was eye-opening by works of Hiva K, Paulo Nazareth.

editorial_summary.overview: Industrial-style art gallery featuring avant-garde works, along with an array of programs & events.

442.name: TIFF Bell Lightbox
442.formatted_address: 350 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 3X5, Canada
reviews: I was fortunate enough to attend TIFF..In conversation with Taylor swift! The best thing ever happened to me, I love TayTay & had been waiting from so long to see her & FINALLY❤️ I loved the theatre, audio-visual were on point & made a great experience for attendees.

A not for profit organization that screens more artistic movies than the big budget Hollywood extravaganzas we are used to.  This location has multiple screens for large showings (250 or so) to some smaller theatres that seat 20 viewers.  The staff and volunteers here are very friendly and always look forward to the big September festival that brings a worldwide cast of talent to showcase their goods for all to enjoy

Excellent seating arrangement and ambiance. The sound is amazing, I felt the screen size is a bit smaller compared to the regular Cineplex though . Excellent location at the heart of Toronto's Entertainment District.

The theatre is amazing and has a very nice viewing podium. Therefore even if you are in the front the movie doesn't look so close. The movie selections are really good as movies which don't get released elsewhere are present here. Members also get to watch movies for free too and the price of a ticket is also very affordable as well. Definitely make a trip to watch international acclaim movies without fail.

First time in and loved the ambience and the screening rooms. Quite spacious and friendly ushers to direct you as needed even if it's just getting to the restroom. Not privileged enough to get into the lounge so had to settle for the smaller cafeteria experience. Gift shop offered many TIFF assortment of purchase options and very informative staff. Very clean, well maintained.

editorial_summary.overview: This centre of the Toronto International Film Festival features world cinema & events year-round.

443.name: Rogers Centre
443.formatted_address: 1 Blue Jays Way, Toronto, ON M5V 1J1, Canada
reviews: Just an awesome baseball stadium.   We were here in August 2022 and they opened the roof, which was pretty great.  We had foot long hot dogs and bottomless popcorn.  Doesn't seem to have any bad seats.  If you are there for a day game and they open the roof, I would suggest sitting on the 3rd base side because as the sun sets, it's right in your eyes for a long period of time.  Staff was helpful too.

Rogers Centre is a great place to take in a baseball game. We saw a Sunday 12 noon start and it was a beautiful place to take in a game. We came in from Chicago and Detroit and really enjoyed herself here the club level was a great place to sit. All the amenities were right there where we never had a leave. We were able to eat lunch at a table and step away from our seats. There’s not a bad point of view from anywhere in the stadium!

Went to see the Blue Jays play. Event staff organized, concession stands organized and lines move fast. Got to see the dome open up during a game (see photos). I just wish the fans timed their beer runs better. I missed many pivotal plays because many fans kept blocking my views while they were leaving their seats while players were at bat…..come on guys, get your snacks between innings…!

From an engineering standpoint, this facility is impressive. The concrete looks to be in good shape. The layout is extremely functional. Everything is very easy to find with great wayfinding. Ventilation even with the closed dome is also excellent. However, I do admit it looks and feels very old school (not a bad thing). You don't have the glass exteriors of the new and the overhangs could partially block your view if you get the 200 or 100 seats.  Overall, this is a good time whether you're watching sports, a concert, or something else.

This is one of the most amazing stadium that is always. I enjoyed a lot watching match here, It has super clean seats, friendly and helpful staff  members. Got a lot of food choices here but the main issue is with the price point,the dishes are over priced but as it is a world class stadium so you can't expect food to be cheap. The legroom between the seats is decent enough and the seats are also well maintained here. Overall it's a good experience watching a match here.

editorial_summary.overview: Home of baseball's Toronto Blue Jays, this stadium features a retractable roof & hosts concerts.

444.name: Canadian National Exhibition
444.formatted_address: 210 Princes' Blvd, Toronto, ON M6K 3C3, Canada
reviews: After a two year hiatus because of the pandemic, The Ex is back! Of course, there is the strike of safety inspectors currently. As a result, out of an abundance of caution, we skipped the rides this year. Well, our five year old daughter is much too young for most of these rides anyway. The prices in the food building are outrageous. With inflation on a high, this was expected going in. We spent $56 on food and, as a group, we feel we didn't eat enough. Shopping wise, many merchants handle contactless payments. Some even accept American Express. Only a few accept cash only. Which is kind of silly as I am completely cashless and wallet-less. I'm sure I'm not the only one. Overall, a fun place to spend the day.

Came on Tuesday during the day til 8pm. Was a normal amount of busy. Not too crazy but exactly what you would expect. We went on around 6 rides. Tips: - 10” mozzarella stick is at Deep Fried in the food building. Beware they may not cook it enough and it will not be melted cheese. - Smash burger at The Gourmet Grill is dry. Has too much bun. - bring water bottle around to fill up at stations - get ride all day pass from someone that works at a corporate company for $20

Going to the CNE each year has been a staple in our family for many many years. I have enjoyed it every single year since I was a child and now my children love it as well. It is the highlight of the summer and was dearly missed during the last two years during the pandemic. This year was absolutely phenomenal with record turnouts and phenomenal food! Highly recommend could not say enough good about it! Love it love it love it!

Overall it was good experience!  The event usually occurs couple of weeks before labour day and ends on Labour day. The place accessible via Public Transport, its right in-front of Exhibition Go station/ Tram station.  There is admission fee for adults and Kids above 5. Event is so colourful with plenty of gameshows and wide variety of food stalls around.There are lots of amusement rides , like giant wheel, rope way, Air Show (time specific)as you move along,  It’s a little pricey at the end but good experience towards end of summer season.

This is definitely the one of must try in Toronto , especially if you want to take out the family. Great place to visit and enjoy the rides and games outside, I personally love the international pavilion where you can absolutely find anything from any country. It’s great for shoppers who seek to find a special gifts and more…

editorial_summary.overview: 192-acre complex for soccer, hockey & equestrian events, concerts & festivals, plus dining options.

445.name: Art Gallery of Ontario
445.formatted_address: 317 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M5T 1G4, Canada
reviews: We went to this museum on a weekday and it was still a little busy but still nice. When you’re below 25, you have to register to an annual pass which is free but still takes up a few minutes. The museum in itself was not really my favorite because it had too much of contemporary art which I’m not so fond of. Otherwise, the floor with the miniature boat collection is really nice and the back stairs (accessible from the third and fourth floors) are worth going to admire the view from there. During our visit, there was a nice temporary exhibition which was really nice and intriguing and it seems like they have a nice set of these temp exhibitions !

Where do I even begin?!  I got to the gallery at 3pm, thinking 2.5hrs would be enough time to finish the exhibit. (The gallery closes at 5:30pm)  Spoiler alert: it wasn’t.  I barely made it through the first floor alone. 😭 will definitely be back though!!  If you can, make a day of it or get the annual pass for an additional $10 (day pass is $25).  In my case, I was only in town for a short visit so didn’t make sense for me to get the annual pass.

A huge 5 level of gallery with amazing arts, models, painting and sculpture by different artists. Every room has a story to tell and one can easily spend an hour just in one section. Make sure to eat well and have ample time with you to visit the gallery. Also, they have a stand where you can keep your coat and bag otherwise if you are carrying a backpack, you have to carry it either on the front or the side but not in the back.  I would recommend to get the tickets online or if you are a member of Toronto Public Library you can avail free passes every Saturday.  Overall, a lovely experience.

Great gallery.  Very pleased at the wide selection of art in the collection, including Canadian art, Indigenous art, and foreign art.  The temporary exhibits are also well done.  It’s also always free for people under 25, which is a great way to get young people involved in the arts!  Tickets should be purchased online in advance even if you are under 25, as you may need to wait for an email confirmation.

I spent approximately four hours in the museum just checking out the ground floor. There were four other levels that I didn't have the time to visit. There's A LOT to see here. It's worth it. Just make sure you have ample time to make the most out of it. There's even a restaurant and a gift shop, so you can pretty much spend most of your day here.

editorial_summary.overview: Large gallery with huge Canadian collection, European masterworks & a major Frank Gehry renovation.

446.name: Medieval Times Dinner & Tournament
446.formatted_address: 10 Dufferin St, Toronto, ON M6K 3C3, Canada
reviews: I absolutely LOVE Medieval times, I've been there 3 times. Each time, I was lucky enough to try a different meal since I only had vegetarian option in the past, but they have expanded their menu, and cater to special dietary restrictions now. That being said, I don't go for the food, so I can't comment much on it. I love the garlic bread, and the tomato bisque soup is better than any restaurant tomato soup I have ever had!  The show is SPECTACULAR! I will keep going back if I am able to, there's always a new story plot, I love the horses, and knights. Overall, its a wonderful experience! The servers are super nice, friendly, and hardworking, really appreciate the kindness and enthusiasm from everyone at the castle!

A fun family event. It was well organized and a good pace. The full course dinner was quite good. They had vegetarian and gluten free options too. The portion size could be a bit smaller especially for the kids. They did give a take home bag at the end so that helped. Both adults and kids alike had fun.

It is a wonderful show, far more fun than the expectation.  It takes you back to medieval time and you would feel you were living in hundreds of years ago. The food are also very good especially the medieval soup. I’d suggest to provide half size of the children meal. It is good but too much.

Went there for today's 1:30 show. Absolutely amazing time. My child and I had a blast. So much fun, staff is great, and the atmosphere is really convincing. Clean facilities, lots of open space, and very clean overall. The entertainment was fabulous, and all the actors were amazing at their roles. Will definitely be returning.

A fun time for families & people of ALL AGES. Far more fun than I was expecting, brought me right back to childhood memories. The garlic bread & corn was quite good, entertainment was AMAZING & the actors were great with their roles. Highly recommend this experience for every child & too return as an adult has the same joyful feeling.

editorial_summary.overview: Jousting, horsemanship & falconry plus a 4-course, utensil-free meal served in a castle-like space.

447.name: The Toronto Inukshuk Park
447.formatted_address: 789 Lake Shore Blvd W, Toronto, ON M5V 3T7, Canada
reviews: This is not really a park. There is an inukshuk here and green space. Maybe some seating options if you sit on the rocks. This "park" is more of a connection between Coronation Park and Trillium Park. There is also a path to take you to the trail that runs alongside Lake Shore Blvd West.

If you are looking for a park with a playground, this is not the place to go. However, it does have a very large and cool looking Inukshuk for photos. The stones around the Inukshuk are engraved, which provides additional information. I suggest walking the waterfront trail.
A nice park for walking / biking while enjoying the Toronto skyline views. Cool place to take some photographs as well. The inukshuk here is known to be one of the largest of its kind.
Beautiful lake views and nice points to take pictures.

If you travel around northern #Canada, #Alaska, or even #Greenland, you may spot large rock formations towering over the landscape, resembling the shape of a person with arms stretching out. They are called #Inukshuk.  Inukshuk, a structure made of stones piled on top of each other, was used for navigation in the frozen north where, in the snow of Tundra, everything could look the same.  Peoples of the #Arctic use them to mark hunting grounds for #caribou, #seal, #walrus, #whale or landing sites for boats and kayaks or to warn travellers of dangerous currents beneath the ice.  #Inuksuit are also sacred to the #native peoples. Many #Inuit retain strong attachments to inuksuit believed to have been built by their ancestors. Evidence shows this tradition is as old as 9000 years.  And, some of these landmarks have been standing for 2000 years.  Traditionally constructed by the Inuit, Inuksuit are often intertwined with representations of Canada and #theNorth.  #Indigenous #NativeAmerican #Iñupiat, #Kalaallit, #Yupik,  #NorthernCanada, #Greenland, #Alaska #Inunnguaq #Tundra

448.name: Princes' Gates
448.formatted_address: 11 Princes' Blvd, Toronto, ON M6K 3C3, Canada
reviews: Beautiful landmark with space to sit and relax. You can also take some really nice photos as this is a rather unique landmark for Toronto. History enthusiasts should definitely pay a visit. There’s a lovely park just 5 mins walk from here with beautiful lake views.

Princes' Gates is the iconic entrance to the Canadian National Exhibition.  We can see the angel at the very top of the gate,there are other pillars on each side it is sign of other province.  It’s very nice to go with family, friends and other loved one ☺️

We visited the CNE 2022 located at this place. Overall good, the place maintained good. Place is located right beside to the exhibition GO station. There is tram station as well located right infront, so accessibility wise its all good. ( Can’t comment on parking as I used public transport)

The Princes' Gates is a triumphal arch and a monumental gateway at Exhibition Place in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Made out of cement and stone, the triumphal arch is flanked by colonnades on both of its sides, with curved pylons at both ends. The 350-foot-long (110 m) structure serves as the eastern gateway to the Canadian National Exhibition, an annual agricultural and provincial fair held at Exhibition Place.

2022CNE it was quiet when we arrived approximately 12noon by 8pm it was packed. Bring cash all games are $10 each to play. Food is expensive and a number of vendors take cash only. All being said it's a tradition

449.name: Coronation Park
449.formatted_address: 711 Lake Shore Blvd W, Toronto, ON M5V 3T7, Canada
reviews: In the heart of Downtown Toronto, this amazing patch of green brings a breath of cool fresh air to all residents and visitors. You can play, walk, sit and relax, picnic with friends and family. It offers the shade of beautiful old trees and soft grass below your feet. Enjoy the best of nature close to home.

Very interesting history of this park, apparently it's on the reclaimed land when the workers didn't have had any work.. Trees are also planted by veteran's and it has memorials too.. a good place and a good combination of lake front, baseball ground, cycle tracks and so on.

Beautiful park! Many amazing views of the city skyline. Very family friendly and a great spot to do an evening stroll and unwind. Always very clean and well cared for as well. Make sure you do the whole trail around the cinesphere. Tons to see!
So many beautiful mature Oak trees for shade. Lots of Sun too. I do my yoga here. Clean washrooms nearby. Lots of personal space in a public park.
Great place for a morning run. Calm and serene. View of the lake and the yachts/ small boats along the harbour line is great.

editorial_summary.overview: Lakefront park & picnic spot featuring multiple baseball diamonds & an off-leash dog area.

450.name: TIFF Bell Lightbox
450.formatted_address: 350 King St W, Toronto, ON M5V 3X5, Canada
reviews: I was fortunate enough to attend TIFF..In conversation with Taylor swift! The best thing ever happened to me, I love TayTay & had been waiting from so long to see her & FINALLY❤️ I loved the theatre, audio-visual were on point & made a great experience for attendees.

A not for profit organization that screens more artistic movies than the big budget Hollywood extravaganzas we are used to.  This location has multiple screens for large showings (250 or so) to some smaller theatres that seat 20 viewers.  The staff and volunteers here are very friendly and always look forward to the big September festival that brings a worldwide cast of talent to showcase their goods for all to enjoy

Excellent seating arrangement and ambiance. The sound is amazing, I felt the screen size is a bit smaller compared to the regular Cineplex though . Excellent location at the heart of Toronto's Entertainment District.

The theatre is amazing and has a very nice viewing podium. Therefore even if you are in the front the movie doesn't look so close. The movie selections are really good as movies which don't get released elsewhere are present here. Members also get to watch movies for free too and the price of a ticket is also very affordable as well. Definitely make a trip to watch international acclaim movies without fail.

First time in and loved the ambience and the screening rooms. Quite spacious and friendly ushers to direct you as needed even if it's just getting to the restroom. Not privileged enough to get into the lounge so had to settle for the smaller cafeteria experience. Gift shop offered many TIFF assortment of purchase options and very informative staff. Very clean, well maintained.

editorial_summary.overview: This centre of the Toronto International Film Festival features world cinema & events year-round.

451.name: Iglesia Católica San Juan Bautista
451.formatted_address: 941 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M6J 1W4, Canada
reviews: Great place to pray
Nice church, not to much parking spot, they speaks English and Spanish
A place of worship for Hispanics Roman Catholics
how can any church be bad ... but great awesome priest and Spanish interaction.
My favorite church

452.name: Kensington Market BIA
452.formatted_address: 160 Baldwin St, Toronto, ON M5T 3K7, Canada
reviews: Visiting from Vancouver. Kensington Market and Murals was on our list of places to see. Kensington Market is right besides Chinatown. Great area to walk around around and check out the little shops and restaurants.  Different types of foods for everyone.  The murals were great to see. We were glad to have found the area.  If you're visiting Toronto, this should be a destination spot to walk around and eat.

Kensington market is a unique experience in the metropolitan city of Toronto. With its vintage and art stops, fine dining cuisine from around the world, it's a must-visit spot for all ages. Some very unique products can be seen in some of the stores. Very colorful and vibrant and quite busy. Best to be visited on foot. Some of my favorite stores are Dancing Days and Courage my Love. The only downside is that it is not too clean.

A fantastic eclectic collection of stores, shops and stalls carrying everything you could ever need can be found in the market area. The diverse cultural mapping of nation stores selling makes it a must go to area.
Had a great time walking through the shops,  restaurants, eclectic art and street art!!
The most fun there with my family doing shopping and entertaining.

editorial_summary.overview: Long-standing, colourful market area for independent shops/cafes, plus produce, meat & fish stands.

453.name: Trinity Bellwoods Park
453.formatted_address: 790 Queen St W, Toronto, ON M6J 1G3, Canada
reviews: Spacious park with plenty of greenspace, a baseball diamond, 8 public tennis courts, and splash pad. Public toilets available but are quite dirty and run down. However, great park overall to lounge in the sun or shade. Often will find merchants selling picnic blankets and other second hand items. Plenty of cycling room.

Had the most amazing time here. So many people were with family having a picnic, some were dancing with friends. Beautiful sakura flowers/cherry blossoms at this time of the year but the highlight was the sunset at the dog's pit. Nearby places for coffee and food are really great too.

One of the best and the biggest park in Downtown. This is a good time to go the park to enjoy some cherry blossoms. The park also has tennis court, skate boarding space and some beautiful views. It is also a great place for picnic.
The park is vibrant and clean.  There is a diversity of people and of activities you can do there.  I go the for tennis, the courts are well maintained.

Nice place to chill out in Toronto, but crowded on weekends. I dint got much time to explore the whole park but you can still find good decent place to hang around with friends and enjoy your weekend with peace. Dogs are allowed and be careful if you don't like them bcoz there will be always around with owners. A good picnic stop within the town. Parking is paid on streets and if you take a trnaist do not take form Ossinigton since it's crowded on weekends and frequent is very bad. You may need to walk to nearest station that is whatbi did Fter waiting for a bus for almost 1/2hr

editorial_summary.overview: Spacious park with volleyball & tennis courts, an outdoor skating rink & indoor recreation centre.

454.name: Liberty Village Park
454.formatted_address: 70 E Liberty St, Toronto, ON M6K 3K7, Canada
reviews: A much needed break from the surrounding condominium farm. It's a nice little park. Usually many dogs, as it has a wide open area. Nice spot for kids to run around too. Many amenities nearby.
Good place tô go with children and dogs
30 Year Inglis reunion. A group of people stood in the rain for a photo. It was a great time!
Great little park.  There’s a geocache there too if you can find it.
Liberty village is beatifull full off restaurant  shopping fresh Brad its beatifull

455.name: Koffler Centre of the Arts
455.formatted_address: 180 Shaw St, Toronto, ON M6J 2W5, Canada
reviews: Lovely gallery and work spaces which offshoots Queen West. The renovated school house still has an odd elementary school feel but focused on enterprising young individuals working in this space. Hallways was fill with works and the ground floor has a nice view overlooking towards Trinity Bellwoods.
What can i say about Koffler Centre of the Arts, located in the heart of the city of Toronto Canada. This place is very nice and had a good experience, would recommend.
Very knowledgable docents in a building that was a school now re-purposed
The meaure of things is beautiful.

456.name: Ireland Park Foundation
456.formatted_address: The Corleck Building, 3 Eireann Quay, Toronto, ON M5V 0R, Canada

457.name: Toronto Music Garden
457.formatted_address: 479 Queens Quay W, Toronto, ON M5V 3M8, Canada
reviews: Beautiful garden at the core of the waterfront along the banks of Lake Ontario. It's got exhilaration boardwalks and trails accessible throughout the day/night/year. The summers are amazing with live music played. Good for family friends and your pet to walk and relax. Accessible by walking and street cars. I would highly recommend this place to relax and have fun.

The garden is a good place for family. Can see Toronto Harbour front. A short walk with family or friends to enjoy the flowers and tress. You may see guitarist singing songs so you can relax to enjoy the performance. Flowers blooming hence can take nice photos

Picturesque gardens by the waterfront create a gorgeous backdrop for this casual amphitheatre that both music and nature lovers alike can fully appreciate. Kid- and pet- friendly.
