Take a blanket to stretch out on the sun-soaked lawns or under the tree canopy of your choosing. Times are listed for performances but check in advance so you don't miss great local talent. (Visited during Summer, August).

I spend my summers down here. Sitting by the docks bring me a sense of calm. When I listen to concerts in the park, presented by Harborfront, in truly is my happy place. I am so glad summer concerts are back! These truly save my sanity!
A small and lush green park to spend time on a sunny day. There was some ceremony going on as well as the top of amphitheatre. Maybe you can reserve/book the spot.

editorial_summary.overview: Yo Yo Ma contributed to the design of this scenic garden with summer concerts & seasonal tours.

458.name: John B. Aird Gallery
458.formatted_address: 906 Queen St W Unit B05, Toronto, ON M6J 1G6, Canada
reviews: The current show by Ilene Sova is a super show managing to be thoughtful, dazzling & summer-like all at once. The Aird Gallery shows are always worth catching. Curator Carla Garnet is doing a great job

Small art gallery inside government building on corner of Bay and Wellesley. Exhibits change monthly. Good for cold winter lunch time visit. Always interesting. Wheelchair ramp. Bright space. Volunteers answer questions.
This gallery is so spacious that their exhibitions show well. Their shows reflect the diversity of the artistic community of the GTA.
A splendid gallery. Only problem it's in s government building  under going construction for refitting. It's also closed on weekends.
Still waiting for the payment of an artwork that they sold over 6 month ago. No phone contact, no answer to any emails inbetween...

459.name: Clarence Square
459.formatted_address: 25 Clarence Square, Toronto, ON M5V 1H1, Canada
reviews: The park itself is nice. But unfortunately it’s full of tents now. Lots of litter, and people screaming and fighting eachother. Best to avoid after sunset.
It’s a tented homeless encampment where there are a lot of people with serious mental health issues .
So sad to see this park not being maintained properly and now become a place to not to be at. Had fond memories with my kid playing all around which is all now been taken over by tents such a shame.

Nice little park in downtown Toronto. 30% of the park is an enclosed dog park. Very popular with dogs. On a warm sunny afternoon, its great to sit on the bench near the central water fountain and people watch. Many people grab a beer or two from the next door LCBO and chat with friends after work. The grass is not well kept, but is acceptable. There are often sketchy homeless people drinking in this park, but they are pretty harmless.
My dog hates it here. It’s probably the ice cold people and poorly socialised dogs. But hey, it’s a leash free dog park, so that’s something.

editorial_summary.overview: Small tree-shaded urban park with a central cherub-topped fountain, an off-leash dog area & benches.

460.name: Margaret Fairley Park
460.formatted_address: 100 Brunswick Ave, Toronto, ON M5S 2L7, Canada
reviews: This is a very unusual wooded park, tucked in a quiet residential area. Though it is a small park, it has many interesting features. A fountain with a large play area, a chess board table, many benches and an interesting sculpture dedicated to a local community member who had helped the people in the area in many ways. The park is named after her.
The kids really enjoyed the splash pad and sandbox with water spout. The very clean porta potty was extremely helpful. Nice to have trees providing shade from the sunshine.
Pretty good... But small...  Handy for those that live nearby...  Gets a lot of wear and tear.... Has fun water tap and sand pit .. tiny splash pad and sprinklers often broken...  Overall nice park
Nice park, great for kids and very pretty design. I especially like the wooden log seats. It's way too small for walking though.
Nice place for kids to play in the neighbourhood! Low speed limits, one way streets! Really safe  Thanks Margaret for this gift.

461.name: Rogers Centre Parking
461.formatted_address: 305 Bremner Blvd, Toronto, ON M5V 2T6, Canada
reviews: I go there maybe once a year for a game. It is the only place to see baseball. The main (bad) thing is getting there. There is a very long 15 minutes walk from Union subway. And if you don't exit the same gate that leads you back to Union subway station you can be out onto Bathurst street. The street at the exits are not clearly marked, for night time. And if you drive, the parking is $25+, and the traffic is so bad around there. The seats are so small and levels are extremely steep. There is much garbage under people's seat. The food is extremely pricey. I guess it is normal. I don't normally buy much except water ($5,6).

Event rate is outrageous, absolutely no need to charge so much money to have someone Park their car. Especially in a place where the lanes are barely wide enough for one car let alone two. As well, there is construction so they have closed off many parts of the different levels, yet continue to charge the outrageous $35 price to park there. Other than being convenient to get to the jays game, this is a rip off, you should find somewhere else to park, even if the daily rate is reasonable just based on principle alone.
Nice place but there was a kind of annoying baseball game on.

Traffic is absolutely insane after anything held here, to make it worse the people who drive dont deserve their license these losers act like they're isnt a traffic rule cause cops aren't around, make it incredibly hard for anyone to get out, police escorts that watch as lane cut offs allow ppl to ruin traffic. It was the worst driving experience ever.

Same old thing Lack of security of  line jumpers outside gate 5 and all othe gates. They all go inside 15 before the gates open to work inside. They need more guards . Don't need to loose yourself before a expensive game .

462.name: George Brown House
462.formatted_address: 186 Beverley St, Toronto, ON M5T 1L4, Canada
reviews: Beautiful building. Cool history.
Not much to see here in comparison to other museums like Mackenzie House

It's a historical house yes, but most of the house is actually office space or an escape room game. There are two rooms downstairs, a rendition of George Brown's office/library and the dining room. It was not really what I expected when visiting the house. I expected more of a museum feel to it.

The George Brown House was absolutely perfect for the wedding ceremony, giving us a beautifully decorated and cost friendly intimate space that still let us have our dream Victorian-themed wedding. The venue managers were very professional, quick to reply, and worked closely with us almost on a weekly basis to answer our hundreds of questions and ensure that our day would go as we planned. Being a national heritage venue does mean that there are several restrictions (e.g. limited candle usage, no confetti/rice, etc.), but these were things we could easily negotiate solutions to. Even on the day of, venue staff worked hand in hand with our wedding party to ensure a smooth rundown.
Went here for an escape room, it is by far one of my favorites because of how immersive and innovative the puzzles were!

463.name: High Park
463.formatted_address: 1873 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6R 2Z3, Canada
reviews: Very nice park! One of the best free park that I have ever seen. Especially during cherry blossom season! People is packed during weekends so better go during weekdays to appreciate the nature and peacefulness of the place. It does not feel that it was situated inside a city. Finding a place to park your car near the park is kinda difficult, we have to park near the lake and walk which is okay since the weather is good. We will definitely go back! You also have to walk to find restaurants

It may be the best park in Toronto! It's suitable for hiking or walking dogs in summer, and there are many facilities and trails to choose from. There are a zoo, nature trails, and a dog walks area, a swimming pool, a tennis court, playgrounds, and many trees! There are a lot of parking spaces here and many shared bicycles to rent. It is also convenient to have a subway station next to the park. We visited this park for the first time and had a great afternoon here.

High park is my favourite part of Toronto especially when you want surround yourself with nature without getting out Toronto. Fall is so stunning here. There are lots of small trains for a easy hike in the park. And btw, this park is huge, with a beautiful lake with swans and ducks. Must visit if you are a tourist, or looking to go for a trail run or just to spend some peaceful time in nature. Heads-up: weekend can be busy, especially in summers and everyone is here taking lots of pictures.

It’s beautiful. Very nice place to hangout with friends, family or alone if you like. You can see various types of bird, goose, swans. On top you will find parking, washroom, food place for convenience (not sure if they are open around the year). Rent a bicycle or walk around to see beautiful nature. Only issue I would say it’s busy sometime

It's a huge park, very beautiful and great for a lot of activities. Parking inside is closed during weekends, nearby street parking is usually full and finding a spot becomes bit of a hassle sometimes and has 3 hours limit. But once you get inside, it's great for spending time with family in a beautiful natrual serene environment. Great for a walk, cycling, picnic with friends and family, there's also a free zoo where kids enjoy watching and interacting with the animals. It's specially beautiful during the cherry blossom season and offers great spots for taking beautiful pictures. The play area is also great for kids of all ages. Overall it's one of the best parks in the city!

editorial_summary.overview: Sprawling park with hiking trails, a zoo, sports fields & a large children's playground.

464.name: High Park Nature Centre
464.formatted_address: 375 Colborne Lodge Dr, Toronto, ON M6R 2Z3, Canada
reviews: A wonderful place to relax or to spend a nice day with the family. A well-developed network of paths and varied views of flora and fauna. A lake, a small animal park and of course
My son attended the High Park Nature Centre program for youths and he had an absolute blast! Informative and helpful instructors, friendly participants, lots of good outdoors time!

High Park is a true treasure.  The skating rink is great, hockey and leisure skate areas.  The playgrounds are fantastic, the zoo is great and the food is cheap and delicious.  I could spend days strolling around exploring and enjoying the nature and wildlife.  Beautiful place.

So relaxing. Lived in Toronto my whole life and dicided to go for a bike ride and walk through High Park. I saw so much wildlife and nature that I'm not used to seeing. Lakeshore was close enough to go biking too.
Such an amazing beautiful park in downtown Toronto , can visit all year round.

465.name: High Park Zoo
reviews: I like the fact that it is free to enter. There are donation bins set up if you choose to donate. Not all animals are out during thr fall and winter but there is definitely enough to have a good time and see some cool creatures. I also really liked the info graphics about each animal. You can learn some interesting facts. And I appreciate that dogs are allowed to enter.

Love coming here with my son. My parents used to take me when I was growing up. Loved just being close to the animals. A nice long walk through the trails. Sit down for lunch. Good place to have a day in nature.

High park Zoo has a good collection of animals. Since the weather was nice, a lot of the animals were outside their barns.  If you are visiting on a weekend, the parking within High park is closed and you have to park on the street outside and walk all the way in.

Really surprised that there's a free zoo in the middle of high park. We saw llamas, deer and mountain goat. For a second I thought the mountain goat was a statue until it moved its head. I was so pleasantly surprised and then realized that the mountain goat was true to it's name - it climbed the top of the little wooden shed. Wish they had more animals. A beautiful spot to visit in the fall!
An adorable little zoo tucked away in High Park! I will definitely be back to see the capybaras as they were not out the day I went. Lots of benches and picnic tables to relax and watch the animals!

editorial_summary.overview: Fenced-off grassy areas for animals like capybaras & bison, plus llamas & rabbits kids can pet.

466.name: High Park Children’s Garden & Teaching Kitchen
466.formatted_address: 1873 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6R 2Z3, Canada
reviews: Newly created area for children activity & learning . When we visited it was closed . Taken picture from outside. Nice place though. I would like to revisit with my child during spring time. Nice picnic area available near by. Parking available as well. It’s free of cost entry.
Very nice park in heart of GTA
Was here for a Kid's birthday. Great venue, crafts and gardening and learning for kids.
Beautiful park. Clean and well maintained, lovely trails and very popular for cherry blossom season. Excellent selfie location.
Nice huge park but could be better not that much thinks to do .Could be made more family places kids playgrounds parking space, huge lake with could be made some thing in .

467.name: Colborne Lodge
467.formatted_address: 11 Colborne Lodge Dr, Toronto, ON M6R, Canada
reviews: Free to visit during May, which is Museum Month. You must show your City of Toronto public library card.
This place was amazing you learn so much and the tour guide Megan seemed so knowledgeable about what she was saying!
Small tour, but worth it. Important fact: High Park is dry! Wow... who knew?

$30 for a family of 5. Guided tour of the Colbough Lodge which this home and owners owned this land. History of how High Park was  made. Apple cider and cookies provided to kids. Then had a long walk to park and the animals. Fresh air. Exercise . Great day

High park has every that most park don't,it has many natural paths in the woods tennis 🎾 swimming, a zoo and more. You won't be disappointed visiting the park, it runs as far from Bloor st to the south at the lake shore, take in the beautiful landscape, this is a 5 🌟!!!

editorial_summary.overview: An 1837 Regency-style cottage topped by a triple chimney, with period furniture & a picture gallery.

468.name: Sunnyside Bike Park Bikes
468.formatted_address: Ellis Ave, Toronto, ON M6S 2X1, Canada
reviews: Awesome bike part a great variety of features to try out. Great increase in jumps and drops difficulties starting from beginner to advanced. Two fun pump tracks and a fun variable skinnies section

Could be a good park. now it's just rutted and eroding. No maintenance and can be very hazardous. Need someone with true knowledge of how to build a dirt track. Hopefully they fix the place and come up with a better setup to allow drainage.
A fun place for mountain bikes. Nice assortment of Berms, Jill's, and assorted features that you would find on an off road trail. A great place for practicing....

Sunnyside dirt park neglected mess! Ride at your own risk! Good job city of Toronto.. Deep ridges on takeoff and landing rotted wood features and no volunteer days to support. This is not a good example of what a dirt park should be.. DOA

Somewhat maintained (Grass gets cut). However rain erosion is slowly killing roll in features.  On dry days sand gets very fine and packs shoe tread and some tyres, causing slipping. It can also get blown around causing a breathing hazard. The location of this park is between two highways and next to a train track, the air quality is terrible for kids. The dirt pumptrack is non-functional. The woodent pump track is a great feature for all ages to learn on. No bathrooms. Has a drinking fountain.

469.name: Sunnyside Park
reviews: It was a busy Saturday morning, the weather was good. Went from the Sunnyside Pavilion , cross the Humber Bay Arc Bridge, stopped at the Sheldon Lookout, to the Palace Pier and back. It was about 6km. The lake view was beautiful. The temperature was pleasant. Paid parking spaces were plentiful. There were public washrooms along the path.
Great place for a walk or a bike ride, can be nosy if there is traffic.
Beautiful park in particular summer time is amazing around here. The vibe, hanging out, plenty of activities and exercise. Youth and families having party and BBQ. A nice refresh from the lake draft.
Beautiful views calm place to hang around and get some nice tanning, just try not to go into the water.
Walk west of the park for quieter scenery, no life guards, enjoy the sailboats to bird watch PS perfect place to launch canoes 🛶 or kayaks

editorial_summary.overview: Lakefront park & picnic spot with a beach, playground, cycling trails & boardwalk.

470.name: West Lodge Park
470.formatted_address: 165 Lansdowne Ave, Toronto, ON M6K 2W1, Canada
reviews: Nice little park with a community garden and a small skate park.
Nice during the week to hang out play Frisbee and picnic on weekends nice for the children
Nice place to chill lookout for the junkies tho
It's OK small great for doing a few runs but could use a little ledges
Nice park. Just need lot of patience to ignore ill-mannered people who passes through park to other street. Seriously who smokes in kids play area

471.name: MacGregor Playground
471.formatted_address: 346 Lansdowne Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 3Y1, Canada
reviews: This is a great park for family's! Not so much for fur babies. This area is not dog friendly although I do break the rules lol

The red clay field is awesome to play on but the batter's box needs work; please note wood bats only at this location! Dog friendly place to socialize with nice grass to play, secluded shady areas available. Clean washrooms and the splashpad is so cool on a hot day. Love the train that pulls by every so often adding to ambience of Toronto. Quiet spot among the noise.
Field, track,  baseball diamond,  play structures, new splash pads, washrooms,  shade, Adirondack chairs, picnic bench, parking on street or behind school. Great place to spend hours
Great park for the kids to attend the splash pad!! My kid loved it. Ice cream truck goes by it frequently.

Such a great park! The splash pad is top. And there is a little park for the kids to play in after they’re done splashing around. There is usually free street side parking along the street. Must most importantly there are bathrooms which are relatively clean all things considered.

472.name: Museum of Contemporary Art Toronto Canada
472.formatted_address: 158 Sterling Rd #100, Toronto, ON M6R 2B7, Canada
reviews: Free Ground Floor entry and very reasonable pricing for paid exhibitions on 1st and 2nd floors. A wonderful space, with great original features (those concrete pillars!) And the most sumptuous cafe for pre or post treats.

Great space with contemporary art in a wide range of mediums. The current exhibit has some painting, photography, and sculpture but also includes works which utilize mixed media and interactivity. The museum occupies several floors and I recommend taking the stairs if you can.  There's a restaurant on the main floor but there is also a brewery and a coffee roastery nearby.

MOCA brings regularly rotated contemporary artists from all over the world and brings them to this gorgeous and spacious building! At the moment, there typically is only 3 floors and less than 5 exhibits/artists being featured, but its always awesome and thought provoking works of art! Every first Sunday of the month is free, sponsored by TD, so consider coming on one of those days.  MOCA has come a long way from their small gallery space on Queen West years ago, so we need to celebrate what they have been able to offer and make use of this beautiful space ❤️
Best place to spend Friday afternoon 🤩 This location has three floors of Contemporary Art. I would advise you to visit the Shirin Neshat exhibition while it is still ongoing (until July 31 2022)

A nice place to visit. One thing to note before going to the Museum of Contemporary Art Toronto is to review their website for the particular exhibition or display that is going on in the week you want to visit else you will be surprised by what you see compared to the art posted by reviewers. For example, during the day I visited, it was the exhibition of THOMAS DEMAND HOUSE OF CARD & MARTIN BOYCE, RIRKRIT TIRAVANIA, CARUSO STJOHN , and this is to run through December 2022. And so if you visit in February, you may not see any of these things.

editorial_summary.overview: Modern works by new & established artists are on display at this leading international art gallery.

473.name: Daniel Faria Gallery
473.formatted_address: 188 St Helens Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 4A1, Canada
reviews: Great gallery with great exhibits.  Well worth to get on the mailing list.  Always fascinating art and interesting people.
Interesting roster of Canadian artists, great gallery space and helpful friendly staff.
Didn't like the art display
Wonderful!

474.name: Sheldon Lookout
474.formatted_address: Martin Goodman Trail, Etobicoke, ON M8V 3W9, Canada
reviews: This is the starting point to hike the Humber River Trail north. The area there is nice and they even have some relaxing chairs to sit at and look at the Toronto skyline.
Beautiful place for walk, date, cycling and family time. Outstanding view of Toronto skyline and Humber bridge on d other side. Best time to visit at sunrise or else sunset.

Enjoy the best sunrise views of Toronto at the midsection of several accessible and mixed use trails.  The picture perfect lookout is best enjoyed from one of the many seating areas set up by Toronto Parks and Humber Bay.  The beach access, and arch bridge nearby are also lovely, and worth a short walk. I often see ducks and their babies here early in the morning.
Beautiful spot in Toronto. Highly recommend it to visit.
Cool place to walk around and enjoy the view

editorial_summary.overview: Waterfront observation point with colorful chairs & vistas of Humber Bay & the city skyline.

475.name: Sorauren Avenue Park
475.formatted_address: 289 Sorauren Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 2G4, Canada
reviews: Lovely little park. Lots of places to sit. I went for the farmer's market which was nice. It's a good neighborhood park for jogging, cycling also. It's good for taking your kids for a walk for just chilling with friends. Some corners are good for nature close-ups.

A beautiful Farmer's Market. It is open on MONDAYS ONLY, Rain OR Shine! We've gone during the Summer and colder months and there are always great options there! (I will add more photos the next time I go!)

What a beautiful park located in the agreable Roncesvalles neighborhood, every time I go to Toronto I go to this park. I just like to sit on a banch and watching people,childrens,dogs and all the activities, the residents of this neighborhood participate a lot of the life of this park by organizing family activities, in the summer there are films screening and once a week a public market and without forgetting you people who playing tennis, baseball, running.... For myself the pumpkin ball in October is the most grandiose. Love this park 💚💚

Sorauren is a gem of a park. Great place to have a picnic or play some games in the summer. There is a decent sized dog park that is accesible all year. In the spring/summer/fall there is a farmers market ever Monday night.  A new community centre that will be located at the southeast cornber of the park is currently  in the design phase. It will maintain most of the current amenities but add gym and pool spaces among others.

Has a great cafe right by the park, everyone seems to come for the soft serve, I enjoyed the chia pudding which was an option for people who don't consume sugar. I got to enjoy myself while my son was at a birthday party at the park, lots of room to run around. Very family oriented, although coming to the cafe is not the best place to study as it is a busy place, at least it was on a Sunday. Overall pleasant experience, thank you.

editorial_summary.overview: Simple neighborhood park offering outdoor tennis courts, sports fields & drinking fountains.

476.name: Rennie Park
476.formatted_address: 1 Rennie Terrace, Toronto, ON M6S 2X2, Canada
reviews: Good park. Lots of play space for the kids. Slides, swings and sand pit too.

nice park, well maintained, there is tennis court, soccor field, playground and surrounded hills ideal for toboggan in winter. A wild but short hiking path along the pond. There is a bridge which seems to be abandonded.Free parking.
This park has it all. Lots of big shady trees, perfect for a picnic. There's also a covered pavilion for larger groups. Skating rinks, tennis courts, and a nice little hiking trail.

I love this park. Public tennis courts, playground, skating rink in the winter and a large field for soccer and baseball. I always visit with my pets and so do many other people. If you have a dog, definitely check out Rennie park.
Great park and playground. Lots of space for everyone and all ages. Small splash pad for the little ones.

editorial_summary.overview: A 24-acre park with an ice rink, wading pool, tennis courts, playground, picnic shelter & ponds.

477.name: Jamie Bell Adventure Playground
477.formatted_address: 185 Spring Rd, Toronto, ON M6R 2Y8, Canada
reviews: Absolutely awesome playground. Unfortunately the puddles gather at the bottom of the slides after a rain storm. Bring extra shoes and socks for the little ones. Very popular playground that gets pretty busy. Recommend bringing a small camp chair as the benches and picnic tables fill up fast. Public restrooms are close by.
Great play park. Huge wooden structure, lots of swings. Plenty of in shade seating for parents. Water fountain and bottle filling station too. Car park and toilets nearby.

The little ones really loved it. Its a giant wooden castle themed play ground. Some  parts are worn down but overall it's still standing fairly strong there are lots of platforms to walk and climb on. Swings,slides  a little "zipline" type thing . Its free and right near high park zoo which is also free and great for small kids
We call it the castle park, always fun for smaller kids mostly. Apparently it's open to vehicles during weekdays so you can park inside.
The playground itself was nice, many kids playing around, parents chatting, overall it was clean. Sadly food choices are extremely limited around the area...

478.name: Lesya Ukrainka Monument
478.formatted_address: 285 Colborne Lodge Dr, Toronto, ON M6S 2T9, Canada
reviews: She was so innovative. An inspiration.
Hadn't heard of her before I saw the monument.  Still don't know too much about her.  But the monument is good.
Awesome memorial, special point for me and my friends!
monument to the great ukrainian poetess
High Park awesome.

479.name: High Park Labyrinth
reviews: A simple premise - walk along a defined path in a labyrinth to get to the center of the pattern; take in the tranquility and simplicity of the task. It’ll take you less than 10 mins. Appreciate the flutter of the leaves on the trees around you and the breeze as you do. Sit in the center for a moment once you get there.

A beautiful park to take a walk or ride a bike. May is usually time for the cherry blossoms and the park is packed with families from all walks of life enjoying the sheer beauty of these trees and the park in general. Bring good walking shoes as it takes a while to see the park in its entirety. Pack a lunch and some patience too while finding parking.
Cherry blossom May 7th 2022. Almost fully blossom 🌸.
Great spot for shoots, walk, run etc
Had a great time here. Sat in the middle for a while and contemplated life. Felt like I lost track of time on the way out, went into a bit of a trance-like state.

480.name: November's Pyramid
480.formatted_address: 430 Parkside Dr, Toronto, ON M6R 2Z3, Canada
reviews: Excellent.

481.name: Budapest Park
481.formatted_address: 1575 Lake Shore Blvd W, Toronto, ON M6K 3C1, Canada
reviews: Beautiful park with a trail along the water. On this hot day the cold breeze was very nice and refreshing. The beaches were filled with people and the whole atmosphere was fantastic. There is a lot of space with areas to play sports, eat or relax in the sun. Lots of trees providing shade as well which was amazing. The views are fantastic and the trail is just long enough to reach about 10,000 steps back and forth. Loved every second down there! Great spot for swimming too btw
Budapest Park lies near to Lake Ontario Stretch. A beautiful place to spend time with Family / Friends.  It has a small beach where we can play Volleyball and do Kayak.

Loved the Park. Both times I visited on a weekday. It was empty and enjoyed it thoroughly. There were seats scattered all over, empty picnic tables under the shades. Loved the serene and peaceful atmosphere.

Budapest Park is a wonderful area to enjoy anytime of the year and today was amazing with full sun and warmth. Great spot for families and children. Walking around or biking the trails. Walk around the shoreline on the beach or sit and take in all the amazing views.

Its a wonderful area to have a walk and a nice place close to the beach. Several places and areas to sit. There normally is a pretty cold breeze in this area, so do recommend wearing a extra layer when going to this area!

editorial_summary.overview: Waterfront park with a sandy beach, skyline views & a bike trail, plus a playground & a wading pool.

482.name: Grafton Avenue Park
482.formatted_address: 23 Roncesvalles Ave, Toronto, ON M6R 2K2, Canada
reviews: This is a small little patch of green space which is obviously well loved by the neighbourhood. They have a community garden along with three benches in a small area. So people are welcomed to come sit and enjoy some zen time
Cute little parkette with a community garden in the middle.
Serene little patch close to the waterfront. A nice little getaway.
It's Ok nothing is special.
Sit on the park bench and watch the world go by. .

483.name: Todmorden Mills Heritage Site
483.formatted_address: 67 Pottery Rd, Toronto, ON M4K 2B9, Canada
reviews: A hidden gem! We were out for a family drive and just happened to turn into this place that we have always just drove past.  Good thing we did! It's an outdoor and indoor historic village, buildings from the late 1880s onwards.  They have building tours; the place is connected to walking trails; and inside the interpretive centre was a free art installation... An interactive one at that!  Washroom facilities are brand new and clean. Outside, there were brand new info plaques that even had a few audio nuggets to drop... Very cool! It's someplace that we will drop by once or twice a year to see what new installations they have on, and catch a tour!

Good place to walk around and get some fresh air. Nice area for a for walk. Interesting heritage site in the city. Many displays that had interactive speakers, now broken, need to be fixed. Current display canoes very interesting.

We visited for a tree-focused tour of the Wildflower reserve, led by conservationist Steve Smith. Fascinating to see the space through the eyes of the folks who built it, plant by plant by plant. The paths (out the South end of the parking areas) are worth the stroll for the birds and native bio diversity on view, even without the guide!

Walk the Don: Lower Don Trail ' Pottery Road (Todmorden Mills) to Cherry Street (Distillery District)  The Lower Don Trail is from Pottery Road to Cherry Street at the Distillery District, a total of 6 km.  Glad to see that the City of Toronto is investing on recreational trails.  The kilometer markers were new and the Corktown Common was likewise a recent development.  I was under the Prince Edward Viaduct and could see the subway crossing the viaduct.  When I am on the subway and passing by the viaduct and looking down, I could see the trail and the Don Valley Parkway to my right and Bayview Avenue to my left (when the train is going  The end of the trail was the Distillery District.

Visited the site in early October, 2022. A great (and free!) site/museum to learn about a neat, hidden piece of Toronto's history! This is a place that so many people pass by unknowingly on the DVP, so it's great to get to know the site and its impacts on the city's development. I especially liked stepping into the homes. They were very well preserved and have very cool artefacts/replicas, such as antique cash, TTC transfers, and what bathtubs (if you could call it so) used to look like. The grounds are also quite nice for a walk; you could take a short loop around the museum. I even spotted a blue heron! Would encourage more people to come and visit. Plus, you could walk from here to/from Evergreen Brick Works to make it a longer outing.

editorial_summary.overview: Restored 19th-century buildings, including 2 residences & a brewery, plus a wildflower preserve.

484.name: Beaumont Park
484.formatted_address: 9 A Beaumont Rd, Toronto, ON M4W 1V4, Canada
reviews: Very good place, loved the fall colours and luxurious properties with private swimming pool
Excellent trail for a walk or bike. It would be even better if there were at least one porta potty in the middle of the trail. Not much to see as far as birds and nature, literally just a trail.

The place is close to nature and nice retreat for weekend, easily commutable via bike for ones who are living in downtown Toronto or around. However, certain necessary infrastructure is either missing or not maintained to an acceptable level.
This park is my winter summer favorite place to hang out. It has a nice river stream next to it which rarely freezes.
Awesome place to walk with your dog, lots of furry friends, great place to scape from the city stress even though you are still in the city

485.name: Wellesley Park
485.formatted_address: 500 Wellesley St E, Toronto, ON M4X 1H9, Canada
reviews: Greenery is soo good for summer. This place is quite and has a good treat to walk. They have benches here to chill around along with nice huge trees.  There is also a green space and stair case to trek down and above. It’s pretty quite and cool here.  There is a dustbin and and recycle bin for maintaining the cleanliness.  Make sure you don’t get here when it’s raining as it might get very mushy and sticky.  Good place for a small family picnic and enjoyment.
Good park for kids to play. It has  water splash and play area
Quiet cute little sand park with water park. Accessible swings and entrance

Beautiful small park anytime of the year. We take our evening walks though here every evening and love the fall views as the trees turn color each year. Always very quiet and relaxing anytime of the day or week.
Park has a badminton court but no net.. also has a children's play area as well as water fountain. Good place to laze around. Has multiple parks in the surrounding.

486.name: Evergreen's Winter Market
486.formatted_address: 550 Bayview Ave, Toronto, ON M4W 3X8, Canada
reviews: If you expect the Evergreen Holiday Market to have a similar Christmas vibe to the Distillery then you will be sadly disappointed. Except for the skating rink, it was purely commercial.
Great place to bring your family, enjoy different foods. Nice walking around the factory. I go every year and 2020 will not be different.

This is basically my ideal location and experience. It looks gorgeous, clusters of people are enjoying themselves inside and outside of the building, there are great food truck eats available, and a large number of small businesses at tables. Thanks for an amazing time!

Good date idea to kill a few hours. Food is ok and there is skating available as well. They have live music performances and other events. Great to have some photos for instagram if that's all you're looking for.
Had a great time with good food and good company. Roasting marshmallows over the fire was also fun

487.name: Evergreen Brick Works
487.formatted_address: 550 Bayview Ave, Toronto, ON M4W 3X8, Canada
reviews: A great place to enjoy nature as it is. The walking trail is natural with multiple humanmade wooden bridges over water bodies. You can walk up to the top to have a better view of the entire place. Great place to go alone, with friend or family. They don't have toilets everywhere so make sure to visit one at the building one before going in or after coming out. The bus stops right at the parking lot. They also have a cafe at the entrance building but they close up by 5 pm. The sound of the leaves when the wind goes through then is what I found most amazing about this place. The place is quiet even though there were a lot of people with kids and pets.

Lots of trails to enjoy a quick hike.. still so close to the city but feels like you're in a forest. The views of the city are also fantastic from here. We always bike here and find it quite challenging to dock our bike share bikes. It's great that there's bike path all the way here. There's always a farmer's market or vintage clothes going on here. So it's super vibrant but pretty expensive. We love it and visit in all seasons except in winter of course. Fall and spring are particularly beautiful.

I recently visited this place for the first time and loved it! What an awesome way to keep the history alive while breathing in life into it. I plan on coming back during their Saturday market but the Sunday I went was beautiful. It was a great day to go walking on their paths, reading about the history and learning about the wildlife. There needs to be more places like this that help us reconnect to nature.

Well maintained paved trails at the top and bottom level with nature all around! Going up to the top starting from the right side (or left, it's a loop) gives a great view of the hills and the city skyline. Once you reach the Don Valley Parks lookout, there's a small dirt path that takes you to the railway tracks. The path also connects to the Beltline trail.  There is a small shop containing lots of knickknacks and potential souvenirs at the main entrance area. The cafe is also a lovely place to get refreshments or a meal. Plenty of seats and picnic tables around as well, although it does get crowded during popular times in autumn.

One of Toronto’s true gems, this urban oasis has it all. Great walking paths, tons of wildlife and a real sense of nature in the middle of our city. On a daily basis in the spring and summer you’ll see turtles, frogs, snakes and a plethora of birds.  Originally where most of the bricks in Toronto came from this amazing place has been transformed.  The farmers market in the summer months is a huge bonus. From fresh strawberries to delicious street food and if you’re lucky a live music performance I highly recommend a trip to the Brick works.

editorial_summary.overview: Eco-oriented complex with a weekend farmer's market, a gardening store, event space & nature trails.

488.name: Withrow Park
488.formatted_address: 725 Logan Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 3B9, Canada
reviews: IMO the best park in Toronto. Perfect place to have a picnic or chill on the bleachers and watch people play soccer. Many lovely summer afternoons spent here just enjoying the world. Relaxed environment - clean and no one bothers you. There is a public washroom.

I love coming to this park and i am so glad it's just a 20 min walk away from home. The place is very well maintained, there are beautiful trees all over, play ground for kids, a big wide open field for kids to run around, or for people to chill. There a pretty big dog area as well, for all the dog owners and dog lovers to come around. I personally love to come here on days off just to look at dogs interacting. This park gives me a sense of peace, everyone seems to enjoy their time here. One of the best community parks in East York area. Definetly worth a visit, especially now with all the foliage.
I love this market so much, not in my neighborhood but it's worth making the trip out there on Saturdays in the spring, summer and fall.  They use reusable programs like Muuse.ca too🙌😎
Good place for tennis. Only two but surface is better than other public courts. Really crowded and line ups.

Always my favorite park beside my work. I eat my lunch here. It is very relaxing here. I like to sit down under the tree and feel the cool breeze. Lots activities for kids here but you can still have your little corner and have peace and quiet time. Soo love the place well mentained.

editorial_summary.overview: Recreational retreat featuring tennis courts, baseball fields, a playground & seasonal skating rink.

489.name: Toronto Necropolis
489.formatted_address: 200 Winchester St, Toronto, ON M4X 1B7, Canada
reviews: a very beautiful place, and so much history, with some gravestones from mid 19th century, along with very new ones. I love going there, very peaceful and meditative space (even with the noisy DVP so close). I only wish there were more benches. there is also the splendid chapel by the main entrance, which is so photogenic. by TTC: probably the best way to get there is 506 streetcar (get off at Parliament/Carlton) or 65 Parliament bus (get off at Parliament/Winchester - it is about 5-10 minutes walk east - giving you an opportunity to admire the charming and quiet Cabbagetown streets. l
Really nice chapel. We couldn't see it inside as it was closed, but the outside is definitely worth visiting if you are in the area.
This a very pleasant place to visit. Saw a our famous people there. Saw Jack Laytons grave, William Lyon Mackenzie's and George Browns grave.

Calm clean and peaceful atmosphere. Usually touch this place while going for a stroll at riverdale park. The management is taking super care of the property and you will simply love the place. There are graves from 1850 and you feel like walking through the past! There are old mausoleums and headstones which is a nice sight. The chapel and the entrance looks beautiful in the gothic revival style.
Very peace full place to stroll or site on a bench. Grounds are kept in very good condition

editorial_summary.overview: 19th-century burial ground featuring Gothic architecture & the tombs of many prominent Torontonians.

490.name: Lower Don Parklands
reviews: Beautiful trail with a nice view of the Don River that runs alongside it. Bridges are installed with colourful RGB lights which makes for quite the view after dark. Cyclists, prepare for some uphill climbs, and pedestrians must be careful at the bottom of the hills.
One of the greatest in the city. This is probably the single greatest hub to connect to all the other parks in the city.  Toronto truly is a city within a park.

Scenic trail that connects Edwards Gardens to Thorncliffe Park, Evergreen Brickworks, Victoria Park, and downtown. You can catch rabbits and deer along this trail that runs parallel to the Don River. It is mostly wooded with patches of grass space and some seating along the riverbed. Repaving is overdue on many points along the trail, particularly near Riverdale Park.
Amazing trails, makes you forget the city life. Come here to enjoy some tranquility

Perfect day for a walk around the trails. Minus 7 and sunshine today. This area is amazing and parking free on Beechwood at the very bottom under the Don Valley Parkway. Endless areas to walk, bike, even mountain bikes in the area. Great for families, children and furry kids. Trails are plenty wide enough to social distance and really not that many people can be seen as the trails are off in many different directions. You can travel north or south, towards the Brick Works or away from that area. You can cross the Don River over a foot pedestrian bridge and or walk along the small water side trails.

editorial_summary.overview: Oak- & maple-planted riverside park with a hiking, cycling & art trail & an annual salmon run.

491.name: Bennington Heights Park
491.formatted_address: 465 Heath St E, East York, ON M4G 1B7, Canada
reviews: Nice park off Bayview to relax, walk the dog and watch a tennis game. Tennis courts are open to the public 8-11pm on the weekend. Steps from Bayview take you right to the school, keep in mind it is private property so better to take the route from Heath St.
Its next to my child's school and the place is green with loads of trees with sunlight makes it a good place to spend some time.
It's not a really a park and not really a school. It's both. But some will consider it their own personal space and not mind others. Keep your dog on a leash around kids. Neither are predictable.
Fun park & if you go to south end , can catch great views of the sunset! My daughter & I enjoyed together
Benningtion Height. Is a small prak near School, great place to relax and look at the sky,

492.name: Holy Name Parish
492.formatted_address: 71 Gough Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 3N9, Canada
reviews: Beautiful church and a special Reverend. Everyone was so polite and the music played was wonderful. Thank you all ❤
Very beautiful Church.. peaceful and gorgeous inside as well.
December 8, 2021 Incredibly beautiful piece of architecture on the Danforth. I was awed by it when I was a child in the early 1960's and am equally awed by it now that I am in my mid-60's!
We attended Sunday Mass on  March 5th and felt just wonderful  and part of your congregation. The choir is amazing. The Church is beautiful. Felt very much at peace there. Thank you.
Mass is good here.  Nice church and Father Jinto performs a great mass.

493.name: Riverdale Farm
493.formatted_address: 201 Winchester St, Toronto, ON M4X 1B8, Canada
reviews: This is a great place to take your little ones to see some farm animals and visit the barn. We got to walk around inside and meet the farmers. Great time. The paths were closed for the winter but I can imagine how beautiful it must be in the spring/summer when the trail and picnic areas open. Looking forward to coming back.

A hidden gem in downtown Toronto. Beautifully kept farm on a large but well kept land. A must visit for all age. Walk through the farm and admire the plants and animals. Free entrance. Cannot take your pet though.

A nice short excursion, especially with kids with short attention spans. There are washrooms and water fountains onsite and I think a small cafe but it would be smart to bring your own snacks or a meal.  Free parking on the south side of the farm. The park surrounding the park is also very nice and is worth exploring if you have more time. There is a wading pool in the summer at the park.

This colossal grassy area with a few scattered trees and benches at the roadside to sit and enjoy from a height seeing lots of people enjoying themselves in the ground is a good place to relax in the evenings. The Toronto skyline, including the famous CN Tower, provides a picturesque views that are able to fill the viewers with tranquility and great pleasure. This is a good relaxing place for the people of the neighborhood.

What a great spot to bring our three year old grandchild.  We all loved it.  Sheep, goats, chickens, geese, turkeys, rabbits, cow and horses. Very historic property.  Large public park right beside the farm, with a children's wading pool managed by the City of Toronto.

editorial_summary.overview: Farm offering livestock, gardens & craft programs set within a park with ponds & picnic areas.

494.name: Riverdale Park East
494.formatted_address: 550 Broadview Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 2N6, Canada
reviews: Perfect picturesque picnic spot for you and your pet!  You have a lovely view of the Toronto skyline, while enjoying your picnics in the summer!  Reach early in the evening to ensure you get a spot as per your liking, as this park tends to get crowded in the summers.  There is a running track for those looking to get moving as well as enough space to place soccer.

Excellent place to come and have a break from the hustle and bustle of the city. There were a lot of people just hanging around, enjoying the view and having picnics. Saw some people walking their dogs as well. The views of the Toronto skyline are just breathtaking.

My son n daughter in-law took me to the Riverdale park today on 7 May 2022 as the temperature was 16°C pleasant n pleasing sunny..with their baby for an outing. There were many families with children relaxing on the grass with some drinks n snacks, looked like a picnic spot.. It was nice to spend some time in the pleasant weather though it was windy

Rode pass this place couple of times while making a delivery, lots of people hanging out here. Enormously field with a track and baseball diamond area. However a great view of Downtown Toronto. No wonder why it's so unique to look at. Great positive energy for sure 😊

Beautiful park! I had a picnic there with friends and I couldn't believe how big it was. There's a track you can use or huge field space to play anything you want. The slopes will definitely see tobogganing this year.

editorial_summary.overview: A popular tobogganing spot, this sizable park with skyline views offers an ice rink & sports fields.

495.name: Chorley Park
495.formatted_address: 245 Douglas Dr, Toronto, ON M4W 2B9, Canada
reviews: Chorley Park  Toronto has its own Golden Encore, the last trees to change colour.  I love this park, it has history in it and the trail leads to a lot of other trails around Toronto.  It is always worth going back to.
Isn’t it so beautiful in autumn? It is a small park in a quite neighborhood but I was lucky to see multiple shades of fall here. There is also a stair connecting to don valley trail.
A must see for a quick weekend hike. Photoes are from my hike last spring. Lots pf greens and beautiful sceneries to take pictures. There's also a beatuiful pond with green leaves on top.
Beautiful park, well kept. People who use this park seem responsible and clean after themselves. I never find garbage or dog feces anywhere on the ground. Please don't ruin it. Thank you

We had a birthday party at this park. It was great. Lots of space for picnicking, playing soccer, trees for climbing😁, natural life ponds, hiking, cool place. There is paid parking or if you lucky you can get free parking on the road near the upper level of the park.

496.name: Chester Hill Lookout
496.formatted_address: Chester Hill Rd, Toronto, ON M4K 1V4, Canada
reviews: You get a beautiful landscaoe view from this point...lovely scenery and nice neighbourhood walk while reaching this place. Good to visit during evening to enjoy amazing sunset view. I visited during morning and weather was cold...but a good spot around.

Decent lookout spot. It is a bit far back from the city, so you may need a decent camera to get a good shot. Can get busy enough, especially around dusk as a lot of people come for sunset. There is a house beside it that does seem to, understandably, get frustrated when people encroach on the property. We saw a couple park outside their garage and were asked to move. This lookout is in a residential area so I'd just say, be respectful of the residents and their neighbourhood.
Amazing views! You can just relax or hangout at this place. But the view can be better if they trim down some trees which obstruct the view of the skyline.
Sweet little spot. It was cold when we went there but would love to go during a lively weather and just lounge around. The sunsets  be amazing. Pretty Toronto skyline on the spot.

Such a calm barely crowded place with a lovely view. Located at the end of a residential lane. We went around 6pm on friday but very less people. However not even a bench so not the place to hang out as a group and also the area is tiny. Can park on the lane.

497.name: Don Valley Park
497.formatted_address: Don Valley Pkwy, Toronto, ON M4K, Canada
reviews: I give the park and the Lower Don River Trail 4 star for it's natural beauty and the way it's kept untouched at the heart of the city. But I got one star back because there are no seats or any washroom facility along the trail (unless we get further off the trail).  I understand that we don't want to disrupt the natural environment by construction, though, at least seats along the trail at safe places and environmentally-friendly structures and washrooms do help to attract more people and the ones who can't walk long trails without getting rest along the way on seats.  This good trail also needs more access by providing more entry paths to the park from all neighbourhoods around the area.
Great place to take your kids to ride.  It is paved trails and it is very flat.  I can't believe we saw deers too.

Perfect place for a Park with so much foot traffic and or bikes traveling the trails of the Don River. Just needs some picnic tables for the summer months. We made our way from Riverdale Park West today and hiked along the Don River up as far as Pottery Road and so much has changed over the years. I miss that wooden structure that we used to walk or bike on that passed under the bridges. Now the trail takes you away from the 2 bridges and no sign of the past.

The bike trail from Canary District is a great cycling workout along the River. Many cyclists along the way. The trail is located within the city, and in the summer, it gives you a feeling of riding in the villages of India. Didn’t see any wildlife other than the insects that fly into your mouth and nose while cycling. Try to get done with the trail way before sunset to avoid the insects.
It’s now become a ritual to go on the David Balfour trail to the Brickworks and back on Moore Park trail (refer photo 3)

498.name: Gargoyles Sculptures
498.formatted_address: Old Toronto, Toronto, ON M4K, Canada
reviews: Nice sculptures but couldn't really enjoy them because of disrespectful visitors. Some were sitting on the sculptures. Some were using them as a place to rest their jackets. I had to go and ask for them to kindly let me see the sculpture underneath their jackets or their body. Imagine if this happened in a museum!
Beautiful sculptures by Duane Linklater.
Fun sculptures to check out. The path to get here may be a little confusing but it’s a hidden gem and worth a look if you’re in the area.
This is a really wonderful exhibit of urban sculptures marvels. Situated on a gorgeous park trail along the Don river, it is all weather beauty to visit alone or with friends and family.
The construction is ongoing for year's, still a long way to go.

499.name: Scenic Lookout Binoculars
499.formatted_address: Prince Edward Viaduct, Bloor St E, Toronto, ON M4K, Canada
reviews: Handy binoculars on the Prince Edward Viaduct. You can see the Toronto downtown skyline. There is also a good view of the CN Tower. It is free and accessible to all who walk the bridge. If you want to visit the binoculars by car, park your car on one side of the bridge and walk here.
A great landmark of the city

500.name: Neighbourhood Love Mural by Monica Wickeler
500.formatted_address: 270 Danforth Ave, Toronto, ON M4K 1N6, Canada

501.name: Don Valley Brick Works Park
501.formatted_address: 550 Bayview Ave, Toronto, ON M4W 3X8, Canada
reviews: Very beautiful park in middle of city. You cant imagine there would be such a remote place just besides a highway. You can also continue your walk toward mount pleasant cemetery if you’d like to walk more

Pretty good. The park is pretty small but well maintained. Probably not suitable for older people - you need to go up the hill quite a bit. The parking is plentiful at $8/day but it gets busy on the weekends.

This is one of my favourite parks in the city! I first went there many years ago before the buildings were restored as part of a field trip. I learned about the wonderful geological features, like fossils of trilobites and even a giant beaver! However, the beautiful wetlands were what captured my heart. It’s so amazing to see wildlife like snapping turtles and blue herons in the city! I highly recommend hiking up to the lookout, especially in autumn to take in all the glorious colours.

This is a hidden gem in Toronto. Once in the park it seems we have reached the country side. Fall is the best time with the riot of colors. Great place for all ages. Must visit if you live or visiting Toronto.
Lots of parking. Nice and quiet park. Gentle slops and easy to walk. Great areas for neat brick back drop pictures. Dog friendly.

editorial_summary.overview: Natural 40-acre park on a former quarry site with trails, ponds & Toronto skyline views.

502.name: Craigleigh Gardens
502.formatted_address: 160 South Dr, Toronto, ON M4W 1S2, Canada
reviews: Great off leash park.  Beautiful park with lovely benches and trees. It's never been too crowded when I've been there.
We had enjoyed our walk down the trial next to Criagleigh Garden this morning. The scenery is very pretty.
Nice park to relax in if you are riding up and down the Don and want to venture west a bit.

Small park, but beautiful. Surrounded by houses and a ravine on one side. Beautiful mature trees if you want to stay out of the sun. If you love dogs this is the place for you. Highly recommended, but capacity is limited due to it's size. And if you are going to be there in the evening, there are mosquitoes, due to the aforementioned ravine.
Off leash dog favorite.  Great ginkos in golden splendor.

editorial_summary.overview: Stately, 3.4-hectare green space with mature trees, benches & a popular off-leash dog area.

503.name: Wychwood Barns Park
503.formatted_address: 76 Wychwood Ave, Toronto, ON M6G 2X7, Canada
reviews: This is one of those ‘Private neighborhoods’ Elegant houses neatly tucked behind old and humongous trees, not for effects, just how it is..There’s a buried creek here that pools to a very nice pond being used for skating in the winter months. The roads are uphill, downhill and turned all the way to loops, you’ll get confuse, I think that’s the idea so you don’t wander around here. So anyway, Taddle creek winds under those big houses and ends at Davenport Rd.  Wychwood Barns Park is a dream! Go visit and say your oohh aaaahhhh. Enjoy!
Nice multipurpose park and facility for events.  And it even has a volleyball court (but bring your own net).  Farmers market every Sat morning.
Large park with dynamic space for indoor and outdoor events. Very limited parking options around.

This review is for the Saturday farmers' market. It's quite a social scene for kids of all ages and their dogs. Music plays! You will find local purveyors of vegetables, mushrooms, meats, fish, cheese, honey, bread, pastries and more, plus fast food and drinks of various styles and ethnic origins. Quality seems universally high and prices are reasonable for such an  entertaining atmosphere. There's lots of green space, many TTC options, plentiful parking, and that stretch of St. Clair provides a variety of interesting shopping opportunities. Highly recommended!
A great community space that is inviting and open.  Went to the Garlic Festival and enjoyed every minute of this event.

editorial_summary.overview: Park featuring a playground, a sports field, volleyball, an off-leash dog area & the Wychwood Barns.

504.name: Casa Loma
504.formatted_address: 1 Austin Terrace, Toronto, ON M5R 1X8, Canada
reviews: This was a great experience... very cool castle estate. Gardens were cool. Historical write-ups for the rooms, a horse stable, antique car museum, and a Back Stage Celebrities walk, which has little scenes with (wax?) statues and clips playing for all of the movies that were recorded at the castle. Loved it! I wasn't quite as excited about the 3rd floor, but if you are into military history, you would love it. Getting up to the tower was awesome, too.

Truly a beautiful space! It's a Gothic Revival style mansion and house museum with beautiful grounds during the summer. I can imagine weddings at this place! To get to the highest levels you have to take some very narrow stairs and if you are able to, it's totally worth going to the top. You will see amazing views of the surrounding areas! Can't wait to return here someday when things are back to normal, or as close to normal as possible!

The place was amazing. Last time that I was in here was when I was a child. Everything changed a lot! The guy at the front collecting tickets was super nice! And answered all our questions.  Our favorite was getting to climb the stairs all the way to the top floor! We wish the secret garden was open. I heard lots of good things about it. We also loved the celebrity rooms.  It keeps on running through my mind on what if Casa loma did an overnight thing where they turn off all the lights and everyone used a flashlight. That will be amazing. Maybe do this for Halloween?  We will be back for sure!

When visiting Toronto don’t miss the opportunity to visit this beautiful castle. The grounds and fountains and gardens are beautiful. So much elegance and history is packed in each room. This castle was really interesting and fun to explore. There are plenty of places to relax and just take in the views. It’s like a museum but more engaging and fun. Apparently they have a Halloween show but my visit was before then. I bet this place looks fabulous decked out for Christmas .

More than the castle and its architecture, I enjoyed the history of the castle presented in a documentary movie in the basement. So, be sure to check that out which is included in your ticket. Another perk is that you get audio guide devices which were very cool. The ones that we got did not have headphones so you had to hold them like you are speaking on the phone, but I saw some other people with devices having headphones. The most enjoyable part of the experience was that there are 2 towers that you had to climb very narrow stairs to reach the top. They were decorated and designed for escape room game purposes which was fun to see. Overall, it was a very pleasant experience.

editorial_summary.overview: Grand 18th-century castle featuring regular tours & gardens that are open seasonally.

505.name: Royal Ontario Museum
505.formatted_address: 100 Queens Park, Toronto, ON M5S 2C6, Canada
reviews: It is absolutely amazing, you can spend a whole day in the museum. It has different sections of historical ages from all over the world. You can see many things from different civilizations. I loved the geology part. You can find brilliant minerals and stones. It is one of the best museum I have ever seen. Highly recommended to visit.

The ROM is World Class, all the way! Better then any of the Smithsonian in Washington DC. It is really a natural history and art & culture museum rolled into one! I only spent a few hours here, however you could come here for days and still be able to take in everything. I would recommend visiting the museum website in advance and prioritize what collections you want to see. Some rooms are going to be more busy then others based on the content. Lots of child friendly exhibits, ask the curators as to which ones are best suited for children. I bought the city pass in advance. NOTE: For the city pass the museum does require you to pick a day of visitation in advance. The city pass made it easy to access the museum. I recommend a visit to the geology collection. Some of the biggest geodes I have ever seen!

Clean and organized. Big and spacious museum. The dinosaur floor is a win for the kids and the most packed. In other floors/exhibits, Not so much of the Displays are so archaic but still worth a visit.. The artist's exhibition is also a nice one, they help in introducing promising artists. We enjoyed our visit. We enjoyed it. There’s so many things to see at the ROM. We had less than 2 hours before closing, and wish we had more time. Each floor is full of amazing artifacts! Very informative, quick lines to get in, and worth visiting - especially with the CITY PASS. We will be back!

ROM has an amazing collection. Every section you go seems better than the previous. Even if you have specific interests you can't help but appreciate others. If one wants to take a glimpse at every exhibit it can easily take 3 hours to complete the museum. But if one really wants to examine and learn they can spend the whole day in one section

A day well spent at the ROM, from the Dinosaurs display to the Bats cave, from learning about the ancient to modern history of the World. The museum is large with pretty nice interiors and well-displayed artifacts; my favourites were the Minerals and Precious stones section. The staff was also polite and helpful. One thing I would suggest is that they should increase the closing time from 5:30 to 7 PM. Overall it's a nice place to spend the day.

editorial_summary.overview: Sprawling natural history & world cultures galleries, plus dinosaurs in the Libeskind crystal wing.

506.name: Church of the Redeemer
506.formatted_address: 162 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M5S 1M4, Canada
reviews: One of the more impressive communities here; deep roots in the social gospel, good to see those judged by society freely accepted here, acceptance and open discussion about the world is very important and I don't feel stifled here. After being mistreated at conservative places, this place is one of the few faith communities in which actions speak louder then empty words. As church attendance falls from churches, it rests on progressive churches to show the way in accepting millenials instead of scoffing at them. As Tolstoy says, if you have rightly become alienated by organized religion and their hate and hypocrisy, don't let it scare you away from your mission to help other people, seek God/Nature again, and don't let men and their evils rule you, otherwise they will win.
This church is beautiful. Right in downtown, close to subway.
Nice church .

when my friend Julian showed me this place,  I was amazed by the oatmeal, bread and hummus snacks the people there gave to me. I could smell fresh coffee brewing when I arrived. breakfast between 8- 9am. and at 10:30 am they served lunch. it's a great place to get out of the cold and fuel up. thank goodness for this place.

I was at the church for a celebration of life for the late Dane Gaskin. Whom was taken from this world all too soon. He was a recording artist and in general a great guy. The service was lovely and the staff and church carefully selected the music he loved. In a busy city this church is truly lovely including the people in it. Dane you were loved by all me and so many. My you be at peace now. Love David.

507.name: Yorkminster Park Baptist Church
507.formatted_address: 1585 Yonge St, Toronto, ON M4T 1Z9, Canada
reviews: I don't know what this is like as a church, but it's a great concert hall. Acoustics were lovely, and it was well-organized and pretty easy to get to, even for those of us outside of Toronto. We parked at the Green P garage at 20 Delisle, and that worked great.

On Wednesdays after 5pm they offer a hot meal service during beginning of winter on November til March next year. A variety of tasty soups plus an option of veggie or meat dinner and dessert. They also provide a ttc token per person and clothing bank.

One of the the oldest Baptist church in Toronto. It's beautiful stone walls and it's high cathedral like ceilings make this church an awesome sight to see. The people are really friendly and polite! They validate parking on Sundays. I'm so glad me and my bible study group came here New Years eve!
Beautiful church, huge, accommodates 500 easily.   Christmas Concert with Lorena Mckennit was wonderful.

They play their bells randomly and for hours at a time it’s 2pm on a Thursday and the bell has been going for an hour. Not a song or anything just donging. This happens often and also at random so you can’t plan your work calls around the noise. I once made the mistake of emailing and asking if their was a schedule for the bells so I could plan around them and got a rude reply saying “The bells ring every 15 minutes.” (they do not, sometimes they play every 15 but usually every hour sometimes *for* 3hours) I’m not even asking them to stop! Just to post a schedule or something so people can work around them

508.name: Spadina Museum
508.formatted_address: 285 Spadina Rd, Toronto, ON M5R 2V5, Canada
reviews: I was able to visit this place as a part of Doors Open Toronto. The house is fantastic - they've done a wonderful job maintaining the historical finishes inside - to match the photos that exist.  There was staff in every room, explaining details about the house. They had a video playing in the basement that went into even more detail.  The grounds are even more stunning. They had little games like they would have been playing in the 1800s. The trees were flowering(!!!), the gardens were perfect... It was breathtaking.

I really liked this museum. Excellent preservation of the home with very knowledgeable guides to take you on a tour of each room. There’s also the beautiful, really well-maintained grounds where you can grab a drink, do some reading or just sit and soak in the peace and quiet.  Highly recommend a visit, especially on a nice summer day.
Beautiful place! We spent amazing time here. Thank you so much for the tour, it’s was fascinating!  Recommend booking in advance to avoid disappointment, cause now spaces are limited.

Visited during Doors Open on a gorgeous sunny day; a fair number of visitors to the awesome gardens. Very peaceful and colourful. Noted many plants I know.  Lots in bloom.  The building is a historic landmark & is free entry always, according to the signage.

Nice historic landmark and pretty exterior- was here for the Dis/Mantle exhibit and it was great to learn briefly about Black history with a modern artistic interpretation.  It is currently a free exhibit!  There is a greenhouse in the garden but that is closed to the public.

editorial_summary.overview: Heritage home demonstrating domestic life in the 1920s & '30s, plus a Victorian-Edwardian garden.

509.name: Hare Krishna Temple - International Society For Krishna Consciousness (ISKCON)
509.formatted_address: 243 Avenue Rd, Toronto, ON M5R 2J6, Canada
reviews: This is great experience to visit this Temple for DARSHAN of the Deities .  We were lucky to attend Aarti ceremony also during 12-15 to 12-30 P M. Very pious feelings. A lady devotee was chanting the Hare Krishna mantra and then the Aartis. Her melodious voice added to the holy and sacred vibes. 🙏🙏
I wasn't expecting the temple to be at par with what we have in India but it felt so calm and serene by visiting the temple. It felt like home! Food at govinda's was amazing too.

This temples is just 30mins by walk from my house and whenever in life I am stressed, I visit the temple for some peace of mind. The temple is very peaceful and has good architecture. The temple is well kept and the idols are dressed very beautifully with colourful attires. There is place to take off and keep your shoes. Then, one can sanitize their hands with the available sanitizer before entering the temple. This temple is not crowded at all. I have been on Sundays and there used be hardly one or two other people.

One of the best place in toronto to experience peace of mind and blissfulness. One must visit this temple to get the blessings of Deities.Hare Krishna temple is very well kept and organized in all manners. Atmosphere inside is truly energetic and divine. The volunteers here are so supportive and when we talk to them we ourself feel energetic and happy. The Temple also serves food here by name of Govinda which is very fresh and satvik as well. On Krishna Janmashtami the temple is crowded as people from all over toronto visit here for blessings. Highly recommended.Hare Krishna!

One of the peaceful place to visit. Lord Krishna idol is just mesmerizing. You can get inner peace in such a peaceful vibe. Always to go place when nearby. Kudos to the management team for tge cleanliness.

510.name: St. Basil's Catholic Parish at the University of St. Michael's College
510.formatted_address: 50 St Joseph St, Toronto, ON M5S 1J4, Canada
reviews: Went there for the Sunday 12 noon mass. It was such a pleasant experience at the reception.  They are very careful and strict about all the social distancing guidelines and helps you with the seating based on the size of the group. You don't have to register to attend the Sunday Mass at the moment. The Holy Mass experience was beyond beautiful than the church architecture. It felt nice to listen to the choir during the Mass. My soul was filled with joy after returning home.
⛪ Beautiful Church ⛪  Open to the public. There are some amazing statues of Christ. You can light a candle. Very pleasant inside.
Healing help from Catedrala St Basil 's Catholic and ours priests. God Bless
Beautiful church with large sign I front that made it easy to find
A serene place to reflect. Went here as part of the stations of the cross exhibition.

511.name: Zen Buddhist Temple-Toronto
511.formatted_address: 86 Vaughan Rd, York, ON M6C 2M2, Canada
reviews: A great place to spend your Sunday if you're into Zen meditation

Very warm and welcoming place. Not yet a full member but have found the Sunday services (both at 10:00 and 4:00; the latter is best for beginners) straightforward, helpful and well-organised. There's no pressure and you can meditate however you'd like, but they also offer training programmes for Korean Son (Zen/Chan) sitting practice. By far the best place to begin with this in Toronto, with plenty of events to encourage participation.

I am not sure how to accurately convey my experience here with a simple review. But hopefully, someone will hear what they need to hear in reading what I write here.  I started here in 2011, coming my first time simply to learn how to meditate.  I had no intention of getting into Buddhism, as the idea seemed foreign to me, and to be honest I was/am skeptical of religions as a whole to begin with. But meditation is a thing that has nothing to do with religions. So, for certain reasons that I won't get into, I wanted to learn. Or shall I say rather, that I felt obligated to learn. Wanting had really nothing to do with it...  ...at first.  I came once a week to meditate, and slowly at first, I became exposed to little things about Buddhism here and there. Quite honestly, I was expecting the hard sell, or at least a soft one from the Sunim (monk), and the Abbess. But what I got was neither. What I got were things that no matter how much I tried, and threw all of my experience and knowledge (and this was considerable, I believe) against I could not find any fault with. So this was enough to open the door wider for me to get a bigger step inside. The rest (as far as my story goes) is history.  Buddhism (of the Korean Zen variety, as is the tradition here) gave me the tools to change my life from that of an abused and neglected child who grew up angry, disfunctional, emotionally scarred, traumatized, and - my major problem at the time, for which I was desperately seeking a solution to - ADDICTED TO FENTANYL (as well as just about everything else), to that of one who is at peace, and who sees the world completely different than I used to. Not so terribly deluded as I was, able to help others, able to find joy in my connection with others, and with all living beings. Able to be fully compassionate, fully empathetic, fully loving as an individual. I have this place to thank for all of that.  I'd been to AA, NA, CA, rehab (8 times), detox (15 times), committed (twice), arrested (once, charged but not convicted), Kundalini Yoga for addiction program ($3000), retreats ( too many), seminars (too many), and odd ball programs here and there. Not saying that it all didn't work. It's all part of my story, and every bit of it has contributed to my betterment in some way or another. But any truth to be found in all of the aforementioned, is truth that the Buddha dharma is about specifically, almost as though all of these programs were attempts to convey a truth that Buddhism states without any cloud cover, or misunderstanding.  I would not suggest simply showing up will solve all your problems in life, but you may just find what your looking for.  If you come, you will be most welcome. Who knows, maybe even by me, lol.
I love this place. Sanha is very inspiring, she leads the meditation with pure presence and embodies all the qualities I am trying to develop with my meditation practice.
Great place to be. Very friendly sangha. Regular meditation classes offered for all levels.

512.name: Gardiner Museum
512.formatted_address: 111 Queens Park, Toronto, ON M5S 2C7, Canada
reviews: Such a unique and beautiful collection of ceramics. The first floor consists of pottery from the Americas and some new exhibits. The second floor has a wide collection of Japanese and Chinese ceramics - vases, tea sets, plates, and figurines. There is a beautiful  set of figurines in the European section on the same floor. If you appreciate decorative ceramics and glass, then this is a must see!

Collection -They had a large varieties of pottery from around the world. I was impressed by the pieces but also the conservation. They look like they were plucked out of time.  Staff - Friendly and knowledgeable, they have amazing people working at the museum.  Services - They do classes on clay pottery, so be sure to check it out. Also, it is free currently in 2022 Aug. Which is an amazing way to give back  to the community.  Highly recommend if you love pottery, ceramics, and art in general. 👍
Small museum with a very interesting collection of ceramics and porcelain from many different cultures and centuries. I really enjoyed it. There is a nice cafe/restaurant on the top. Friendly staff.

This is a smaller Museum and there is lots to see for sure. But my friend and I noticed that the curation wasn't very great and didn't speak to the diversity of the pieces that were there. There are a lot of pieces collected by older white folks for many years and while that might be the case the curations didn't speak to the pieces themselves and the history of the pieces in terms of how they might have been obtained and the difficulties with that.

I can’t believe the number of times I’ve been to the ROM and didn’t even know this gem of a museum existed so close! I went in to see the pieces created by Japneet Kaur and ended up really appreciating how much of the content was Southern American (esp. Peruvian) and south East Asian (esp. Japanese and Chinese). Very clean and low key so you can just have a quite stroll through the place!

editorial_summary.overview: Besides exhibits, this ceramics museum offers classes, lectures & tours, plus a bistro & gift shop.

513.name: Nordheimer Ravine
513.formatted_address: 326 Spadina Rd, Toronto, ON M5P 1N5, Canada
reviews: This ravine has a built in off leash dog park. I go almost everyday to walk my dog and escape the city. You feel like your out of the city. It also connects with the Belt Line which is a beautiful walk.

Nordheimer Ravine to Cedarvale Park  We started the hike at the Spadina Station and passing by the Baldwin steps leading to Casa Loma.  We bypassed the Baldwin steps and went on the trail to Cedarvale Park. There was a nice display of fall colours.  There was also an off-leash dog-park.

A whole different world within a city..  Wonderful for those who want to experience forest bath. I didn't experience anything odd but hopefully they have security in place in case any issue occurs or any anti-social elements attack.
It's really small but I guess it is a nice spot for walking your dog
