Walk off St Clair and you're there - one of the many hidden oasis right in the middle of Toronto!

editorial_summary.overview: This ravine features a walking path through native trees & plants, plus local wildlife.

514.name: The Tollkeeper's Park
514.formatted_address: 750 Davenport Rd, Toronto, ON M6G 2B3, Canada
reviews: Visit the Tollkeepers Cottage and learn about history of life in 1860 which is a little museum in the park. Run by volunteers open Saturdays entrance  by donation

Interesting obscure piece of Toronto history. Realistically, this spot is more of a bench and open space near an old building that's generally locked. Will check back in if I ever see it open. Should be a museum.

Step back in time. This is a recteation/restoration of an actual toll keepers cottage from the time if the BNA act. They so hold regular events and when 5he house is quiet the surrounding garden and grounds provide a sweet respite from modern life.
Nice little parkette, it is small, but it is not used very much.  I take my dog there once a day for a little off leash training
A nice park

515.name: Casa Loma Escape Series
515.formatted_address: 1 Austin Terrace, Toronto, ON M5R 1X8, Canada
reviews: These games are really well done, and designed to work well with larger groups that could be strangers. There are lots of puzzles to keep big groups all active and entertained. Also means you can go more than once to each, and do different parts. For experienced escape artists, the puzzles are a bit on the easier side, but still quite fun and engaging. The staff actors are also fun, and aren't part of most experiences elsewhere. Great for hooking your friends before taking them to private rooms.
We Loved it, we try to go every year! It's so much fun! If you  can't do stairs then  think twice as there are many stairs in the courtyard.

I've done at least 8 escape rooms this year and Escape Casa Loma-- at least, the escape room itself-- definitely makes my top 3.  Pros: The live actors really made the experience unique and immersive. They were all decked out in clothes fitting with the theme. They were always in character and had great, infectious energy. The escape room itself was fun and full of interesting puzzles, and no two were the same, despite there being so many. There were few to no literal locks that you had to find a combination for; everything as far as I could remember was sensor-based, which is extremely creative. I loved that there were multiple floors leading up to a tower-- but after a while we got a bit sick of the stairs. The decor was beautiful and I loved every detail.  Cons: The stairs were endless, and I really wish the website were more upfront about how many stairs you'd need to climb -- not only within the escape room itself, but also just to get there. It's also kind of unclear where to go to get to the escape room and you have to walk through a lot of employee hallways, which was very off-putting. I also think mixed group escape rooms shouldn't exist, since it ruins the experience greatly, and feels like a cash grab. Luckily, we got a nice group of people, but it was still slightly awkward and felt jarring when trying to solve puzzles in a timely manner.  Overall, a top-tier escape room with a few flaws that strongly impacted the experience, but still one of my favorites by far. I'd definitely go back to Toronto just to do another escape room here, but I'd try to get a full group if possible to avoid another mixed one.

Such a fun, immersive escape room experience! The actors stay in character and give clues which really keeps the atmosphere. Some of the challenges are tough and require thinking outside the box but we got it right down to the last minute which made it very exciting! Will go back for sure. We did the King of the Bootleggers.

My Bachelorette party and I had a lot of fun at the Casa Loma Escape room! The interactive hosts are really good actors and help with subtle hints when you get stuck. We just missed escaping, but that's okay. They walked us through what we missed and I will most likely be trying another one of their Escape rooms in the future.

516.name: TeodoraArt Gallery
516.formatted_address: 214 Avenue Rd, Toronto, ON M5R 2J4, Canada

517.name: Secret City @ Casa Loma
517.formatted_address: 328 Walmer Rd, Toronto, ON M5R 2Y4, Canada
reviews: I did the Escape The Tower game and it was really fun and challenging. (Almost made it out!) The support staff were great characters who lead the way and the atmosphere is really authentic.

Escape the Ghost Ship was great!  It was really cool to do an escape room on a boat cruising around the harbour!  The only down side was we could have used a few more minutes to enjoy the wonderful view from the boat!  Nick was our host and he was really fun and hilarious.
Secret City blends escape games with a unique immersive experience which takes you and your friends on an adventure you cannot forget! Loved getting to explore Casa Loma in a new and uniqe way

Good games, but don't bother with VIP... while the escape games themselves are fun and can be easily booked on line, any other customer service interaction is about as much fun as a visit to the dentist. In the end, the booking and customer service process was so abysmal that we just booked a game online and decided to do the rest of our event elsewhere.

Did "Where Dark Things Dwell" with a bunch of friends and had a blast! The theme was creepy and atmospheric, the actors were very good and scared us at times, and the puzzles were unique, challenging, and fun to do! It was also a different approach than normal since it was outside vs the normal escape room within a single building. We didn't finish all the way unfortunately but had a lot of fun overall! Would definitely recommend to all kinds of escape room enthusiasts

518.name: Oriole Park
518.formatted_address: 201 Oriole Pkwy, Toronto, ON M5P 2H1, Canada
reviews: 2022 August 3.5★ If your in the area, this isn't a bad park to stop by. Especially since there's a public washroom and it's connected to trails nearby. The park itself is fairly clean. On nice days, the park will be full of people given the amenities: Ping pong/table tennis table Baseball diamond Tennis court Children's playground with swings and climbing structure Small splash pad Small garden Free book exchange Public washrooms  There's also a public bike rental in this park.
The park is medium in size. Popular among local people. Baseball area in one corner. Ice cream truck in another corner. Good for picnic and spending good time with your family and friends.

As someone who has relocated from Dubai which has fantastic parks, I was pleasantly surprised with the number of parks in Toronto. Oriole park near davisville subway station is a fantastic clean park for kids. My daughter loved open space, greenery and the water splash area where kids love to cool down. It also has couple of tennis courts and a very unique table tennis table and lots of space for jogging.
Such a good vibe park. Everyone has something for them here. Table Tennis and Tennis court adds extra attractions. Toddler water splash area is a huge hit too. Colorful, pretty park

Clean and well maintained park. Not huge, but certainly worth a stroll through.  There's a baseball diamond, a playground, benches, and a ping pong table (paddles and balls not provided, of course).  On the weekends it gets fairly busy, and during the warmer seasons, there are often peewee baseball games (which can get loud, be mindful of this if you're seeking serenity).  This park connects to bicycle routes in all cardinal directions, including the beltline trail.

editorial_summary.overview: Park with a playground & splash pad, plus sports facilities, washrooms & many shade trees.

519.name: Artscape Wychwood Barns
519.formatted_address: 601 Christie St, Toronto, ON M6G 4C7, Canada
reviews: A nice way to connect with the neighborhood and community.  One get authentic fish roti, Tibetan momo's, homemade sushi and miso soup, fresh pastries, baked goodies, cheese, meat and  fruit and vegetables.  The price is a bit high but it's worth it.

Attended Halloween Howl with Solid and Rob with my little ones. Amazing show if you have not taken it in. The farmers market is not to be missed either. Highly recommended. It's a good way to meet other members of the community and it's important to teach our children how they can be part of the local community.
Went on market day and loved it!!! Tried some fresh onigiri and mochi, brought home cilantro olive sourdough bread and had a great chat with a few vendors. 10/10 morning.

Dropped by this weekend to check out the garlic fest and it was lovely! I would go back again in the future. I hear there are weekly farmers markets so if I am ever in need of locally grown fresh organic produce, I’ll be sure to stop by here.
Airy spacious and luminous with plenty of natural light at the atrium. This is an impressive space for artists and designers to showcase and exhibit their products and pieces.

editorial_summary.overview: Long-standing transit facility turned arts hub featuring studios, a gallery & farmers market.

520.name: Timothy Eaton Memorial Church
520.formatted_address: 230 St Clair Ave W, Toronto, ON M4V 1R5, Canada
reviews: My husband and I went for Advent service and were greeted by many friendly people. Rev. Jason was engaging and intelligent with a fresh perspective that was relevant to today. The program lists many activities.
enjoyed my visit and christmas service, 2nd time  and will be an annual thing for me

Attended the Church for the Foodbank set up outside the side entrance. People were very friendly and helpful to all! Treated with respect, dignity and kindness always! Very Grateful for the service offered!
My nephew got married here in July 2022. It is a beautiful church. Inside and outside is clean.
Beautiful architecture. Made me a little surprise by appearing out of nowhere when I was cycling

521.name: Ukrainian Museum of Canada, Ontario Branch
521.formatted_address: 620 Spadina Ave., Toronto, ON M5S 2H4, Canada
reviews: Today was a special day .. as I got to know about Ukrainian history....  the exhibit was great ... Want to thank everyone involved, specially your ancestors . Thanks to them and their hard work, somehow we all “emigrants” have better way to start our lives in our new home ... ❣️
Highlight of my trip to Toronto. Thank you so much for the tour!
This small museum has an excellent collection of Ukrainian textiles (clothing, embroidery, etc.) and puts together some wonderful exhibits.
Nice place with interesting exhibitions.
Well organised exhibits

editorial_summary.overview: Large facility with 5,000+ artifacts & displays documenting the history of Ukrainians in Canada.

522.name: Liss Gallery
522.formatted_address: 112 Cumberland St, Toronto, ON M5R 1A6, Canada
reviews: I recently visited to view the Dr. Seuss show. It was a wonderful experience, enjoying prints of such classic works. The owners were friendly and informative.

The Liss Gallery is a small gem of a place in Yorkville. I bought a beautiful print of Dr Seuss' Cat in the Hat there.  It inspires me whenever I look at it.  The staff were knowledgeable and helpful.  Great place I would recommend it.  I am looking forward to going back to see the exhibit of Dr Seuss' 60th anniversary Cat in the Hat and How the Grinch Stole Christmas prints.
The person working there was extremely friendly, and answered all the questions I had, and the exhibit was amazing

I remember this gallery owner. She had a gift shop in Montreal selling Eskimo art to American tourists. She called it a gallery but it was at best a gift shop. Not unusual she surfaced in Toronto selling amateur art. Not an addition to the Toronto scene. Pretentious about her knowledge. Drivel really.
Liss Gallery is wonderful. The proprietor is fabulous. Catch the Dr. Suess Exhibition well worth the visit.

523.name: Dufferin Grove Park
523.formatted_address: 875 Dufferin St, Toronto, ON M6H 3K8, Canada
reviews: We attended the Native Child Centre Powwow and it was an amazing atmosphere. The park was very accessible via parking and transit. Plus since it’s right next to the mall we were able to get drinks and use the washroom without any issues through the day (since we didn’t want to use the opera potties). Thanks for hosting a wonderful event and hope to attend next year.
Every time I go out shopping I pass by here and have some coffee. Very beautiful colours in the fall and very green during spring and summer. I wish there were a clean bike trail.

Great playground with lots of unique structures. There's areas for all ages, a 4 person see saw and a kids outdoor kitchen. Some stuff is starting to look dated and it's not great when it's muddy, but it's got charm. Good sledding Hill for smaller kids. It's been ages but have fond memories of visiting the farmers market, but I live too far to come for weekday markets. Today I discovered they have a city run fire pit too.
I absolutely love this beautiful park!!!  We want to an awesome pow wow there in October.
haunted as helllll I freaked myself out at 3:30 (yeah it’s superstitious but I was scared and I always chill there at any other hour np)

editorial_summary.overview: Large park with an ice rink & playground, plus basketball, picnic areas & a weekly farmer's market.

524.name: Museum of Contemporary Art Toronto Canada
524.formatted_address: 158 Sterling Rd #100, Toronto, ON M6R 2B7, Canada
reviews: Free Ground Floor entry and very reasonable pricing for paid exhibitions on 1st and 2nd floors. A wonderful space, with great original features (those concrete pillars!) And the most sumptuous cafe for pre or post treats.

Great space with contemporary art in a wide range of mediums. The current exhibit has some painting, photography, and sculpture but also includes works which utilize mixed media and interactivity. The museum occupies several floors and I recommend taking the stairs if you can.  There's a restaurant on the main floor but there is also a brewery and a coffee roastery nearby.

MOCA brings regularly rotated contemporary artists from all over the world and brings them to this gorgeous and spacious building! At the moment, there typically is only 3 floors and less than 5 exhibits/artists being featured, but its always awesome and thought provoking works of art! Every first Sunday of the month is free, sponsored by TD, so consider coming on one of those days.  MOCA has come a long way from their small gallery space on Queen West years ago, so we need to celebrate what they have been able to offer and make use of this beautiful space ❤️
Best place to spend Friday afternoon 🤩 This location has three floors of Contemporary Art. I would advise you to visit the Shirin Neshat exhibition while it is still ongoing (until July 31 2022)

A nice place to visit. One thing to note before going to the Museum of Contemporary Art Toronto is to review their website for the particular exhibition or display that is going on in the week you want to visit else you will be surprised by what you see compared to the art posted by reviewers. For example, during the day I visited, it was the exhibition of THOMAS DEMAND HOUSE OF CARD & MARTIN BOYCE, RIRKRIT TIRAVANIA, CARUSO STJOHN , and this is to run through December 2022. And so if you visit in February, you may not see any of these things.

editorial_summary.overview: Modern works by new & established artists are on display at this leading international art gallery.

525.name: Daniel Faria Gallery
525.formatted_address: 188 St Helens Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 4A1, Canada
reviews: Great gallery with great exhibits.  Well worth to get on the mailing list.  Always fascinating art and interesting people.
Interesting roster of Canadian artists, great gallery space and helpful friendly staff.
Didn't like the art display
Wonderful!

526.name: MacGregor Playground
526.formatted_address: 346 Lansdowne Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 3Y1, Canada
reviews: This is a great park for family's! Not so much for fur babies. This area is not dog friendly although I do break the rules lol

The red clay field is awesome to play on but the batter's box needs work; please note wood bats only at this location! Dog friendly place to socialize with nice grass to play, secluded shady areas available. Clean washrooms and the splashpad is so cool on a hot day. Love the train that pulls by every so often adding to ambience of Toronto. Quiet spot among the noise.
Field, track,  baseball diamond,  play structures, new splash pads, washrooms,  shade, Adirondack chairs, picnic bench, parking on street or behind school. Great place to spend hours
Great park for the kids to attend the splash pad!! My kid loved it. Ice cream truck goes by it frequently.

Such a great park! The splash pad is top. And there is a little park for the kids to play in after they’re done splashing around. There is usually free street side parking along the street. Must most importantly there are bathrooms which are relatively clean all things considered.

527.name: Wallace Emerson Park
527.formatted_address: 1260 Dufferin St, Toronto, ON M6H 4C3, Canada
reviews: This is a nice little park with a small ice rink next to a larger hockey I rink. If you’re coming to skate this is a nice place to go, but that’s pretty much all there is. It is next to a plaza so you can go do a bit of shopping after you are done skating. Lots of free parking.
Amazing place with amazing people. Enjoy it while you can before they remove the rinks.
Fantastic little skate area with both a proper rink with boards for hockey and independent skating area. They have change rooms on site and lots of oarking in the adjacent plaza (for now).

The playpark is large and stuffed with activities like a bball court, waterpark, playground with lots of things I wish I had as a kid plus a mighty fine skate park is located within a two minute walk! What else could you want?! Other than a pool I suppose!!!!
Love the ice hockey rink ( the one with the boards ) and leisure skating pad . Its a shame the condo developers at Galleria Mall are going to remove the ice rink for good

528.name: Campbell Park
528.formatted_address: 225 Campbell Ave, Toronto, ON M6P 3V5, Canada
reviews: Neat park, tucked in the Junction triangle. Kiddo plays in a soccer league there and she greatly enjoys it. There is a wadding pool/splash feature and a playground as well as a hockey rink. Everything I've gone there is young adults having a good time either playing soccer or picnic-ing
Nice little park in the block. Nicely maintained field.

The playground area covered in sand; nice and soft. If your kids love to play with sand this is the one! This place also has wading pool during summer time which is very nice!!! Its open from 12-7pm but come at around 1.30. They should be done with putting chemical in the pool around that time.
Nice place to get fresh air.  There is a hockey ring in this park. The restroom is closed for the season.
Great ice rink and park

editorial_summary.overview: Recreational oasis offering a playground, sports fields, a basketball court & wintertime ice rink.

529.name: Perth Square Park
529.formatted_address: 350 Perth Ave, Toronto, ON M6P 3Y3, Canada
reviews: This park is perfect for picnic. It has sandpit, playground and splash pad! Lots of big trees all over the park even for splash pad! Sometimes when you go to the park and wish it has washroom well yes this park has washroom!!
Best community park I've been to in awhile! Lots of friendly young and old families there . Lots of kids for your kids to play with. Even has a fire pit!

This quiet little park is a hidden gem. There is a fun splash pad for the kids and lots of grass (both shaded and unshaded) for picnicers or sunbathers. There's a Dominos and Tacos Gus just up the street so you aren't far from food. There are swings and other playground equipment for the kids, too. I recommend this place.

Splash pad! The kids love it. Very spacious and washroom is open. There's also a fire pit that's pretty much not monitored at the moment. You can also bbq here if you have coal or gas bbq. Nice friendly family vibe!

Lovely little park.  It has public washrooms, playground, and splash pad. There are big beautiful trees to take a break to sit in the shade as well as sunny open space.   It is a great place for a picnic, and it has public bathrooms. Clean, well kept, and also a nice walkway for baby carriages.

531.name: Green Line
531.formatted_address: 1401 Dufferin St, Toronto, ON M6H 4C7, Canada

532.name: Mackay Avenue
532.formatted_address: 133 MacKay Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 2N7, Canada

533.name: Mural 🐝
533.formatted_address: 1340 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6H 1P2, Canada
reviews: Very bright and colorful 🐝🐝🐝Mural.

534.name: Chelsea Avenue Playground
534.formatted_address: 103 Chelsea Ave, Toronto, ON M6P 2B7, Canada
reviews: One of my favourite parks, but the pool takes for ever to open. We all wish if the pool Starts at 9am.Also, there is no washroom.
Small, but has a decent playground for little ones.
No washroom! The pool opens at 11 but takes an hour to fill before the kids can swim. Otherwise good park!
It’s great but the splash pad takes forever to open don’t understand why since it’s open on many other parks

Beautiful little park encapsulated by Ivy growing up the tall fences. Lots of places to sit, nice playground/swings for the kids, water dispensers for a dog dish and one for a water bottle. It's nice to see a park with so much thought put into it for a change

535.name: Baird Park
535.formatted_address: 275 Keele St, Toronto, ON M6P, Canada
reviews: Great park with plenty of picnic benches. A lawn bowling club and a park for the kids. If I'm not mistaken I believe there is a dog park as well. Lots to do in such small park. Great place for hanging out

We've been taking our dog here since he was about 4 months old. Great off-leash park for younger dogs, enough room for them to run around while still being able to keep an eye on them. There's a fountain right outside the gate for when your thirsty pup needs a water refill.
One of the best neighbourhood dog parks.  Fun for both doggos and their humans. Plenty of shade for those hot summer days.
Great little park with splash pad, ping pong table, dog kennel, lawn bowling court, washrooms, playground.

Nestled on a residential area right next to Keele Street, this great little local park comes complete with an off leash area for dogs, a fenced in playground area for children, and a lawn bowling club, as well as enough grass to set up a picnic if you so choose.  It's also got some picnic benches, park benches, and some Muskoka chairs for relaxing in.

536.name: Bloordale Pond
536.formatted_address: Bloordale Village, Toronto, ON M6H 4E6, Canada
reviews: It's always so relaxing to sit by the pond. How nice of the City of Toronto to install such a lovely water feature.
I dropped by on a Sunday afternoon after heavy rainfall and enjoyed the reflection from the huge Kentucky Coffee Trees across the street in the still water. Well worth the visit!

Wonderful Reflective pond that also doubles as an impromptu ice rink come winter. Well maintained by the city so you are ensured a full bassin whenever there is a trickle of rain. A must-see.  #ThisCitySucks
When the water wars come, this pond will be our salvation
SO this is where all the water from the park water fountains is going...

537.name: Free Little Library
537.formatted_address: 21 St Clair Gardens, Toronto, ON M6E 3V6, Canada

538.name: Lithuania Park
538.formatted_address: 155 Oakmount Rd, Toronto, ON M6P 2M3, Canada
reviews: I love relaxing in this park. Beautiful community vines. All that's missing is drop in baseball games!

One of the nicer parks despite its size. Also one of the few approved sledding hills in the city. It has a field, newer play structures and a spray pad. Parking is scarce but its close to Keele station if you are taking transit.
It is a great park. They have got new monkey bars and kind playground. It is a lot of fun for everybody. And course, sledding in the Winter is the best!

Decent park for kids to play in, with a splash pad and other playground equipment. Upper baseball diamond area might be better used as a dog park since we rarely see a game on, but always see people playing there with their dogs

Great for walking with my pup when High Park is too busy as the neighbourhood is pleasant to stroll through (mostly dog - friendly).  In winter, a coyote might live in the hidden zone/ small northern ravine). We have only seen them once in 3 years, but others see one seasonally.  If you head North on Parkside, there is a small off-leash on the East side.

editorial_summary.overview: Park featuring a ball diamond & a multipurpose field, plus a playground & a wading pool.

539.name: The Junction mural
539.formatted_address: 2978 Dundas St W, Toronto, ON M6P 2R4, Canada
reviews: "The Junction" is name which originally came from the fact that The West Toronto Diamond, a junction of four railway lines. Historically The Junction was a manufacturing community that underwent a lot of development in the late 1800s. As in many railway and factory towns, pubs became a mainstay of the community and the drinking of the workers got so out of control that the sale of alcohol was banned in the Junction from for over 90 years.Even after The Junction was Annexed by Toronto, prohibition continued. As a result, it's no wonder this area struggled to attract businesses for a number of years.

540.name: Scott and Wallace's secret lare
540.formatted_address: 65 Alberta Ave, Toronto, ON M6H 2R7, Canada

541.name: We Are All Animals
541.formatted_address: 1844 Bloor St W, Toronto, ON M6P 3K6, Canada

542.name: The Little House
542.formatted_address: 128 Day Ave, Toronto, ON M6E 3W2, Canada
reviews: At 300 square feet, this house is the smallest in Toronto. It was even featured on an episode of the Ellen DeGeneres show a few years back.
Take a minor detour if you’re walking on Dufferin in this area and check out Toronto’s littlest house.

I have friends who live on this street, and though they prepared me for “the little house” it still wasn’t quite what I was expecting, it really is a tiny house amid a “normal” street. Real quirky feature that’s worth seeing!
Rather peculiar that this place is blotted out in Street View. I can't imagine a good reason, but Canadians can be a bit odd at times....
Wow! it’s so tiny!
